questions.text: A 40-year-old woman complains of anhedonia, insomnia, psychomotor retardation, decreased concentration, and low mood between December and January for the past 3 years. Which of the following is the first-line treatment for this patient?
questions.solution:
The clinical vignette describes seasonal affective disorder and the first line of treatment is SSRI + Phototherapy.

Seasonal Affective Disorder (SAD): 

Seasonal affective disorder is characterized by recurrent episodes of major depression, mania, or hypomania with seasonal onset. It is a subtype of the following mood disorders  - unipolar major depressive disorder, bipolar I disorder, or bipolar II disorder

In this disorder, patients typically experience depression as the photo-period of the day decreases with advancing winter. 

The first line of treatment involves SSRI + Phototherapy. SSRI monotherapy may be tried if phototherapy is contraindicated(ex: in retinal diseases or photosensitivity). Phototherapy typically involves exposing the affected patient to bright light for approximately 1 to 2 hours before dawn each day.

Phototherapy has also been used for the treatment of jet lag, seasonally varying OCD, and geriatric sleep disorders.

questions.text: A 40-year-old female presents with fatigue and cough. She has had these complaints for the past year and her symptoms have progressively worsened. She has noticed a streak of blood when coughing and states that her clothes fit loosely now. She has no history of smoking.  CT scan of her chest shows a 3cm mass located peripherally. Gene sequencing shows mutations in the EGFR gene. Which of the following is appropriate for the management of this patient?
questions.solution:
The clinical vignette is suggestive of a diagnosis of lung cancer(most likely adenocarcinoma) with EGFR mutation. EGFR mutation-sensitive lung cancers are highly sensitive to tyrosine kinase inhibitors of EGFR signal pathway such as Gefitinib and Erlotinib.

Adenocarcinoma of the lung presents with findings common to lung cancer such as cough, hemoptysis, fatigue, weight loss, dyspnea, and wheezing. Trousseau syndrome(migratory thrombophlebitis) is commonly seen as a paraneoplastic syndrome. Initial evaluation involves X-ray and CT scan of the chest with confirmatory through biopsy of the specimen. Among nonsmoking females, adenocarcinoma of the lung is the common lung cancer.

Other options:

Option D - Imatinib: Is a tyrosine kinase inhibitor effective in the treatment of CML and GIST.

Option A - Bevacizumab: monoclonal antibody against VEGF, used in the treatment of proliferative diabetic retinopathy

Option C - Paclitaxel: a taxane, is a plant alkaloid and chemotherapy agent

questions.text: A 53-year-old postmenopausal woman came to the OPD with complaint of urinary leakage since 6 weeks. Which of the following is the most appropriate first step in this patient’s evaluation for incontinence?
questions.solution:
In all women who present with urinary incontinence, urinalysis and culture should be done first in order to exclude any urinary tract infection. In patients diagnosed with UTI, treatment should be initiated and then the patient should be reevaluated.

Further evaluation for incontinence is done if UTI is excluded or if the incontinence persists despite appropriate antibiotic therapy. Postvoid residual volume and urodynamic studies may be performed.

questions.text: A 37-year-old woman with neurofibromatosis 1 (NF 1) brings her 9-year-old daughter to the pediatrician. She wants to know if the girl has NF 1. The presence of which of the following features would confirm NF 1 in the daughter?

choices.text: One iris hamartoma in the left eye

questions.solution:
The presence of one plexiform neurofibroma would confirm NF 1 in the daughter.

Neurofibromatosis type 1 (NF1) or von Recklinghausen's disease is an autosomal disease. NF1 is the most common of all neurofibromatosis. It is caused by a loss of function mutation, on the neurofibromin (NF1) gene. 

To diagnose neurofibromatosis 1, two or more of the following clinical manifestations should be present:

  • Six or more café-au-lait macules: > 5 mm in diameter in prepubertal and > 15 mm in diameter in postpubertal individuals
  • Axillary or inguinal freckling
  • Two or more iris Lisch nodules (hamartomas of iris)
  • Two or more neurofibromas or one plexiform neurofibroma
  • A distinctive osseous lesion such as sphenoidal and tibial bone dysplasia
  • Optic gliomas
  • A 1st-degree relative with NF-1

The FDA has recently approved a new drug selumetinib, mitogen-activated protein kinase 1 & 2 inhibitors for the treatment of NF1 in pediatric patients who are 2 years or older with symptomatic, inoperable plexiform neurofibromatosis. It can help reduce tumor progression.

questions.text:
A 35-year-old man is brought to the emergency room after a syncopal episode. Additionally, he complains of palpitations that had started before the syncopal episode. His BP is 135/90 mm of Hg and a heart rate is 110 bpm. He recently had started taking azithromycin for an infection. Serum electrolytes are as shown below
Serum Electrolytes Values Normal Range
Sodium (mmol/L)  140  135-145 
Chloride (mmol/L)  100 95-105
Potassium (mmol/L)  3 3.5-5 
Bicarbonate (mmol/L)  21 18-22 

ECG findings are shown in the image below. Which of the following is the first line for the management of this condition?
questions.solution:
The clinical vignette and ECG represent a case of torsades de pointes. Magnesium Sulphate is the first line of management in hemodynamically stable cases.

Torsades de pointes commonly present as syncope or chest pain. This patient's hypokalemia and use of azithromycin predispose him to develop symptomatic torsades de pointes.

Torsades de pointes means twisting of points, it implies twisting of the QRS complexes around the isoelectric line of the ECG. It is a form of polymorphic ventricular tachycardia that is seen in patients with prolonged QT interval. 

A prolonged QT interval usually results from prolonged ventricular repolarization (lengthening of the T wave). A premature ventricular contraction falling in the elongated T wave can initiate torsades de Pointes.

The features of torsades de pointes are:

  • Polymorphic QRS complexes that change in amplitude (as seen in the image)
  • Cycle length gives an appearance of oscillations around the baseline
  • QT prolongation

Other options:

Options B & C - Procainamide and Ibutilide are used in the management of Wolff Parkinson White syndrome. 

Option D - Defibrillation is indicated only if the patient is hemodynamically unstable, or as a last resort.

questions.text: A 50-year-old male presents with acute pain in his right big toe. He reports that he had a similar pain after an appendicectomy 2 years back. Vitals show BP of 145/100 mm of Hg. Physical examination is remarkable for a right 1st toe PIP joint that is swollen, erythematous, warm, and tender to palpation. Arthrocentesis and observation under a microscope show findings as shown below in the image. His acute episode is managed and the patient returns 3 weeks later for management of hypertension that was recently discovered. Which of the following drugs is recommended for the management of his hypertension?
questions.solution:
The clinical vignette with a patient having acute inflammation of the right first toe with the image showing negatively birefringent crystals is suggestive of a diagnosis of gout. For a patient with gout, losartan can be used for the management of hypertension.  

Losartan has a mild uricosuric effect and can be used for hypertension in gout. Other drugs deemed safe are calcium channel blockers. Beta blockers, ACE inhibitors and diuretics are not recommended for the treatment of gout.

Clinical features - extreme pain of joint(most commonly first metatarsophalangeal joint - podagra), stiff or swollen joint, deformity of the affected joint (ex: nodules), subcutaneous nodules

Diagnosis - Synovial fluid analysis - negatively birefringent needle-shaped crystals under polarized light

Treatment - NSAIDs, corticosteroids, colchicine, probenecid, allopurinol 

Changes in diet, including overindulging in certain foods & beverages, can cause gout attacks this time of year because holiday foods and drinks (high-fat food, sweetened beverages) can often be rich in purines. It can contribute to uric acid build-up.

questions.text: A 40-year-old woman comes to the clinic to discuss options for contraception. She has two children but is unsure whether she has completed her family. She has been smoking 4-5 cigarettes per day for the past 15 years. Her menses are regular, but with heavy menstrual bleeding. Which of the following will be the most ideal contraceptive method for this patient?
questions.solution:
The best contraceptive method for this patient would be a  Norplant (progesterone) subdermal implant. It is one of the most effective contraceptive methods other than sterilization.

This patient is unsure whether she has completed her family, so she cannot be offered surgical sterilization (Option D). Oral contraceptive pills (Option A) are contraindicated in this patient who is a smoker over 35 years of age. Copper-T intrauterine device (Option C) will worsen this patient's heavy menstrual bleeding; therefore, it is not the best choice for this patient. 

Mechanism of action of implants:

  • Inhibits ovulation in 90% of the cycles for the first one year of use
  • Also causes atrophy of the endometrium and cervical mucus thickening

Insertion:

The capsules are inserted subdermally, in the inner aspect of the nondominant arm, 6–8 cm above the elbow fold between the biceps and triceps muscles. 

The implants are inserted on the first day of the menstrual cycle, within 5 days of abortion, and 3 weeks after the delivery. The woman needs to use barrier contraception or abstain in the first 7 days of insertion.

Advantages of implants:

  • They are long-acting with sustained effect—compliance is good.
  • They are coitus-independent with no ‘nuisance’ of daily oral or frequent injections.
  • Pregnancy rate varies between 0.2 and 1.3 per 100 woman years.

Disadvantages of implants:

  • Breakthrough bleeding, irregular cycles, and amenorrhea occur as with other progestogenic contraceptives.
  • Ectopic pregnancy is reported in 1.3% of users.
  • Local infection may occur.
  • The implant requires insertion and removal with nonbiodegradable capsules, which are, however, minor surgical procedures.
  • The implants are expensive and cost rupees 10,000.

Norplant I  contains six silastic capsules- has been withdrawn and replaced by a single rod implant.

Norplant II (Jadelle) consists of two rods each containing 70 mg LNG. The daily release of hormone is 50 mcg, and it provides contraception for 3–5 years.

Implanon: Amenorrhea is common at the end of 1 year. Acne is reduced, and there is no risk of osteoporosis.

questions.text: A 50-year-old chronic alcoholic patient comes to your clinic with complaints of trembling of his hands for the last day. His past medical history includes bipolar disorder treated with risperidone, the dose of which was increased recently, hypertension treated with hydrochlorothiazide, and diabetes mellitus managed with metformin. He has tried to quit alcohol many times in the past but has been unsuccessful. His last drink was 5 days ago. On examination, he appears agitated and paces up and down the room. His pulse rate is 85 beats/min, respiratory rate is 18/minute and temperature is 99F.  Physical examination is unremarkable. Liver function tests were done, which revealed an AST: ALT ratio of 2.4. What is the diagnosis and the treatment in this patient?
questions.solution:
The given clinical complex describes a case of antipsychotic-induced akathisia due to risperidone.

Although tremulousness and agitation may also occur in alcohol withdrawal, they tend to occur hours after the last drink, not 5 days after, as in this patient. This patient also shows typical laboratory findings in a patient with alcoholic cirrhosis with the AST: ALT ratio >2. 

According to DSM V, medication-induced acute akathisia is subjective complaints of restlessness accompanied by observed movements (e.g., movement of the legs, rocking from foot to foot, pacing, or inability to sit or stand still) developing within a few weeks of starting or raising the dose of certain medications or after reducing a medication used to treat extrapyramidal symptoms.

Cause: Decreased dopamine in the ventral tegmental area and substantia nigra

Treatment:

  • Slow dose titration schedule, dose reduction, or switching to a less potent antipsychotic
  • First-line drugs - Beta-blockers
  • Second line drugs - benzodiazepines like lorazepam
  • Third line drugs - Anticholinergic agents like trihexyphenidyl, benztropine

questions.text: A 6-year-old girl was rescued from a neglected household. The girl was in severe malnutrition and was therefore fed high-calorie meals at the rehabilitation home. She developed confusion and seizures. Investigations revealed that her serum phosphate, potassium, and magnesium levels were low. These electrolyte abnormalities are due to excessive administration of ____.
questions.solution:
The child in this case is suffering from refeeding syndrome, and her serum phosphate, potassium, and magnesium levels are low due to the increased serum insulin levels, which in turn is caused due to the excessive administration of carbohydrates.

The hallmark of refeeding syndrome is the development of severe hypophosphatemia after the cellular uptake of phosphate during the 1st week of starting refeeding.

Refeeding syndrome is a complication of the acute nutritional rehabilitation of children who are undernourished from any cause, and it may follow overly aggressive enteral or parenteral alimentation. 

When excessive carbohydrates are administered, the resultant increase in serum insulin levels may produce the following:

  • Hypophosphatemia (hallmark)
  • Hypokalemia
  • Hypomagnesemia

Hypophosphatemia can produce the following manifestations:

  • Cardiac: Hypotension, Decreased stroke volume
  • Respiratory: Impaired diaphragm contractility, Dyspnea, Respiratory failure
  • Neurologic: Paresthesia, Weakness, Confusion, Disorientation, Lethargy, Areflexic paralysis, Seizures, Coma
  • Hematologic: Leukocyte dysfunction, Hemolysis, Thrombocytopenia

A controlled transition over 3 days is recommended by the WHO for treating malnutrition, to prevent refeeding syndrome.

questions.text: A young boy who was driving a motorcycle at a high speed collided with a tree and was thrown on his right shoulder.  An X-ray of the patient is given below. Which of the following nerves is affected in this patient?

choices.text: Lower lateral cutaneous nerve of the arm
Medial cutaneous nerve of the arm
Upper lateral cutaneous nerve of the arm
Posterior cutaneous nerve of the arm

questions.solution:
The X-ray indicates that this is a case of anterior shoulder dislocation, and the structure most commonly injured here is the axillary nerve. The upper lateral cutaneous nerve of the arm is a branch of the axillary nerve. 

It supplies the skin over the lower half of the deltoid.

The course of Axillary nerve:

  • Origin - Posterior cord of brachial plexus in the axilla. In the lower part of the axilla, it runs behind the third part of the axillary artery, where it lies on the subscapularis and is medial to the median nerve
  • In Axilla - Exits the axilla through the quadrangular space to enter the arm accompanied by the posterior circumflex humeral vessels.

Axillary nerve divides as anterior and posterior branches at the deltoid and supplies the following structures

  • Anterior branch - deltoid and skin over anteroinferior part
  • Posterior branch - teres minor and posterior part of the deltoid; continues as the upper lateral cutaneous nerve of the arm

Axillary nerve injury: 

It is mostly due to a fracture of the surgical neck of the humerus, inferior dislocation of the humerus, and inadvertent IM injection.

Anterior dislocation

It is the most common shoulder dislocation. It is caused by trauma from behind the shoulder pushing the head out anteriorly. It may also be caused due to falling on an outstretched hand in an abducted and externally rotated shoulder. Associated findings include tearing of the capsule, producing avulsion of the glenoid labrum (the Bankart lesion) or a crushed posterolateral part of the head, giving rise to a Hill–Sachs lesion.

The patients present with extreme pain and wish to avoid being examined. On examination, the lateral outline of the shoulder may be flattened out, and there is an inability to touch his/her opposite shoulder (Duga's test). X-ray confirms the diagnosis and shows overlapping shadows of the humeral head and glenoid fossa in AP view and a humeral head out of line with the socket in a lateral view.

Other options: 

Option A: The lower lateral cutaneous nerve of the arm is a branch of the radial nerve. Supplies the skin of the lateral side of the arm 

Option B: The medial cutaneous nerve of the arm is a branch of the medial cord.  Supplies the skin on the medial side of the inferior half of the arm, posterior to the basilic vein. 

Option D:  The posterior cutaneous nerve of the arm is a branch of the radial nerve.  Supplies the skin of the back of the arm from the insertion of the deltoid to the olecranon.

questions.text: A 67-year-old male presents to the emergency department with sudden painless vision loss in his left eye. He has had a similar episode before but his vision was quickly restored. On physical exam, a carotid bruit is heard and a relative afferent pupillary defect is noted on ocular examination. His fundus appears as shown below. Which of the following is the best immediate step in the management of this condition?
questions.solution:
Sudden painless unilateral vision loss with carotid bruit (carotid artery disease) and the fundus picture showing a cherry-red spot is suggestive of central retinal artery occlusion (CRAO). The best immediate step in management is ocular massage among the given options.

Central retinal artery occlusion (CRAO) occurs due to obstruction of the retinal artery at the level of lamina cribrosa. Risk factors include heart disease, carotid artery disease, mucormycosis, varicella infection, radiation exposure and trauma. It may be caused by the following: 

  • Emboli of carotid artery or cardiac origin are the most common cause of CRAO. Other emboli are cholesterol emboli, calcium emboli, and platelet fibrin emboli
  • Atherosclerosis-related thrombosis
  • Retinal arteritis with obliteration
  • Angiospasm
  • Raised intraocular pressure
  • Thrombophilic disorders

Patients often present with sudden painless monocular loss of vision with history of a similar episode that resolved spontaneously (amaurosis fugax). On examination, direct pupillary reflex is absent and relative afferent pupillary defect (RAPD) is positive. Fundus examination shows marked attenuation of arteries (thread like arteries), interrupted blood flow in vein (cattle track appearance), cherry red spot, severe edema and retinal pallor.

A cherry-red spot of the macula is typical and arises in this area because of the absence of ganglion cells at the foveola resulting in the transmission of the normal choroidal color. This in contrast to the surrounding area where intense retinal whitening blocks the transmission of the normal choroidal color.

Treatment is to dislodge the emboli by suddenly decreasing the IOP by IV acetazolamide or ocular massage. Ocular massage is considered the most effective method. Other treatment options include IV mannitol, vasodilators (nitrates), fibrinolytic therapy, or laser photodisruption in some cases. In cases of giant cell arteritis, steroids are beneficial.

Related Pearl: Important causes of cherry-red spots

  • Commotio retinae
  • Central retinal and cilioretinal artery occlusion
  • Metabolic storage diseases
    • GM1 gangliosidosis
    • Mucolipidosis type I (sialidosis)
    • GM2 gangliosidosis (Tay-Sachs disease and Sandhoff disease)
    • Farber disease
    • Niemann–Pick disease
  • Retinotoxicity due to specific agents, including quinine, dapsone, gentamicin, carbon monoxide, and methanol

questions.text: A 48-year-old male who is a known diabetic for 10 years has been hospitalised due to community-acquired pneumonia. 5 days later, he developed significant dyspnea, tachypnea, cyanosis. Chest X-ray revealed diffuse bilateral coalescent opacities.  The arterial PaO2/FiO2 ratio is 120 mmHg. There are no signs suggestive of cardiac failure, on  examination. Which of the following statements is incorrect regarding the inflammatory response in this condition?

choices.text: Lymphocytes play the most significant role in tissue injury.
It is known as shock lung.
Damage to the endothelial cells is the key initiating event.
Prognosis is poor with high mortality rates.

questions.solution:
Acute respiratory distress syndrome (ARDS) has set in this patient with pneumonia. Shock lung also known as ARDS/ HMD/ ALI  is characterised histologically by diffuse alveolar damage. Neutrophils play a significant role in tissue injury in this condition.

The characteristic histological picture is that of a hyaline membrane lining the alveolar walls. Edema, scattered neutrophils and macrophages, and necrotic epithelial cells are also present.

ARDS is a clinical syndrome manifested as a result of severe lung injury and characterized by inflammation, which causes increased pulmonary vascular permeability and edema. Damage to the endothelial and alveolar epithelial cells, with inflammation, is the key initiating event and the basis of lung damage. Acute respiratory distress syndrome (ARDS) is a manifestation of severe ALI.

In ARDS, neutrophils adhere to the activated endothelium and migrate into the interstitium and the alveoli, where they degranulate and release inflammatory mediators, including proteases, reactive oxygen species, and cytokines.

Diagnostic criteria in ARDS—Berlin definition: The Berlin definition requires each of the following criteria to be present to diagnose ARDS:

  1. Onset- Acute: Respiratory symptoms must have begun within one week of a known clinical insult
  2. Bilateral alveolar or interstitial infiltrates: must be present on a chest X-ray image or CT scan
  3. Respiratory failure must not be fully explained by cardiac failure or fluid overload. Objective assessment e.g Echo should be done in cases of no known cause.
  4. Impairment of oxygenation must be present: The severity of hypoxemia defines the severity of ARDS

Severity

PaO2/FiO2 (On ventilator settings that include PEEP ≥5 cm H2O)

Mild

> 200 mmHg but ≤ 300 mmHg

Moderate

> 100 mmHg but ≤ 200 mmHg
Severe

≤ 100 mmHg

ARDS is clinically characterized by the abrupt onset of significant hypoxemia and bilateral pulmonary infiltrates in the absence of cardiac failure. Chest x-ray shows diffuse bilateral infiltrates- white-out appearance.  The prognosis is poor with high mortality (40%). (Option D)

questions.text:
The graph below represents a type of inhibition. Read the examples listed below and select all that follow the kinetics shown in the graph.
  1. Cyanide on cytochrome c oxidase
  2. Malonate on succinate dehydrogenase
  3. Alanine on pyruvate kinase
  4. Arsenic on glyceraldehyde 3-phosphate dehydrogenase
  5. Glucose-6-phosphate on hexokinase
questions.solution:
The given image shows a 'Lineweaver-Burk plot' or 'double reciprocal' plot of non-competitive inhibition. Among the given options, all are examples of non-competitive inhibition, except for the action of malonate on succinate dehydrogenase, which is an example of competitive inhibition.

Noncompetitive inhibition cannot be overcome by increasing the concentration of the substrate. Thus, noncompetitive inhibitors decrease the Vmax of the reaction. They do not interfere with the binding of the substrate to the enzyme. Thus, the enzyme shows the same Km in the presence or absence of noncompetitive inhibitors.

1/v0 is plotted versus 1/[S] and a straight line is obtained.This plot can be used to calculate Km and Vmax as well as to determine the mechanism of action of enzyme inhibitors.

In non-competitive inhibition, Vmax decreases (or 1/Vmax increases) but Km is unchanged. Hence the graphs of inhibited and uninhibited reactions have the same x-intercepts (converge at -1/Km) but different y-intercepts.

In contrast to competitive inhibitors, noncompetitive inhibitors bind to enzymes in locations remote from the active site. For this reason, the degree of inhibition is based solely upon the concentration of inhibitor, and increasing the substrate concentrations does not compete with or change the inhibition. Therefore, unlike the increase in Km seen with competitive inhibition, in noncompetitive inhibition, Vmax decreases while Km usually remains the same. While competitive inhibitors can be overcome at a sufficiently high concentration of substrate, noncompetitive inhibition is irreversible.

Competitive Inhibition: when the active site or catalytic site of an enzyme is occupied by a substance other than the substrate of that enzyme, its activity is inhibited. This type of inhibition is known as competitive inhibition.

eg: succinate dehydrogenase reaction is inhibited by malonate.

Competitive Inhibition is reversible.

In Competitive inhibition:

  • Vmax remains constant
  • Km increases (MNEMONIC: In competition, we run for KILOMETRES i.e. Km; Hence remember as Km increases in Competitive inhibition).

Graph showing the changes in Vmax and Km in competitive and noncompetitive inhibition.

questions.text: A 14-year-old boy is brought to the clinic with complaints of involuntary, sudden jerking movements of both upper limbs. He had preserved consciousness throughout the episode, maintained a standing posture, and did not have post-ictal confusion. He has had similar episodes and they have occurred early in the morning after awakening especially when he does not get enough sleep. An EEG study performed on the day of OPD visit was not conclusive. A repeat EEG study performed as soon as the patient awakes reveals a clinching finding. This is likely to be _____________

choices.text: Irregular 4-6 Hz Spike-and- wave activity occurring in bursts
3 Hz spikes amidst a background of slow wave discharges

questions.solution:
The clinical vignette is characteristic of juvenile myoclonic epilepsy. EEG findings here show Irregular 4-6 Hz Spike-and- wave activity occurring in bursts 

Myoclonic seizures are characterized by:

  • Preserved consciousness
  • Preserved postural control
  • Lack of postictal confusion

Myoclonic seizures usually coexist with other forms of generalized seizures but are the predominant feature of juvenile myoclonic epilepsy (JME). The EEG shows bilaterally synchronous spike-and-slow wave discharges.

 

Juvenile myoclonic epilepsy (Janz syndrome):

  • It is the most common generalized epilepsy in young adults ( 12-18 years).
  • They are benign generalized myoclonic seizures with a good prognosis.
  • Typically, it starts in early adolescence (12-18 years), with 1 or more of the following manifestations:
    • Myoclonic jerks in the morning (“shock-like” contraction of a muscle, that is often repeated), generalized tonic–clonic or clonic seizures upon awakening; and juvenile absences.
    • Sleep deprivation, alcohol (in older patients), and photic stimulation provoke seizures.
    • The EEG usually shows generalized 4-5 Hz polyspike and slow-wave discharges.
  • The drug of choice for juvenile myoclonic epilepsy is valproate. Lamotrigine is also useful.

Other options:

  • Option B - 3 Hz spike-wave discharges - seen in absence seizures.
  • Option C - Periodic sharp wave complexes - seen in Creutzfeldt Jakob disease.
  • Option D - Spindles and K-complexes - seen in the N2 phase of normal NREM sleep.

Absence seizures 3 Hz spike and slow-wave (spike and dome pattern)
Juvenile myoclonic epilepsy 4-6 Hz spike
West syndrome Hypsarrhythmia (high-voltage waves with chaotic background)

questions.text: A 40-year-old obese female patient presents with severe abdominal pain. On examination, abdominal tenderness is present over the right hypochondrium and epigastrium. Her erect X-ray of the abdomen is given below. What would be the histopathological section of the affected organ show?
questions.solution:
The given scenario and the x-ray image of the porcelain gall bladder are suggestive of chronic cholecystitis. The histopathology of the affected organ would be showing dystrophic calcifications of the gall bladder.

The porcelain gall bladder is a morphological feature seen in chronic cholecystitis and is characterized by dystrophic calcification. It is a pathologic calcification in which calcium gets deposited at the sites of cell injury and necrosis. 

Other Options:

Option A: Rokitansky–Aschoff sinuses are the outpouchings of the gallbladder mucosa through the gallbladder wall seen in chronic cholecystitis. They can rupture and develop into xanthogranulomatous cholecystitis.

Option B: Xanthogranulomatous cholecystitis is characterized by xanthoma cells. These are macrophages that have ingested biliary phospholipids. In this condition, the gallbladder is shrunken, nodular, and has thickened walls. 

Option D: Hydrops of the gallbladder is characterized by clear secretions within an atrophic, obstructed, and dilated gall bladder.

The below image shows Rokitansky–Aschoff's sinus.

questions.text: A 55-year-old patient presents with a pink, scaly, non-firm patch on his trunk that he observed about a month ago. It has increased in size since then. Histopathology shows ovoid cells in nests and palisading of the peripheral cells of the nests. You prescribe a 5-fluorouracil cream. Where does this drug act in the image given below?
questions.solution:
A pink, scaly, non-firm patch that is gradually increasing in size showing ovoid cells in nests with palisading peripheral cells suggests a diagnosis of superficial basal cell carcinoma. The antimetabolite that is used for topical treatment of this condition is 5-fluorouracil, an S-phase inhibitor. DNA synthesis occurs in the S-phase of the mitosis cycle. 

5-FU acts via two different pathways depending on its dose: G1- S-phase cell cycle arrest and apoptosis at a higher dose and G2-M-phase cell cycle arrest at a low dose.

5-FU:

  • Converted in the body to the corresponding nucleotide 5-deoxyuridine monophosphate, which forms a covalent ternary complex with methyl-THFA and thymidylate synthase, resulting in the irreversible inhibition of thymidylate synthase.
  • Failure of DNA synthesis occurs due to the non-availability of thymidylate.
  • Inhibition of TS by 5-FU depends on THFA, infusion of leucovorin will enhance the efficacy of this drug. Cisplatin and oxaliplatin also synergize with this drug.
  • Rapidly dividing cells are most commonly affected, but resting cells are also affected.
  • Used as an anticancer drug for many solid cancers such as the colon, rectum, stomach, pancreas, liver, urinary bladder, head, and neck. Topical preparations are used in BCC and actinic keratosis.
  • Toxicity includes myelosuppression, mucositis, diarrhea, nausea, and vomiting. Peripheral neuropathy may also occur.

Basal cell carcinoma is a malignant tumor of the epithelial cells arising from the basal epidermis.

The strongest risk factor for developing basal cell carcinoma is exposure to UV radiation. Therefore, it occurs on the sun-exposed areas of the skin, most commonly on the nose and face.

BCC can be divided into localized and generalized.

Localized BCC can be further divided into

  • Nodular and nodulocystic - accounts for the majority of BCC
  • Cystic
  • Pigmented
  • Nevoid

Generalized BCC can be further divided into superficial or infiltrative.

Nodular BCC presents a small, slowly growing pearly nodule, often with tortuous telangiectatic vessels on its surface, rolled borders, and a central crust.

The characteristic finding of BCC is the presence of ovoid cells in nests and palisading of the peripheral cells of the nests, which are shown in the image below.

 

Treatment of BCC includes excision of the lesion or Moh's micrographic surgery, topical imiquimod, topical 5-FU, photodynamic therapy, cryotherapy, radiation, or intralesional therapy.

questions.text: A 50-year-old man complains of left shoulder pain for the past several months. He is a painter and he states that overhead movements now cause him pain in his left shoulder. Physical examination reveals tenderness over the lateral shoulder. As part of the clinical examination, the physician asks the patient to place his hand on his abdomen and bring his elbow forward. The patient is then asked to press his hand into his abdomen. Which muscle does this test specifically test for?
questions.solution:
The clinical vignette describes a case of rotator cuff tear and the patient is being asked to perform a belly press test which tests for the subscapularis muscle.

Belly press test - For subscapularis – The patient is asked to place his hand on his abdomen and bring his elbow forward. The patient is then asked to press his hand into his abdomen. If the subscapularis is torn, the patient will be unable to do this and the elbow will move backward.

The following are tests to check the function of individual muscles - 

  • Supraspinatus – Empty can test (Jobe) - The patient raises his or her arms to a position of 90 degrees abduction, 30 degrees of forward flexion, and internal rotation. The examiner applies downward pressure on both arms from behind the patient. The test is positive when one side is weaker than the other side.
  • Infraspinatus – Resisted external rotation - The patient flexes elbows to 90 degrees and stands holding his/her arm close to the body. The patient then externally rotates both arms while the examiner applies resistance; lack of power on one side signifies weakness of infraspinatus. The test can be repeated in the plane of the scapula with the arm in 90 degrees of forward elevation. The patient is asked to laterally rotate the arm against resistance; the inability to do so suggests a tear of the infraspinatus.
  • Infraspinatus and posterior cuff – ‘Lag sign’ and the ‘Drop sign’ - The lag sign is performed by asking the patient to lift his arms slightly away from the body and place them in maximum external rotation. A positive test is signaled when the patient cannot maintain that position on one side and allows the arm to drift into a more neutral position. This suggests a tear of infraspinatus or supraspinatus. The drop sign is similar: here the arm is in 90  degrees of abduction, the elbow at a right angle and the arm maximally externally rotated; when the examiner lets go, the patient would normally hold that position, but if the arm ‘drops’, it signals a positive test
  • Subscapularis – The lift-off test - The patient places one arm behind his or her back with the dorsum of the hand resting against the mid-lumbar spine. The patient’s hand is lifted off the back and the patient is told to hold it there. Inability to do this signifies subscapularis weakness. 

Rotator cuff tear - 

Risk factors - old age, smoking, 

Clinical features - pain and weakness with shoulder movement.

Physical exam - 

  • Active painful arc test
  • Drop arm test 
  • Weakness in external rotation

questions.text: A 26-year-old woman presented with vertigo, tinnitus, and hearing loss. A glycerol test and electrocochleography were performed to diagnose her condition, and promethazine was prescribed for management. A few days later she presents with complaints of a sudden loss of tone without loss of consciousness. She states that she felt like she was pushed to the ground. What is this phenomenon called?
questions.solution:
The clinical vignette describes a case of Meniere's disease with Tumarkin's otolithic crisis.

Meniere's disease (MD) or endolymphatic hydrops is an auditory disease characterized by an episodic sudden onset of vertigo, low-frequency hearing loss (in the early stages of the disorder), low-frequency roaring tinnitus, and sensation of fullness in the affected ear.

Variants of MD:

  • Tumarkin’s otolithic crisis (drop attacks) is when a patient with Meniere’s develops sudden drop attacks without loss of consciousness. It is an uncommon manifestation. Pathogenesis is not well understood.
  • Lermoyez syndrome - Here, symptoms of MD are seen in reverse order. Initially, there is a progressive deterioration of hearing, followed by an attack of vertigo.
  • Vestibular hydrops - Typical episodes of vertigo occur while cochlear function remains intact.
  • Cochlear hydrops - Only cochlear functions are impaired, while vertigo episodes do not appear until later.

Other options

Tullio phenomenon - It is a condition seen with some cases of Meniere's disease, where loud sounds or noise produce vertigo. This phenomenon is due to the distended saccule lying against the stapes footplate.

questions.text: A male baby was brought to the pediatrician in the 5th week of life with complaints of non-bilious vomiting after feeding. A mass could be palpated in the right upper quadrant. Ultrasound of the abdomen shows the following. Which of the following is the most likely acid-base status in this patient?
questions.solution:
The clinical scenario and the image showing thickened pylorus, with cervix sign and nipple sign on ultrasound is suggestive of infantile hypertrophic pyloric stenosis. The acid-base abnormality seen in this condition is hypokalemic hypochloremic metabolic alkalosis, hence the ABG which shows a pH: 7.48, pCO2: 47, HCO3: 30 is the answer.

A pH >7.40, with increased HCO3, and increased pCO2 indicate metabolic alkalosis.

Hypertrophic pyloric stenosis most presents with non-bilious projectile vomiting. It is common between 2 and 8 weeks of age. Hypertrophy of the circular muscle of the pylorus results in constriction and obstruction of the gastric outlet. Male infants are at a higher risk.

Clinically, an olive-shaped mass is palpable in the right upper quadrant or epigastrium. When the infant is given a test feed, visible peristalsis is usually observed moving from left to right across the abdomen.

Infants with hypertrophic pyloric stenosis develop a characteristic metabolic abnormality- hypochloraemic hypokalaemic metabolic alkalosis. Persistent vomiting results in loss of hydrochloric acid leading to the development of metabolic alkalosis (due to loss of H+) and hypochloremia (due to loss of Cl-).

Diagnosis:

Ultrasound examination is the Investigation of choice for this condition. Ultrasound examination confirms the diagnosis of congenital hypertrophic pyloric stenosis (CHPS) in the majority of cases. The diagnostic criteria for pyloric stenosis are a muscle thickness of ≥4 mm and a pyloric length of ≥16 mm. The cervix sign and nipple sign are signs seen on USG.

  • Nipple sign- Double-layered hypertrophic mucosa protrudes into the stomach
  • Cervix sign- The sonographic appearance of the hypertrophied pylorus resembles that of the uterine cervix 

Management:

  • The child should be rehydrated and the metabolic abnormality has to be corrected before proceeding to surgery.
  • The Ramstedt pyloromyotomy remains the standard surgical procedure for its treatment.

Related Pearl: Radiological findings in various GI disorders

Duodenal atresia: Double bubble sign

 

Jejunal and ileal atresia: Multiple air-fluid levels (plain erect X-ray abdomen) presenting as triple bubble sign. 

 

Congenital hypertrophic pyloric stenosis: Single enlarged gastric gas bubble - single bubble sign

 

Sigmoid volvulus: Coffee bean sign 

 

Achalasia cardia: Bird-beak sign

 

Small bowel obstruction: The obstructed bowel loops are central in location and show valvulae conniventes (mucosal folds that cross the entire diameter of the bowel) characteristic of jejunal involvement.

Large bowel obstruction: The presence of haustrations is a feature of large bowel obstruction. Haustral folds are irregular and do not cross the entire diameter of the bowel. These are absent in the caecum. 

 

Caecal volvulus: Presence of caecal dilatation, single air-fluid level extending into the left upper quadrant, and absence of gas in the distal colon. The colonic haustrations are well maintained.

 

Midgut volvulus: Corkscrew appearance showing the duodenum and jejunum spiraling around the mesenteric vessels in upper GI contrast studies.

 

Necrotizing enterocolitis (NEC): Abdominal X-ray findings include pneumatosis intestinalis (air in the bowel wall).

Cystic fibrosis (CF): Abdominal x-ray with contrast enema reveals a microcolon with several meconium plugs.

Related Pearl: Interpretation of Acid-Base Disorders

pH<7.35 is acidosis

pH>7.45 is alkalosis

A primary change in HCO3- is termed metabolic

If the change in HCO3- is in keeping with the pH (i.e. if there are acidosis and HCO3- is decreased) the problem is metabolic.

If the change in HCO3- is opposite with the pH (i.e. if there is acidosis and HCO3- is increased or normal) the problem is compensatory metabolic.

A primary change in CO2 is termed as respiratory

If the change in CO2 keeping in line with the pH (if in acidosis CO2 is raised) the problem is termed respiratory

If the change in CO2 is in the opposite direction of that of the pH (i.e. if there are acidosis and CO2 is decreased or normal ) the problem is termed compensatory respiratory

questions.text: A 24-year-old woman presents in her third month of pregnancy for an antenatal visit. Identify the correct dosage and duration of supplements to be taken according to the 'Anemia Mukt Bharat' scheme of the Government of India.

questions.solution:
The Anemia Mukt Bharat guideline recommends 60 mg of elemental iron and 500 μg of folic acid daily at least for 180 days, starting from the 4th month of pregnancy and continued throughout pregnancy. Ideally, this must also be followed for 180 days postpartum.

This patient should also be made aware of the color of the tablet which is red. This would help ensure she takes the correct tablet and does not end up taking a pink IFA tablet which is given for Children 5-9 years of age and contains only 45 mg elemental Iron + 400 mcg Folic Acid.

questions.text: 32 grams of bleaching powder was required to disinfect 1820 liters of well water. When measuring the chlorine demand with the below-given apparatus for this well water, which cup would have shown the blue color after adding the indicator?
questions.solution:
The given image is of Horrock's apparatus used to measure chlorine demand of water, 4th cup would have shown blue color for it to require 32 grams of bleaching powder to disinfect 1820 liters of well water.

Since 1820/455=4, the amount of bleaching powder required to disinfect 455 liters of water is 32/4=8 grams

To calculate the dose of bleaching required to disinfect 455 liters of water, the formula is (n×2). As we know the dose required, we have to calculate 'n' (n represents the position of the cup which was first to show the color).

8=n×2, therefore n=4.

The fourth cup would have turned blue on adding the indicator.

Related Pearl: Horrock’s Apparatus

  • Horrock’s Apparatus is used to estimate the chlorine demand of water.
  • This is widely used in the disinfection of wells to find out how much bleaching powder is required.
  • Contents of this water-testing apparatus:
    • 6 white cups of 200 ml each and one black cup with a circular mark
    • 2 metal spoons (each holds 2g of bleaching powder)
    • 7 glass stirring rods and 1 special pipette
    • Two droppers
    • Starch-iodide indicator solution
  • Procedure:
    • Use 2g of bleaching powder to create a thin paste in the black cup. It is now called the Chlorine stock solution.
    • The six white cups are filled with the water to be tested
    • Add one drop of the stock solution to the 1st cup, two drops to the 2nd cup, three drops to the 3rd cup, and so on till adding six drops to the 6th cup.
    • Stir the cups and wait for half an hour.
    • Add 3 drops of starch-iodide indicator to each cup
    • Development of blue color in the apparatus indicates free residual chlorine. 
    • The first cup which develops this color gives an estimate of the amount of bleaching powder needed to disinfect 455 Litres of the sample water.
  • Chlorine demand or the dose of bleaching powder required is given by (n x 2) g for 455 liters of water, i.e., (n x 2) g of bleaching powder is required to disinfect 455 liters of water. Here, n represents the position of the cup (1, 2, 3, etc.) that was first to show a distinct blue color.

questions.text: A 45-year-old woman presented with abnormal uterine bleeding. The images below show the transverse section of the uterus and the histology of the specimen. What is your diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The gross specimen shows thickened myometrium with spongy, trabeculated surface, with focal areas of haemorrhage. The H&E stained specimen shows endometrial glands and the surrounding stroma within the uterine myometrium. These findings are suggestive of adenomyosis.

Adenomyosis is a condition caused by the ingrowth of the endometrial tissue into the uterine wall. The presence of endometrial glands and stroma with the uterine myometrium eventually leads to the thickening of the uterine wall.

Patients present with abnormal uterine bleeding (AUB), dysmenorrhea and dyspareunia. Diagnosis is usually made with transvaginal ultrasonography (TVS) or MR imaging. Hysterectomy is the definitive treatment.

questions.text: A 50-year-old man presented with gradually progressive cough, hemoptysis, breathlessness and weight loss for the past 6 months. He has been working for a company that manufactures roofing sheets with asbestos for the past 15 years. The company did not provide him with personal protective equipment. Lung biopsy showed the following picture. Which immunohistochemical marker will be most likely positive in this condition?
questions.solution:
The clinical picture, occupational history of asbestos exposure and the histological image showing lepidic growth patterns are seen in adenocarcinoma of the lung. Thyroid transcription factor-1 (TTF-1), mucin, and napsin-A are the markers for adenocarcinoma.

Lepidic growth patten refers to the pattern of spread of the tumor in which the tumor cells “crawl” along normal-appearing alveolar septae and resembles butterflies resting on a fence.

Tumors of 3 cm or less in diameter characterized by lepidic growth pattern without stromal invasion are now called adenocarcinoma in situ (formerly called bronchoalveolar carcinoma).

Adenocarcinoma of lung:

  • Adenocarcinomas grow in various patterns, including acinar, lepidic, papillary, micropapillary, and solid with mucin formation. Tumor cells are positive for mucin and thyroid transcription factor-1 (TTF-1).
  • It is the most common form of lung cancer. It is an invasive malignant epithelial tumor with glandular differentiation or mucin production by the tumor cells. It is usually located peripherally (it arises from terminal bronchiole).  Molecular genetics show frequent mutations in EGFR, ALK, ROS, MET, and RET (Receptor tyrosine kinase genes) or KRAS mutations.
  • The most common asbestos-related cancer is lung adenocarcinoma. 

Lung cancer (of all histologic types) is the most common cancer associated with asbestos exposure Pleural mesothelioma is the most specific cancer associated with asbestos exposure. Smoking does not seem to be associated with mesothelioma. Pleuritic chest pain or a mass on the radiographic image are common presentations. 

TTF-1 was first identified in the thyroid, this factor is required for normal lung development.

TTF-1 can be used to distinguish primary adenocarcinoma of the lungs (TTF-1 positive) from other histological types of lung cancers, metastatic adenocarcinoma, and mesothelioma (TTF-1 negative)

P40 and P63 are the markers for squamous cell carcinoma.

Chromogranin, synaptophysin, and CD56 are the markers for small cell lung carcinoma.

Related Pearl: Types of lung cancer

questions.text: Which of the following layers of the epidermis is characterized by the presence of keratohyalin granules?
questions.solution:
Deeply staining granules in the cytoplasm called keratohyalin granules are seen in the stratum granulosum which is marked as 'B' in this image.

The image shows the histological appearance of the epidermis of the skin. The structures marked are respectively:

  • A- Stratum corneum-
    The most superficial layer. It is acellular and made up of flattened squames (scale-like elements) containing keratin filaments embedded in protein. This layer is highly resistant to permeation by water due to its high water content.
  • B- Stratum granulosum-
    Characterised by the presence of deeply staining keratohyalin granules in the cytoplasm. Additionally, condensed and dark staining (pyknotic) nuclei are seen in this area.
  • C- Stratum spinosum-
    Also referred to as the prickle cell layer. Stratum spinosum consists of inter-cellular attachments called desmosomes. During the H&E mounting, the cells shrink and retract at places other than their attachment at the desmosomes. Thus, these desmosomes appear like spines on the cells on microscopy, and hence the cells are called prickle cells. Several layers of polygonal keratinocytes that constitute the stratum spinosum (or Malpighian layer) 
  • D- Stratum basale-
    The deepest or basal layer of the epidermis. It is made up of a single layer of columnar cells that rest on a basal lamina. It contains stem cells that give off keratinocytes which form the more superficial layers of the epidermis. Hence, it is also called the germinal layer or stratum germinativum.

The above 4 layers are present in the thin hairy skin. 

The thick glabrous skin over the palms and the soles contain an additional clear homogenous 5th layer between the stratum corneum and stratum granulosum, called the stratum lucidum.

questions.text: The laryngoscopic appearance of the subglottis in an infant with a history of cardiac surgery is as shown below. Based on this you would expect the infant to have _________________
questions.solution:
An infant with a history of cardiac surgery, which would have required intubation, and laryngoscopy showing narrowing points towards a diagnosis of subglottic stenosis post intubation which would be associated with biphasic stridor.

Biphasic stridor is seen in lesions of the glottis, subglottis, and cervical trachea. For e.g. laryngeal papillomas, vocal cord paralysis, and subglottic stenosis. Inspiratory stridor is heard in supraglottic lesions. It is often produced in obstructive lesions of the supraglottis or pharynx. For e.g. laryngomalacia or retropharyngeal abscess.

Expiratory stridor is produced in lesions of the thoracic trachea, primary and secondary bronchi. For e.g. bronchial foreign body, and tracheal stenosis.

Cotton-Myer grading is used to clinically describe the stenosis.

questions.text:
A 67-year-old patient with chronic kidney disease is being brought to the emergency department with the ECG findings shown below. The steps of management of this condition are given below -
  1. Immediate antagonism of the cardiac effects 
  2. Rapid reduction in plasma ion concentration by redistribution into cells
  3. Removal of excess ion

Choose the incorrect statement from among those given below.

choices.text: Cation exchange resins can be used for Step 3 and have an instantaneous effect
10 mL of 10% calcium gluconate solution can be used for Step 1
Inhaled β2-agonists can be used for Step 2 along with insulin
Hemodialysis is the most effective and reliable method to correct the plasma electrolyte abnormality

questions.solution:
The given clinical vignette describes a patient with hyperkalemia, which is commonly seen in a patient with chronic kidney disease. The ECG obtained from this patient shows peaked 'T' waves which indicates a significant increase in potassium concentration from baseline and require immediate treatment. Cation exchange resins can be used in this patient to remove excess potassium but the effects are not instantaneous. 

The causes of hyperkalemia are given below -

  • Intra- to extracellular shift

    A. Acidosis

    B. Hyperosmolality; radiocontrast, hypertonic dextrose, mannitol

    C. β2-Adrenergic antagonists (non-cardioselective agents)

    D. Digoxin and related glycosides (yellow oleander, foxglove,

    bufadienolide)

    E. Hyperkalemic periodic paralysis

    F. Rapid tumour lysis

  • Inadequate excretion

    A. Inhibition of the renin-angiotensin-aldosterone axis; which increases the risk of hyperkalemia when used in combination 

    1. Angiotensin-converting enzyme (ACE) inhibitors

    2. Renin-inhibitors

    3. Angiotensin receptor blockers (ARBs)

    4. Blockade of the mineralocorticoid receptor: spironolactone, eplerenone, drospirenone

    5. Blockade of the epithelial sodium channel (ENaC): amiloride, triamterene, trimethoprim, pentamidine, nafamostat

  • Advanced renal insufficiency

  • Primary adrenal insufficiency

  • Renal resistance to mineralocorticoid

    1. Tubulointerstitial diseases: SLE, amyloidosis, sickle cell anaemia, obstructive uropathy, post-acute tubular necrosis

    2. Hereditary: pseudohypoaldosteronism type I; defects in the mineralocorticoid receptor or the epithelial sodium channel (ENaC)

The steps of management are as follows - 

  • Immediate antagonism of the cardiac effects of hyperkalemia: Calcium raises the action potential threshold and reduces excitability, without changing the resting membrane potential, thereby reversing the depolarizing blockade due to potassium. 10 mL of 10% calcium gluconate should be infused intravenously over 2-3 mins with cardiac monitoring. Effects start in 1-3 mins.
  • Rapid reduction of plasma K+ concentration by redistribution into cells: 
    • Insulin shifts K+ into the cells; 10 units of intravenous regular insulin followed by 50 mL of 50% dextrose. Effects start in 10-20 mins.
    • β2-agonists with insulin have additive effects on potassium concentration. 10-20 mg of nebulized albuterol in 4 mL of normal saline, inhaled over 10 mins. Effects start at 30 mins
  • Removal of potassium
    • Cation exchange resins such as sodium polysterone sulfonate (SPS) exchange Na+ for K+ in the GI tract and increase fecal excretion of K+. 15-30 g of powder in a suspension with 33% sorbitol
    • Hemodialysis is the most reliable and effective method

questions.text: A 14-year-old boy had rheumatic fever with carditis. He now has persistent mitral regurgitation. What is the age till which he should receive penicillin prophylaxis?
questions.solution:
A 14-year-old boy with a history of rheumatic fever with carditis and persistent mitral regurgitation requires penicillin prophylaxis till the age of 40 years.

The key to controlling acute rheumatic fever (ARF) and rheumatic heart disease (RHD) is secondary prevention with antibiotics. This prevents infections with group A Streptococci and further worsening of the heart disease. The antibiotics used for this purpose are:

  • Benzathine penicillin G, 1.2 million units given once every 4 weeks
  • Erythromycin or azithromycin (in patients allergic to penicillin)

Related Pearl: American Heart Association (AHA) recommendation for duration of secondary prophylaxis of rheumatic fever

Rheumatic fever without carditis

  

5 years or until 21 years of age (whichever is longer)

Rheumatic fever with carditis but no residual heart disease (no valvular disease)

Rheumatic fever with carditis and residual heart disease (persistent valvular disease)

10 years or until 40 years of age (whichever is longer), sometimes lifelong prophylaxis

Revised Jones criteria for the diagnosis of rheumatic fever are as follows:

Arthritis- Polyarthritis only Arthritis- Polyarthritis/polyarthralgia/monoarthritis
Chorea Chorea
Erythema marginatum Erythema marginatum

Polyarthralgia Monoarthralgia

*Low-risk populations are those with ARF incidence ≤2 per 100 000 school-aged children or all-age rheumatic heart disease prevalence of ≤1 per 1000 population per year. If the incidence exceeds the given limit, then it is moderate-high risk populations.

questions.text: A 36-year-old woman comes to the clinic with a history of crampy abdominal pain for the last 6 months. The pain is exacerbated by stress and meals and relieved by defaecation. For the last 4 months she had  episodes of decreased frequency of stools. The stool is pellet-shaped, of small-volume and hard and she frequently also has abdominal bloating and flatulence. She experienced these episodes for at least  1 or 2 days every week for last 4 months. She has had no improvement with lifestyle modification and dietary supplements and her physician starts her on medication for this condition. Which of the following is a possible mechanism of action of this drug?

choices.text: Centrally acting, mu opioid receptor agonist

questions.solution:
The given clinical complex is suggestive of constipation-predominant irritable bowel syndrome. The patient has probably been started on lubiprostone, which is a chloride channel activator.

The ROME IV Diagnostic criteria for IBS  must be fulfilled for the last 3 months with symptom onset at least 6 months before diagnosis.

The onset of symptoms during a period of stress or emotional upset is a feature that supports a diagnosis of irritable bowel syndrome (IBS).

Features in favour of IBS

  • Abdominal pain that improves/worsens with defecation
  • Association with stress or emotional symptoms
  • Small volume of stools

Alteration in bowel habits (constipation/diarrhea) is the most consistent clinical feature in IBS. This means that a majority of people suffering from IBS have an alteration in bowel habits. The most common pattern is constipation alternating with diarrhea, usually with one of these symptoms predominating.

IBS is a clinical diagnosis that can be made without performing many tests if the patient presents with typical symptoms. However, it is recommended to perform the following tests in most patients to rule out other conditions:

  • Complete blood count
  • Sigmoidoscopic examination
  • Stool examination for ova and parasites
  • 3-week lactose-free diet

In patients >40 years, air-contrast barium enema or colonoscopy should also be performed.

Lubiprostone is used in the treatment of constipation-predominant IBS and can be prescribed to this patient.

Other options:

Centrally acting, mu-opioid receptor agonist (Option B) is loperamide, which is used for treatment of diarrhea, not constipation

Encephalinase inhibitor (Option C) is rececadotril, which is used for the treatment of secretory diarrhea

5-HT3 antagonist (Option D) such as alosetron is used in treatment of diarrhoea predominant IBS.

Related Pearl: Drugs used in irritable bowel syndrome (IBS)

For abdominal pain

  • Antispasmodics - Dicyclomine
  • Tricyclic antidepressants - Amitriptyline, Imipramine
  • Selective serotonin reuptake inhibitor - Citalopram

For diarrhoea

  • Opiate - Loperamide
  • 5-HT3 antagonist - Alosetron
  • Bile acid sequestrant - Cholestyramine resin

For constipation

  • Laxatives such as psyllium/ispaghula husk and polyethylene glycol
  • Cl- channel activator - Lubiprostone
  • Guanylate cyclase agonist - Linaclotide
  • 5-HT4 agonist - Tegaserod
  • Selective serotonin reuptake inhibitor - Paroxetine

Related Pearl: ROME IV Diagnostic criteria for IBS

According to the Rome IV criteria, IBS is defined as recurrent abdominal pain for at least 1 day per week in the last 3 months. It must be associated with 2 or more of the following criteria:

  • Related to defecation (improvement or worsening)
  • Associated with a change in stool frequency
  • Associated with a change in stool form (appearance)

The above criteria must be fulfilled for 3 months with onset of some symptoms at least 6 months before diagnosis.

questions.text: Which of the following statements is correct regarding the stage of demographic cycle marked by the red arrow?
questions.solution:
The marked stage is the late expanding phase (stage 3) of the demographic cycle. A demographic gift or demographic dividend is seen in this stage. 

This refers to the presence of a higher number of economically productive individuals (young and middle-aged adults) in the population due to a higher birth rate in the previous demographic phase (phase 2). India is currently experiencing the demographic gift.

The birth rate starts declining alongside a death rate that continues to fall in stage 3 causing a decline in the demographic gap. The death rate declines further and the birth rate falls in this stage.

Related Pearl: Demographic Process and Cycle

Stages of the demographic cycle include:

  • Stage 1 - High stationary 
    • High birth rates and high death rates render the population stationary
    • Narrow demographic gap
  • Stage 2 - Early expanding 
    • The death rate declines and the birth rate remains unchanged
    • The demographic gap starts increasing and becomes maximum
  • Stage 3 - Late expanding
    • Death rate declines further and birth rate falls
    • India is in this stage, currently
    • The demographic gap starts declining
  • Stage 4 - Low stationary 
    • Low birth rate and low death rate renders the population stationary
    • Narrow demographic gap
  • Stage 5 - Declining 
    • The population begins to decline as the birth rate is lower than the death rate
    • The demographic gap is negative

Related Pearl: Demographic Aspects of India

UN Data (2021)

  • India’s population was 1,393,409,000 (1.39 Billion) 
  • In 2021, India ranked 2nd in the list of countries with the highest population
  • Almost 34.5% of India’s population is urban
  • The population growth rate was 1%

SRS Statistical Report (2020)

Vital statistics according to the Sample Registration System data released by the Registrar General of India:

  • Infant mortality rate (IMR) in India - 28 per 1000 live births
  • The crude birth rate (CBR) - 19.5
  • The crude death rate (CDR) was 6.0

questions.text: A 55-year-old woman comes to the clinic with complaints of episodic flushing. She also complains of diarrhea, which is watery, non-bloody, explosive, and accompanied by abdominal cramping. Further evaluation reveals a tumor in the ileum with the histopathology shown below.  Which of the following is not true about this condition?

choices.text: 5- HIAA is used for lab diagnosis
Pellagra can develop due to tryptophan deficiency

questions.solution:
The given clinical vignette with symptoms of abdominal cramping, explosive diarrhea, and episodic flushing, along with the characteristic histopathological findings (stippled chromatin pattern, without mitotic activity or necrosis) points to the diagnosis of carcinoid syndrome. The statement- 'anti-tissue transglutaminase antibodies are present' is untrue about this condition.

Carcinoid syndrome is the result of a carcinoid tumor that secretes excessive amounts of serotonin, which is a product of the amino acid tryptophan. Serotonin is ultimately metabolized and excreted in urine as 5-HIAA (5-hydroxy indole acetic acid). 

The following tests can be used in the diagnosis of carcinoid tumors:

  • Urinary excretion of 5-HIAA and serotonin
  • Serum chromogranin concentration
  • Blood serotonin concentration
  • Plasma 5-HIAA concentration
  • Tumor localization with CT, MRI, somatostatin receptor imaging, and endoscopic biopsy

In carcinoid syndrome, elevated levels of serotonin stimulate fibroblast growth and fibrogenesis, which leads to the development of cardiac valvular lesions. These lesions most often affect the right side of the heart because the inactivation of humoral substances by the lung protects the left heart. In a few cases, the left side of the heart may be affected (in patients with right-to-left shunt, as in patent foramen ovale).

Alterations in tryptophan metabolism are seen in all patients with over 70% of dietary tryptophan converted to serotonin. Some tumors also produce histamine, kallikrein, prostaglandins, and tachykinins.

These features of serotonin result in the following symptoms that are found often in carcinoid syndrome-

  • Episodic flushing
  • Diarrhea - explosive, non-bloody, and accompanied by abdominal cramping
  • Bronchospasm
  • Cardiac valvular lesions - commonly involve the right side because the left heart is protected by the humoral inactivation of substances by the lungs
  • Pellagra- because of shunting of most of the dietary tryptophan to serotonin synthesis. (4 D's: diarrhea, dermatitis, dementia, death)
  • Muscle wasting due to poor protein synthesis
  • Mesenteric and retroperitoneal fibrosis

Treatment:

  • Somatostatin analog therapy
  • Antidiarrheal therapy
  • Surgical excision

Incorrect option: 

Anti-tissue transglutaminase antibodies are used to diagnose celiac disease. Celiac disease is a malabsorptive disorder that can present in early childhood with diarrhea. This usually occurs after introducing cereals into the child's diet. The symptoms usually disappear over a few years and may or may not re-appear in adulthood. The diagnosis is made by testing for autoantibodies (such as anti-tissue transglutaminase, anti-endomysial, and anti-gliadin) and by performing a small intestine biopsy, which can show flattening of the villi. 

Related Pearl: Carcinoid syndrome

questions.text: A 14-month-old child was brought to the emergency in cardiac arrest. Which of the following technique of chest compressions is the best to be followed in this scenario?

choices.text: Thumb of 1 hand, with other fingers encircled on left side of chest.
Heel of 1 hand over lower half of sternum
2 thumbs on sternum, with hands encircling the chest
2 fingers i.e. index and middle finger on lower 1/3rd of sternum

questions.solution:
In children of age >1 year, the heel of the palm on lower 1/3rd of the sternum is applied during chest compressions.

Ideally, there should be 30 chest compressions and 2 breaths in a minute. i.e 100-120 compressions per minute (use 15:2 ratio if second rescuer arrives)

In infants:

2 thumb technique with hands encircling the chest over the sternum is the method to be followed in infants. The 2 finger technique and 2 thumb technique are considered equally effective.

The thumbs or the tips of fingers should remain in contact with the chest during compression and release. In infants, the brachial pulse should be assessed. (For children aged one to adolescence, the pulse should be checked at the carotid artery).

questions.text: A first-year medical student is performing the following test in the biochemistry lab. The presence of which of the following will cause the test result given below?
questions.solution:
The given biochemical test is Pauly's test. It is used for detecting the presence of histidine in proteins. Imidazole ring in histidine will give a positive reaction. When proteins containing histidine react with diazotized sulfanilic acid under alkaline conditions, red color is formed by a coupling reaction.

The reagent used is diazotized sulphanilic acid which is obtained by adding sulphanilic acid, sodium nitrite, and sodium carbonate. The same reagent will give an orange-colored product with the phenol group of tyrosine.

questions.text: A 4-year-old boy was brought with complaints of nasal obstruction. After a detailed examination, he was diagnosed to have adenoid hypertrophy and was planned for adenoidectomy. Which of the following options is not an indication for the surgical management of this patient?
questions.solution:
All the options mentioned above are indications of adenoidectomy, except the submucous cleft palate. It is instead, a contraindication for adenoidectomy.

Indications of adenoidectomy:

  • Adenoid hypertrophy causing snoring, mouth breathing, sleep apnea syndrome, or speech abnormalities, i.e. (rhinolalia clausa - hyponasal voice)
  • Recurrent rhinosinusitis
  • Chronic otitis media with effusion associated with adenoid hyperplasia
  • Chronic suppurative otitis media with recurrent ear discharge associated with adenoiditis/ adenoid hyperplasia
  • Dental malocclusion.

Contraindications of adenoidectomy include: 

  1. Cleft palate or submucous palate
  2. Hemorrhagic diathesis
  3. Acute infection of the upper respiratory tract

questions.text: A surfer presents to the OPD with complaints of multiple wounds on his legs which have progressively increased in size over one month. He spends most of his time in the sea teaching surfing to tourists. Multiple swabs were taken from the wound after examination and sent for routine staining and culture. Lactose-fermenting colonies are produced by the organism isolated, which grows well in 6% NaCl. It does not form yellow colonies on TCBS agar and the Voges–Proskauer test is negative. The most likely organism implicated in this case is__________
questions.solution:
The most likely organism implicated in this case is Vibrio vulnificus. The infections are caused due to the contact of open wounds with seawater. They ferment lactose but not sucrose. It has a salt tolerance of less than 8%. The Voges–Proskauer test is negative.

This organism causes two types of illness. The first is wound infection following contact of open wounds with seawater. The second type occurs in immunocompromised hosts, particularly those with liver disease. Following ingestion of the vibrio, usually in oysters, it penetrates the gut mucosa without causing gastrointestinal manifestations and enters the bloodstream. It causes septicemia and has a high mortality.

The Voges–Proskauer test detects acetylmethylcarbinol (acetoin), an intermediate product in the butene glycol pathway of glucose fermentation. This test differentiates among the enteric rods. 

Note: V. cholerae, V. parahaemolyticus, and V. alginolyticus do not ferment lactose although lactose may be split very slowly by V. cholerae.

Thiosulfate citrate bile salts sucrose agar (TCBS) is a selective and differential medium used for the culture of Vibrio species. Vibrio cholerae produce yellow colored colonies.

The following image shows Vibrio cholerae producing yellow-colored colonies on TCBS:

Vibrio parahaemolyticus: They produce green-colored colonies on the TCBS agar as they do not ferment sucrose.

Related Pearl: Culture media used for Vibrio cholerae

The following are various culture media used for Vibrio cholerae: 

Transport Media

  • Venkatraman-Ramakrishnan (VR) medium
  • Cary-Blair medium
  • Autoclaved sea water

Enrichment Media

  • Alkaline peptone water (APW)
  • Monsur’s taurocholate tellurite peptone water

Selective Media

  • Alkaline bile salt agar (BSA)
  • Monsur’s gelatin taurocholate trypticase tellurite agar (GTTA)
  • Thiosulphate citrate bile sucrose (TCBS) agar -
    • Yellow colonies- Vibrio cholerae
    • Green colonies- Vibrio parahemolyticus

questions.text: A 9-year-old boy present’s to the Emergency with complaints of pain on the right side of his scrotum for the past half an hour. History reveals trauma with a cricket ball. On examination, it is found that the right-sided testes is positioned high and the left testes is found to lie horizontally. The sign shown by the right and left testes are respectively:-
questions.solution:
Deming’s sign: Spasm of the cremaster muscle and the twisting of the cord cause the affected testis to be positioned higher


Angell’s sign: The testis on the opposite side lies horizontally because of the bilaterality of the mesorchium between the testis and epididymis.


Prehn’s Sign is used to differentiate the torsion of testes from acute epididymo orchitis. In the case of acute epididymo orchitis, the pain gets relieved on the elevation of the testis but not in torsion of testes

questions.text: A 46-year-old farmer from rural India comes to the clinic for evaluation of cough and chest pain for one week. He also complains of fatigue that started about a month ago. Workup reveals the findings below. Which of the following signs will not be seen on x-ray/CT scans in this condition?
questions.solution:
The given clinical presentation resembles hydatid lung. The patient who is a farmer (who probably handles sheep) presents with cough, chest pain and fatigue. The CT scan shows a 'water lily sign', which is characteristic of complicated hydatid cysts. "Ball of wool" sign is an ultrasound finding.

"Ball of wool" sign, also called the yarn sign, is an ultrasound finding which represents degeneration of hydatid cysts. The inner side of the cyst detaches from the cyst wall and folds on itself, causing a change from anechoic (fluid) to a solid, hyperechoic appearance without internal septations or daughter cysts 

The radiographic appearance resembles the air crescent of a mycetoma. If there is a disruption of the inner layers, a cavitary lesion results with one or more of the following radiographic features:

  • an air-fluid level
  • a floating membrane (water lily sign, Camelotte sign)
  • a double wall
  • an essentially dry cyst with crumpled membranes lying at its bottom (rising sun sign, serpent sign)
  • a cyst with all its contents expectorated (empty cyst sign).

Classical radiological signs seen in hydatid cysts:

Uncomplicated Hydatid Cyst Complicated Hydatid Cyst
Well-circumscribed round radio-opacity (resembling a canon ball on AP and a rugby ball on lateral projection) Crescent sign
Polycyclic and bilobed appearance Cumbo or double arch sign
Slot sign (impending rupture) Water lily sign
  Camelotte sign
  Rising sun sign
  Dry cyst sign

 

Hydatid cysts result from infection by the Echinococcus, and can result in cyst formation anywhere in the body. There are two main strains which are causing Hydatid cyst:

  • Echinococcus granulosus: commoner
  • Echinococcus alveolaris/multilocularis: less common but more invasive

Definitive hosts are carnivores (e.g. dogs, foxes, cats), and the intermediate hosts are most commonly sheep. Humans are accidental host, and the infection occurs by ingesting food contaminated with Echinococcus eggs. Most common location of Hydatid cyst is liver followed by the lung.

questions.text: Which of the following is incorrect regarding the management of Bowen disease?

choices.text: High factor broad spectrum sunscreen is recommended
5-flurouracil is the first line of treatment
Disease involving the nail requires wide excision
Curettage, cautery and cryotherapy are widely used

questions.solution:
Bowen disease involving nail has a high risk of invasion/recurrence and requires digit amputation or Mohs micrographic surgery(not wide excision).

Bowen disease is an intraepidermal squamous cell carcinoma is characterized by a persistent, non‐elevated, red, scaly, or crusted plaque with a small potential for invasive malignancy. It usually grows progressively but sometimes undergoes spontaneous partial resolution. Human papilloma virus infection is associated with it. It can occur anywhere, but it occurs more in the head and neck region. Histologically, it is characterized by full-thickness epidermal dysplasia and disordered differentiation with loss of epithelial polarity.

Diagnosis is generally clinical and is aided by a lack of improvement even after corticosteroids are tried when a benign condition is suspected. Biopsy may be done for uncertain cases. 

Treatment- High-factor sunscreen is recommended for all patients. The first line of treatment includes cryotherapy, curettage, 5- fluorouracil cream, imiquimod, or photodynamic therapy. Perianal disease and nail unit disease are aggressive. Hence for perianal disease, wide excision is recommended and for nail unit disease, digit amputation or Mohs micrographic surgery are recommended. 

Image: Red scaly plaque seen on the finger, in an 81-year-old woman with Bowen’s disease.

questions.text: A 35-year-old man was rushed to the ER following a road traffic accident. You suspect a femoral shaft fracture and decide to use the following splint. How is the length of this splint calculated?

choices.text: Highest point on the  medial side of the groin up to the heel plus 4 inches.
Highest point on the  medial side of the groin up to the heel plus 6 inches.
Anterior superior iliac spine up to the heel plus 6 inches.
Anterior superior iliac spine up to the heel plus 4 inches.

questions.solution:
The image shows the picture of a Thomas splint and its length is calculated by measuring the distance between the highest point on the medial side of the groin to the heel and adding 6 inches.

The ring size is calculated by adding 2 inches to the thigh circumference at the highest point of the groin.

The Thomas splint is used for immobilization following hip and thigh injuries.

Parts of the splint include:

  • Outer bar
  • Inner bar
  • Ring

The outer bar has a curvature near its junction with the ring to accommodate the greater trochanter.

questions.text:
A 35-year-old primigravida comes to the clinic with the results of her second-trimester prenatal screening tests. She is at 16-weeks gestation and has not taken any prenatal vitamins. She has a history of epilepsy on medications. She has no new complaints today. Her vital signs are within normal limits. Examination shows the symphysiofundal height to be 17cm and fetal heart sounds are heard. The results of her laboratory tests are given below.
Test Value Median Value and 95% CI
MSAFP 93 30.9 (30.07 - 31.73)
Unconjugated estriol 4.9 4.95 (4.85 - 5.04)
