What is the next step in management of her condition?

choices.text: Repeat measurement of MSAFP at a later date

questions.solution:
The clinical vignette describes a case of neural tube defects that could be attributed to the patient's lack of prenatal care. All pregnant women should be started on prophylactic folic acid in order to prevent the development of neural tube defects. This patient is particularly at higher risk, because of the use of her history of epilepsy. Patients who are taking enzyme-inducing anticonvulsants, such as phenytoin, carbamazepine, primidone, and phenobarbital, which are known to decrease folate levels, and valproic acid which may interfere with folate metabolism need to take higher doses of folic acid. 

MSAFP is a screening test. If it is raised, it should be followed by a diagnostic test and the most preferred test is targeted sonography.

Alpha-fetoprotein (AFP)

  • It is the major serum protein in the embryo and fetus.
  • Its concentration increases steadily in both fetal serum and amnionic fluid until 13 weeks gestation, after which, levels rapidly decline. Conversely, AFP is found in steadily increasing quantities in maternal serum after 12 weeks.
  • Defects in the fetal integument, such as neural tube and ventral wall defects, permit AFP to leak into the amnionic fluid, resulting in dramatically increased maternal serum AFP levels.
  • Maternal serum AFP screening is generally performed from 15 through 20 weeks.

Note: Amniocentesis is a diagnostic test for amniotic fluid AFP measurement. It was once considered the standard for the diagnosis of open neural tube disorders, and now it has been replaced in most centers by targeted sonography.

questions.text: Identify the instrument_____
questions.solution:
The device shown in the image is a Slit Lamp.

  • It can be used to visualise the anterior and posterior chambers of the eye. It cannot be used to visualise the retina directly, because of the refractive power of ocular media.
  • Most slit-lamp microscopes offer magnifications between ×5 and ×50, with ×10, ×16, and ×25 being the most popular. Image resolution is ultimately limited by diffraction.
  • Because the cornea has such high refractive power, the slit-lamp microscope can view only the first one-third of the eye. 

Slit lamps are not useful beyond the anterior part of the vitreous as the focal point is generally in this region. Using a contact lens with a flat anterior face or a high power convex or concave lens however can diverge the beam by eliminating the refractive influence of the corneal curvature and thereby overcome this shortcoming. Special lenses, in conjunction with the slit-lamp microscope, can be used to view the posterior vitreous and the posterior pole of the retina.

The lenses used are as follows:

  • Contact type: Goldmann three-mirror contact lens, modified Koeppe lens.
  • Non-contact type: Convex lens +60D, +78D, +90D (best lens). Hruby lens is a planoconcave lens with dioptric power of -55D.

Other options - 

Image: Humphrey's Visual field analyzer

Image: Keratometer

Image: Ophthalmoscope

questions.text: During the examination of a victim of assault, you notice a wound with ragged, irregular, and uneven margins with tears diverging at an angle from the end of the main wound. The wound shows typical ‘swallow tails’. Bleeding from this wound is not significant and a closer examination shows crushed blood vessels and hair bulbs. You would document this wound as:
questions.solution:
The characteristics described are consistent with that of a lacerated wound.

In a lacerated wound, the margins are ragged, irregular, and uneven. Tearing at the ends of a laceration, at angles diverging from the main one itself are called swallow tails.

The edges of the laceration may indicate the direction in which the blow or force was applied. The depth of the wound shows bridges of irregularly torn fibrous tissue, blood vessels, and nerves and can be soiled by mud, sand, glass, brick particles, vegetation, machine oils, hair, or fibres. These materials embedded in the wound are of great medicolegal value.

Lacerated wounds do not bleed much as the vessels are crushed and torn, thus facilitating hemostasis. The exception to this is injuries to the scalp, where temporal arteries may bleed freely as they are firmly bound and unable to contract. Lacerations over the hairy areas will show hair bulbs crushed and buried into the depth of the wound. Because of the crushing and tearing nature of the production of lacerations, there can be associated abrasion or bruising.

Swallow tail in a lacerated wound is shown in the image below:

Other options:

Option A- An incised wound is a clean-cut wound made with a sharp-edged instrument through the skin and subcutaneous tissues, including blood vessels. The length of the wound is more than the depth and width. The edges are well-defined and usually everted, free from contusions and abrasions. It is usually spindle-shaped. The depth is higher at the commencement and progressively becomes shallower, known as tailing. Tailing determines the direction of the force applied when creating the wound.

Option B- Chop wounds or slash wounds are the wounds produced by chopping motion, made with heavy and sharp weapons like axe, cleave, etc. The dimensions of the wound correspond to the crosssection of the penetrating part of the weapon. The margins are sharp and show slight abrasion and bruising with the destruction of underlying organs. The presence of an incised wound on the skin with an underlying fracture or deep grove in the bone indicates a chop wound.

The image below shows a chop wound.

Option C- A stab wound is a type of mechanical injury that is produced when force is applied along the long axis of a narrow, pointed object like a knife, sword, chisel, needle, screwdriver, etc, into the depth of the body. 

The margins of the wound are clean-cut and inverted. The length of the wound is slightly less than the width of the weapon. The width of the wound corresponds to the maximum possible width of the blade. The depth of the wound is greater than the length and width of the external injury on the skin surface. The shape of the surface wound depends on the type of weapon, cutting surface, the direction of thrust, cleavage lines, etc. The shape of the wound is usually triangular or wedge-shaped. Depending on the type of instrument used, one side of the wound may be sharp, while another side may be blunt. The blunt side may show small splits at each corner, called fishtailing. 

Below is the image showing the fish-tail appearance of stab wounds.

questions.text: A 33-year-old comes to the clinic with a history of bladder problems. She complains of hesitancy, an interrupted stream of urine, and incomplete voiding. In the last year, she has visited the clinic once for gait disturbances and was admitted once for vision loss in the right eye. She received appropriate treatment for her condition. MRI of the brain is shown below. She also demonstrates characteristic lesions in the spinal cord above the sacral parasynthetic centers. Which of the following appearances is likely to be seen on cystography?

choices.text: Pear shaped appearance of the bladder

questions.solution:
The given clinical vignette describes a case of multiple sclerosis, based on clinical history and the imaging which characteristically shows plaques in the periventricular and juxtacortical regions. Neurogenic bladder is a common finding. Christmas tree bladder or pine cone bladder is a cystogram appearance which usually seen in severe neurogenic bladder with increased sphincter tone.

Pinecone bladder:

  • A pinecone bladder or Christmas tree bladder is a cystogram appearance in which the bladder is elongated and pointed with a thickened trabeculated wall.
  • It is typically seen in severe neurogenic bladder with increased sphincter tone (detrusor sphincter dyssynergia) due to suprasacral lesions (above S2-S4) or epiconal lesions (in and around S2-S4).
  • Neurogenic bladder is a term applied to a dysfunctional urinary bladder that results from an injury to the central or peripheral nerves that control and regulate urination.

This finding is not pathognomonic of a neurogenic bladder. It can also be seen in patients with lesions anywhere along the sacral reflex arc. Occasionally, it is also seen in bladder neck obstruction of a non-neurogenic cause.

The image below shows a characteristic Christmas tree appearance in neurogenic bladder.

Other options:

Tear drop bladder (pear shaped bladder) (Option C) is characteristically seen in pelvic lipomatosis, bilateral pelvic hematoma, pelvic abscess, bilateral pelvic lymphadenopathy, intraperitoneal bladder rupture.

Pear-shaped (or teardrop-shaped) bladder is one whose normal round or ovoid shape has been extrinsically compressed to resemble a pear. The pear may be inverted or upright, depending on how the excess pelvic tissue compresses the bladder.

 Other important radiological appearance in urogenital system:

  • Sun-burst appearance of the bladder: Extraperitoneal bladder rupture. (Option D)
  • Thimble bladder: Tubercular cystitis (Option A)
  • Paint-brush appearance: Medullary sponge kidney
  • Drooping flower appearance: Ectopic ureter
  • Rim sign/crescent sign: Hydronephrosis
  • Bilateral spider leg deformity: Polycystic kidney disease.
  • Flower vase curves of the ureter: Horseshoe kidney.
  • Saw-toothed or cock screw appearance of ureter: Tubercular ureteritis

questions.text:
Which of the following statements are correct regarding this class of antibody?
  1. It is most effective in agglutination reactions.
  2. It has a half-life of 5 days.
  3. It is the only heat labile antibody.
  4. Increased levels are seen in a defect of the CD40 ligand.
  5. Involved in vertical transmission from mother to fetus in Rubella.
questions.solution:
The given image shows a pentameric immunoglobulin, hence it is an IgM antibody.

IgM antibody is the first antibody released in response to any antigen. It is released in the form of a pentamer and has 10 antigen-binding sites. The half-life of IgM is 5- 7 days. It is a heat-stable antibody. It is the most efficient immunoglobulin in agglutination, complement fixation, and defense against bacteria and viruses. However, it is less effective in the neutralization of toxins and viruses compared to IgG. It does not cross the placenta.

Reaction

IgG

IgM

Neutralization

Strong

Weak

Agglutination

Weak

Strong

Complement fixation

Moderate

Strong

IgE is the only heat-labile antibody.

Clinical correlate:

  • Because of their short half-lives, the presence of IgM antibodies indicates a recent infection.
  • It cannot cross the placenta. Therefore, the presence of this antibody indicates intrauterine infection.
  • Hyper IgM syndrome is a syndrome where there are high levels of IgM with very low levels of IgG and IgA. It occurs due to a deficiency of the CD40 ligand. CD40L is expressed on T cells and is required to induce B cells to undergo class-switching from IgM to IgG and IgA. 
 

Related Pearl: Properties of immunoglobulin classes

IgG:

  • Half-life- 23 days
  • Appears late, indicates chronic infection
  • It is the only maternal Ig to cross the placenta.
  • Has 4 subclasses.
  • Causes complement fixation, precipitation, and neutralization of toxins and virus.

IgM:

  • Half-life- 5 days
  • Has the highest molecular weight and is a pentamer.
  • Polysaccharides and lipids mainly stimulate IgM secretion.
  • Intravascular distribution.
  • Appears early, indicates recent infection.
  • Acts as surface immunoglobulin on the B cells.
  • It causes agglutination, hemolysis, complement fixation and opsonization.

IgD:

  • Half-life- 2-8 days.
  • Acts as a surface immunoglobulin on the B cells.
  • Serves as recognition receptors for antigens.

IgE:

  • Half-life- 1-5 days
  • Causes type I hypersensitivity.
  • It is the only heat labile antibody.
  • Levels are raised in helminthic infections.

IgA:

  • Half-life- 6 days
  • It is of 2 types- Serum IgA and Secretory IgA 
  • Secretory IgA (A dimer) results in mucosal immunity.

Related Pearl: Primary immunodeficiency disorders

Cellular immunity: Problems with T cells

Deficiency of complement proteins

questions.text: A 3-year-old boy is brought by his mother with complaints of poor growth, weakness, abnormal gait, and bowing of the legs. The head appears as seen in the image below. Laboratory investigations revealed low serum levels of vitamin D. All of the following findings can be seen in this patient except
questions.solution:
From the given scenario, the clinical features of the patient and low serum vitamin D levels point to a diagnosis of vitamin D deficiency rickets in the patient. The image shows frontal bossing seen in rickets. This condition is associated with an increase in parathyroid hormone (PTH) levels. 

Nutritional rickets commonly occur due to the deficiency of vitamin D, thereby affecting the metabolism of calcium and phosphate ions in the body. Vitamin D is mainly synthesized by the following mechanism -

This active vitamin D stimulates and increases the absorption of Ca2+  ions from the intestine. It does so by increasing the formation of calbindin which is a calcium-binding protein, that transports calcium into the cells. 

Thus, in vitamin D deficiency, low calcium levels may be seen in the blood. To raise this serum calcium, the secretion of the parathyroid hormone rises and causes - 

  • Reabsorption of calcium in the kidneys and decreases renal calcium excretion
  • Secretion of phosphate ions in exchange, leading to an increase in renal phosphate excretion 
  • Increase in bone turnover 
  • Increases the level of the enzyme 1-α hydroxylase which leads to more production of the active form of Vitamin D - 1,25 dihydro cholecalciferol.

Radiological features of rickets:

  • Loss of provisional zone of calcification: earliest radiological finding of rickets. 
  • Delayed appearance of the epiphysis
  • Widening of growth plate: normal width of growth plate is 2-4mm. It is increased in cases of rickets due to excessive accumulation of uncalcified osteoid at the growth plate.
  • Cupping of metaphysis: normally metaphysis meets epiphysis as a smooth line of sclerosis. But in rickets the line is absent and the metaphyseal ends appear irregular and the cartilage accumulating in the growth plate creates a depression in the metaphysis causing cupping.
  • Fraying: indistinct margins of the metaphysis

  • In healing rickets, zone of calcification becomes denser.

  • Wrist: especially the ulna

questions.text:
A 65-year-old male patient with weight loss and dyspepsia is scheduled for endoscopy of the upper GI tract. He is prepared for the procedure, administered local anaesthesia and it is started. Shortly after beginning the procedure, he complains of headaches and lightheadedness. On examination, his lips are pale.
Vitals  
Pulse rate 110/min
Blood pressure 150/90 mm Hg
Respiratory rate 20/min
SpO2 83% on RA

Oxygen is administered but there is no improvement in saturation. Which of the following is the appropriate treatment for this condition?
questions.solution:
The clinical vignette describes a case of methemoglobinemia. The patient should be treated with methylene blue.

 

Methemoglobinemia is a side effect of Prilocaine. 

Prilocaine is metabolized to o-toluidine, which converts hemoglobin (Fe 2+) to methemoglobin (Fe 3+) producing methemoglobinemia.

Treatment of methemoglobinemia includes reduction of methemoglobin to hemoglobin by intravenous methylene blue (1–2 mg/kg of a 1% solution over 5 min).

Note: Benzocaine used in topical local anesthetic sprays can also cause dangerous Methemoglobinemia.

Also know: Pulse oximetry in methemoglobinemia shows 80% to 85% irrespective of the arterial oxygen saturation.

Related Pearl: High Yield Points in Local Anaesthetics

Cocaine: 

  • Naturally occurring
  • Vasoconstrictor
  • 1st local anesthetic

Chloroprocaine: Intradural injections are contraindicated and may cause paraplegia

Prilocaine: 

  • Safest
  • Causes maximum methemoglobinemia
  • Suitable for Bier’s IV block
  • EMLA is a eutectic mixture of LA containing 2.5% lidocaine & 2.5% prilocaine

Bupivacaine

  • Long-acting
  • Most cardiotoxic
  • Contraindicated in regional IV anesthesia
  • Toxicity is treated with amiodarone, bretylium(for VT), vasopressors (for circulatory collapse), isoproterenol and benzodiazepines (sedative)

Procaine

  • LA of choice in malignant hyperthermia
  • 1st synthetic LA
  • Metabolized to PABA, which have been associated with rare anaphylactic reactions

questions.text: A 52-year-old female patient presents with a low mood for the past 7 months. She says that she feels sad for most of the day and nearly every day. It is also associated with decreased appetite, insomnia, decreased concentration, and a lack of energy.  Which of the following sleep changes can be seen in this patient?

choices.text: An increase in total sleep time

questions.solution:
Depression is associated with a premature loss of deep (slow-wave) sleep.

Sleep changes in depression:

  • A premature loss of deep (slow-wave) sleep
  • An increase in nocturnal arousal manifested as
    • An increase in nocturnal awakenings,
    • A reduction in total sleep time,
    • Increased phasic rapid eye movement (REM) sleep
    • Increased core body temperature.

The combination of increased REM drive and decreased slow-wave sleep results in a significant reduction in the first period of non-REM (NREM) sleep, a phenomenon referred to as reduced REM latency. 

Diagnostic criteria for diagnosing depression:

  1. Depressed mood most of the day
  2. Anhedonia- diminished interest in day to day activities
  3. Significant weight loss when not dieting, or weight gain. Change in appetite.
  4. Insomnia or hypersomnia
  5. Psychomotor agitation or retardation
  6. Fatigue or loss of energy
  7. Feelings of worthlessness or excessive, inappropriate guilt
  8. Diminished ability to think or concentrate, indecisiveness
  9. Recurrent thoughts of death, suicidal ideation, a suicide attempt, or a specific plan for committing suicide.

At least five symptoms must be present over a two-week period and at least one symptom must be either depressed mood or anhedonia.

Related Pearl: Signs and symptoms of depression

Mnemonic "SIGECAPS"

Sleep disorder (increased or decreased)

Interest deficit (anhedonia): loss of interest in previously pleasurable activities

Guilt (worthlessness, hopelessness, regret)

Energy deficit

Concentration deficit

Appetite disorder (increased or decreased)

Psychomotor retardation or agitation

Suicidal tendency

questions.text: A 22-year-old male patient presented with acute onset of tender, enlarged lymph nodes in both groins as shown below. He described the primary lesion as a small, painless papule. He also complains of anorectal pain, tenesmus, and rectal discharge. Which of the following statements is incorrect regarding this condition?

choices.text: The incubation period ranges from 10-30 days.
C. trachomatis  L2 serovar is the most common agent.

questions.solution:
The clinical history of tender, enlarged lymph nodes in both groins and the image of inguinal adenitis or bubos in a young male are suggestive of lymphogranuloma venereum which is caused by Chlamydia trachomatis. Pseudobubos are seen in donovanosis.

Chlamydia trachomatis serovars L1, L2, and L3 cause lymphogranuloma venereum (LGV), but most commonly L2.

In LGV, a primary ulcer presents after 3–30 days of exposure. It usually presents on the coronal sulcus in men and the posterior vaginal wall in women. It is usually a papule or an ulcer, which can be painless or painful and disappears soon, without leaving a scar.

The secondary stage appears after about 2–6 weeks consisting of inguinal and femoral lymph nodes, which are enlarged, painful, and tender. In men, the inguinal lymph nodes are involved most often, and the intrapelvic and pararectal nodes in women. May be associated with hemorrhagic proctitis in those engaging in anal intercourse.

In the tertiary stage of LGV, the genitalia along with the anorectal region can be involved. There is fibrosis of the lymphatic system which causes genital lymphedema. This may lead to rectal strictures and elephantiasis of the vulva (esthiomene).

The primary lesion is usually not noticed and the disease is first seen at the stage of inguinal adenitis (bubo). Smears of material aspirated from the bubos may show the elementary bodies (Miyagawa's granulocorpuscles). Serological diagnosis is helpful and complement fixation tests can be used.

Donovanosis (granuloma inguinale) is a sexually transmitted disease caused by Klebsiella granulomatis. Lymphadenopathy is usually rare in this disease. The granulomatous lesion may extend into subcutaneous tissue and mimic lymph nodes, known as ‘pseudobubo’.

  • The usual presentation is acute urethritis with complaints of burning dysuria and purulent discharge.

questions.text: A 17-year-old girl comes in for an annual examination. Her mother complains that her daughter aspires to be a model and is constantly worried about her appearance. The mother feels her child is "too skinny" and barely eats her food. On further questioning, the girl admits that she has not menstruated in 4 months. Physical examination is significant for an undernourished girl with a BMI of 17. Which of the following findings do you expect in this patient?
questions.solution:
The clinical scenario describes a case of anorexia nervosa. Hypersecretion of corticotrophin-releasing hormone is seen in a patient with anorexia nervosa.

Anorexia nervosa is a type of eating disorder that is characterized by self-induced starvation to a significant degree, drive for thinness or a morbid fear of fatness, and the presence of medical signs and symptoms resulting from starvation. 

Important complications of anorexia nervosa are:

  • Vital signs- bradycardia, hypotension with orthostatic changes, hypothermia
  • Muscle atrophy and loss of body fat
  • Central nervous system- generalized brain atrophy with larger ventricles, decreased cortical mass, seizures
  • Cardiovascular- decreased cardiac mass, reduced cardiac chamber volumes, mitral valve prolapse, myocardial fibrosis, and pericardial effusion
  • ECG changes- T wave flattening or inversion, ST segment depression, and lengthening of the QT interval
  • Renal- Reduced GFR, or problems in concentrating urine leading to diuresis, hyponatremia, and dehydration. 
  • Electrolytes- There may be depletion of potassium, magnesium, and phosphate.
  • Hematologic- anemia of starvation, leucopenia, hypocellular bone marrow
  • Metabolic- hypercholesterolemia, nonsymptomatic hypoglycemia, elevated liver enzymes, decreased bone density.
  • Endocrine-
    • Low levels of LH, FSH, estrogen, low to normal thyroxine
    • Elevated cortisol, cortisol releasing hormone, growth hormone, prolactin

DSM 5 diagnostic criteria for anorexia nervosa - 

A. Significantly low body weight for age, sex, developmental trajectory, and physical health due to restricted intake.

B. Fear of becoming fat and persistent behavior that interferes with weight gain.

C. Persistent lack of recognition of insight to the disorder and not understanding the seriousness of the low body weight.

Clinical features - anxiety, depression, negative self-image, amenorrhea, irritability, constipation, dry skin, hair loss, fainting or dizziness, lethargy, and BMI < 18.5

questions.text:
A woman brought her 14-month-old child to the PHC for routine immunization. The child was born in February 2020 at home and has not received any vaccine till now due to the lockdown. The mother is apprehensive about her child's health and wants to immunize him. Which of the following vaccines can be given to the child now?
  1. OPV
  2. Measles
  3. BCG
  4. Vitamin A
  5. Pentavalent
questions.solution:
The correct answer is 1, 2, 4.

In the case of an unimmunized 14-month-old child, OPV, measles, and vitamin A vaccines can be given.

Catch-up vaccination involves the administration of vaccines in children who have not been immunized at all (left-outs) or for children who took vaccines but could not complete the course (dropouts).

According to the National Immunization Schedule, BCG can only be given up to 1 year of age. 

OPV can be given till 5 years of age.

Measles can be given till 5 years of age.

DPT can be given until 7 years of age (with booster doses).

Only the above-mentioned vaccines have upper age limits. 

For pentavalent, IPV, PCV, and rotavirus vaccines, if at least one dose is given before one year of age, then remaining doses can be administered and the schedule must be completed irrespective of the age of the child. If the first dose is not administered before one year of age, then these vaccines cannot be administered to the child under UIP.

questions.text:
A 42-year-old female presents with flaccid bullous lesions involving the oral cavity and the skin. Acantholytic cells are noted on Tzank smear. On immunopathology, fishnet pattern of IgG on suprabasal keratinocytes is noted. Autoantibodies against Dsg3 and Dsg1 are positive. The condition occurs due to which of the following types of hypersensitivity reactions?

Dsg1: Desmoglein 1
Dsg3: Desmoglein 3
questions.solution:
The given clinical condition is pemphigus vulgaris, which is characterized by flaccid bullous lesions involving mucosal surfaces (oral cavity) and skin, acantholytic cells on Tzanck smear, fishnet pattern on immunopathology, and autoantibodies against Dsg1 and Dsg3. Pemphigus vulgaris occurs due to antibody-mediated type II hypersensitivity reaction.

Pemphigus vulgaris is a persistent immunobullous disorder marked by the presence of antibodies targeting desmosomal proteins, which are responsible for intraepidermal intercellular connections. The antibodies target desmoglein 1 and desmoglein 3, which belong to the cadherin family. The primary pathological process is acantholysis.

Acantholysis in the lower spinous cell layers is shown in the histology image below:

Clinically, patients exhibit poorly defined, slow-healing oral lesions and erosions. Fluid-filled blisters, often on an erythematous base, may appear on normal skin. The rupture of these blisters results in painful erosions that heal without scarring. 

Direct immunofluorescence is the most reliable confirmatory test for this condition. It reveals the deposition of IgG and C3 between cells on the surface of keratinocytes across the entire epidermis, presenting a distinctive fishnet/ chickenwire appearance, as depicted below:

Related Pearl: Types of Type II Antibody-Mediated Hypersentivity

There are 3 mechanisms involved in type 2 hypersensitivity reactions- 

  1. Antibody-mediated cellular dysfunction- antibodies react with antigens present on cell surfaces or in the extracellular matrix cause disease by destroying these cells, triggering inflammation, or interfering with normal functions
    1. Myasthenia gravis (against acetylcholine receptor)
    2. Graves’ disease (against TSH receptor)
    3. Pemphigus Vulgaris (against epidermal cadherin)
    4. Pernicious anemia (against intrinsic factor)
    5. Insulin resistant diabetes (against insulin receptor
  2. Antibody-mediated opsonization and phagocytosis -antibodies may deposit in tissues or blood vessels, and elicit an acute inflammatory reaction by activating complement and Recruiting Phagocytes
    1. Transfusion reactions
    2. Erythroblastosis fetalis
    3. Autoimmune hemolytic anemia
    4. Autoimmune thrombocytopenic purpura
  3. Complement and Fc receptor-mediated inflammation- antibodies may deposit in tissues or blood vessels, and elicit an acute inflammatory reaction by activating complement
    1. Goodpasture syndrome
    2. Vasculitis due to ANCA
    3. Acute rheumatic fever
    4. Vascular rejection in organ graft

questions.text: A 35-year-old female patient is brought to the emergency room from a restaurant in a confused state after having a meal of cheese and wine.  The patient has a history of atypical depression for which she takes phenelzine. She also takes tramadol for lower back pain. She has a history of diabetes mellitus which is managed with insulin. On examination, her pulse rate is 110/minute, blood pressure is 170/110 mm Hg and respiratory rate is 23/minute. Physical examination shows the findings below. Which of the following is the mechanism for this patient's presentation?
questions.solution:
The given clinical vignette describes a case of serotonin syndrome caused by the interaction between two serotonergic drugs. This patient takes phenelzine (an MAO-A inhibitor) and tramadol (acts on serotonergic and noradrenergic nociception).

Although the clinical presentation resembles the "cheese reaction" seen in patients who take MAO-A inhibitors, the key differentiating factor is the presence of clonus. Clonus is not seen in tyramine-induced hypertensive crisis. Additionally, a hypertensive crisis is defined as systolic pressure ≥180 mmHg or diastolic ≥120 mmHg.

Serotonin syndrome can occur with any drug that increases 5-HT (eg, MAOIs, SSRIs, SNRIs, TCAs, tramadol, ondansetron, triptans, linezolid, MDMA, dextromethorphan). Co-prescription of the above-mentioned causative drugs results in increasing serotonin levels, which increase norepinephrine levels which is responsible for the autonomic symptoms in serotonin syndrome.

It is characterized by 3 A’s:

  • Neuromuscular hyperactivity- clonus, hyperreflexia, hypertonia, tremor, and seizure
  • Autonomic stimulation - hyperthermia, diaphoresis, diarrhea 
  • Agitation.

Treatment: Cyproheptadine (5-HT2 receptor antagonist). 

Cheese reaction occurs in patients being treated with MAO inhibitors who consume tyramine-rich foods. These are cheese, red wine, aged meat, and fish, etc. Apples do not cause a cheese reaction. Inhibition of the MAO-A isoform prevents the metabolism of dietary tyramine in the gut, thus allowing intact tyramine to enter the circulation. A hypertensive crisis occurs as a result of a powerful pressor effect of tyramine. This is treated with phentolamine.

questions.text: A 55-year-old woman presented with gait disturbance. On examination, the Romberg test was positive, and pupillary reflex was absent. Past history is significant for untreated painless genital ulcer. Which of the following investigations would be the best in this case?

choices.text: FTA-ABS- fluorescent treponemal antibody absorption test

questions.solution:
The above clinical scenario is suggestive of tertiary syphilis/ neurosyphilis. Venereal disease research laboratory (VDRL) test of cerebrospinal fluid (CSF) would be the best investigation as the diagnosis is neurosyphilis.

Tertiary syphilis occurs months to years after infection with Treponema pallidum. Patients usually present with the following clinical findings:

  • Gummas: It is the most common manifestation. These are the granulomas involving the skin, bones (perforated nasal septum), liver, and spleen.
  • Cardiovascular manifestations occur due to end arteritis of the vasa vasorum supplying the aorta. This results in aortitis, aortic regurgitation, and aortic aneurysm.
  • Neurosyphilis
    • End arteritis of cerebral vessels results in meningovascular syphilis. Patients present with symptoms of cerebral infarcts like aphasia, hemiparesis, and visual loss.
    • The actual destruction of neurons by the treponemes results in:
      • Tabes dorsalis affect the dorsal column of the spinal cord. Bowel and bladder disturbances, foot slap, impotence, ataxia, loss of position, and vibration sense, resulting in a positive Romberg test.
      • Involvement of neurons of the cerebral cortex results in Argyll-Robertson pupil (reacts to accommodation but not to light), illusions, delusions, hallucinations, slurring of speech, and reduced memory.

The CSF VDRL test is considered diagnostic of neurosyphilis. It has high specificity.

Aqueous crystalline penicillin G or aqueous procaine penicillin G is used for the treatment of neurosyphilis.

Related Pearl: Stages of syphilis

Primary syphilis:

  • Chancre - Painless, indurated, usually single. The chancre self heals in 1-4 months.
  • Lymphadenopathy - Painless, unilateral or bilateral, shotty and rubbery inguinal nodes
  • Dory flop sign - As the chancre is too hard to fold, it will flip over once the prepuce is retracted back.

Secondary syphilis:

  • A & B: Generalized non-itchy rash with no vesicles present on the palm and sole. This is the most common lesion.
  • C & D: Condyloma lata.
  • E: Moth-eaten non-scarring alopecia
  • F: Mucous patches are flat erosions on the tongue that can coalesce to form snail track ulcers. These are the most infectious lesions.
  • G: Pigmentary plaques
  • H: Psoriasiform syphilitic lesions
  • Generalized diffuse non-tender lymphadenopathy

Tertiary syphilis:

  • Gummatous syphilis are deep punched-out ulcers, with gum-like secretions on the floor
  • Pseudo-chancre redux is a gumma occurring at the site of a previously healed ulcer  
  • CVS - Aortitis and aneurysm of the ascending aorta
  • CNS - General paresis of the insane and tabes dorsalis 

Latent syphilis is the period between secondary and tertiary syphilis. In this period the patient is asymptomatic clinically and only serological evidence of the infection is present. It is classified into:

  • Early latent syphilis - Within 1 year of infection
  • Late latent syphilis - After 1 year of infection

Related Pearl: Syphilis - Diagnostic Serology

Nontreponemal tests (VDRL, RPR)

VDRL- Venereal disease Research Laboratory test

RPR- Rapid Plasma Reagin test

  • Quantitative tests(titres)
  • Reagin antibody tests; based on cardiolipin antigen
  • VDRL can be used to test CSF whereas RPR cannot be used
  • RPR does not require preheating of serum unlike VDRL
  • VDRL requires light microscope for interpretation whereas RPR can be read macroscopically
  • Decrease in titers confirms treatment
  • Sensitivity of RPR(86%)>VDRL(76%) in primary syphilis

Treponemal Tests

FTA-ABS- Fluorescent Treponemal Antibody Absorption test

TPI-Treponema pallidum immobilization test

TPPA-Treponema pallidum particle agglutination assay

TPHA-Treponema pallidum haemagglutination test

EIA-Enzyme-linked ImmunoAssay

  • Detect antibody to treponemal antigens
  • Qualitative tests
  • Greater sensitivity in early infection
  • Positive even after treatment hence cannot be used to detect reinfection.
  • First test to be positive: FTA-ABS
  • Most specific: TPHA,TPPA, EIA

questions.text: A 26-year-old woman complains of pain and foreign body sensation in her eye. Physical examination reveals redness of her eyes, the presence of a greyish-white serpiginous ulcer, and hypopyon that have increased significantly over 2 days. Which of the following organisms most likely caused this patient's disease?
questions.solution:
The clinical vignette describes a case of ulcus serpens which is characteristically caused by Pneumococcus.

The characteristic hypopyon corneal ulcer caused by Pneumococcus is called ulcus serpens. The bacterial hypopyon is sterile. 

Ulcus serpens is a greyish-white or yellowish disc-shaped ulcer occurring near the center of the cornea. The ulcer has a tendency to creep over the cornea in a serpiginous fashion. Pain is lesser as compared to other bacterial corneal ulcers. The hypopyon enlarges rapidly. Features similar to bacterial corneal ulcers such as watering of the eye, photophobia, blurred vision, and redness of the eyes are seen.

Other clinical signs include:

  • Swelling of lids
  • Blepharospasm
  • Conjunctival hyperemia
  • Ciliary congestion
  • Violent iridocyclitis is commonly associated
  • Often results in secondary glaucoma

Other causes of corneal ulcers with hypopyon include - Staphylococci, Streptococci, Gonococci, Moraxella, and Pseudomonas pyocyanea.

Other options:

Option A - Pseudomonas - produce an irregular sharp ulcer with thick greenish mucopurulent exudate, diffuse liquefactive necrosis, and semiopaque (ground glass) surrounding the cornea.

Options C & D - Typical oval or irregularly shaped bacterial ulcers with or without hypopyon. They do not produce serpiginous ulcers as seen in ulcus serpens.

questions.text: A 55-year-old male patient was diagnosed with Pneumocystis jiroveci pneumonia. A fixed-dose combination of trimethoprim-sulfamethoxazole was prescribed. The drugs act by inhibiting which of the following enzymes respectively?
questions.solution:
Trimethoprim inhibits the enzyme dihydrofolate reductase, while sulfamethoxazole inhibits the enzyme dihydropteroate synthase.

The fixed-drug combination of trimethoprim-sulfamethoxazole is the drug of choice for Pneumocystis jiroveci (formerly P carinii) pneumonia.

Trimethoprim is a selective inhibitor of microbial dihydrofolate reductase. Dihydrofolate reductase is involved in the reduction of dihydrofolate to tetrahydrofolate. The combination of sulfonamide with trimethoprim will result in a sequential blockade of bacterial folate synthesis that causes a synergistic action and acts as a bactericidal.

Cotrimoxazole is used in the management of urinary tract infections, bacterial diarrhea, dysentery, pneumocystis jiroveci infections, and chancroid.

Adverse effects include nausea, vomiting, stomatitis, headache, megaloblastic anemia, and rashes. Blood dyscrasias can occur rarely.

questions.text: During the clinical examination of a 54-year-old female patient with non-productive cough, exertional dyspnoea, and fatigue, you notice cyanosis and clubbing. On further examination, you hear late inspiratory velcro crackles at lung bases that are unaltered by coughing and the pulmonary function test showed a restrictive deficit. Which of the following conditions should this typical clinical picture prompt you to suspect?
questions.solution:
Interstitial lung disease (ILD) should be suspected in this patient.

ILD or diffuse parenchymal lung disease  is a heterogeneous collection of disorders that share a common presentation (dyspnea), physical findings (late inspiratory crackles), and chest radiographs (septal thickening and reticulonodular changes)

ILD occurs in patients aged more than 60 years and is common in women. They may present with an insidious onset of progressive dyspnea and non-productive cough. Late inspiratory velcro crackles on the lung base are one of the physical findings present in ILD. Cyanosis and clubbing are seen in advanced diseases.

In ILD, Pulmonary function test show a restrictive deficit. 

Based on the histopathological pattern on lung biopsy-

 Type of ILD Histologic pattern seen
Idiopathic pulmonary fibrosis Usual interstitial pneumonia (UIP)
Non-specific interstitial pneumonia A fibrotic or cellular pattern of non-specific interstitial pneumonia (NSIP)
Respiratory bronchiolitis associated interstitial lung disease Respiratory bronchiolitis associated lung disease
Systematic sclerosis-associated ILD Both UIP and NSIP
 Sarcoidosis Non caseating granuloma

Other options:

Bronchiolitis, bronchiectasis, and bronchial asthma are obstructive lung diseases. Pulmonary function test show obstructive pattern. 

Note: Velcro crackles may also be heard in case of radiation pneumonitis. Also, it may be difficult to reliably distinguish the same from crackles of pulmonary edema. 

Related Pearl: HRCT Findings in Interstitial Lung Diseases

Idiopathic interstitial lung diseases

  • Idiopathic pulmonary fibrosis / Usual interstitial pneumonia
    • Honeycombing
    • Reticular shadows
    • Traction bronchiectasis
    • Complete loss of lung architecture
    • Absence of other nonspecific findings (ground-glass opacities, nodules, cysts, consolidations)
  • Non-specific interstitial pneumonia
    • Extensive ground-glass opacities
    • Sub pleural sparing (specific, but not seen always)
  • Cryptogenic organizing pneumonia (COP)
    • Patchy consolidation with air bronchogram
    • Reverse halo/ Atoll sign: Ground glass area surrounded by peripheral consolidation (as shown below in red arrows)
  • Lymphocytic interstitial pneumonia (LIP)
    • Thin-walled cysts (shown below in red arrows)
    • Centrilobular nodules 
    • Ground glass opacities
  •  Respiratory bronchiolitis related interstitial lung disease
    • Centrilobular ground-glass nodules
    • Bronchial wall thickening
  • Acute interstitial pneumonia
    • Diffuse patchy ground-glass opacities
  • Desquamated interstitial pneumonia
    • Patchy ground-glass opacities 

Other forms of ILDs

  • Lymphangioleiomyomatosis (LAM)
    • Regular thin-walled cysts
  • Pulmonary alveolar proteinosis (PAP)
    • Ground-glass opacification with superimposed septal thickening, known as “crazy paving”
    • It is characteristic but not diagnostic
  • Pulmonary Langerhans cell histiocytosis (PLCH)
    • Bilateral irregular shaped cysts with nodules, predominantly in the upper lobe.

questions.text: A 7-year-old boy with frequent nosebleeds is brought to the OPD for a routine check-up.  He has a history of excessive bleeding during a dental procedure that he underwent recently.  A normal platelet count, prolonged BT, normal PT, and a prolonged aPTT are noted in his laboratory reports. Which of the following is the major source of the likely deficient factor?
questions.solution:
This patient's clinical features are suggestive of von-Willebrand disease. It is caused by a deficiency of the von-Willebrand factor. The major source of plasma von-Willebrand factor is endothelial cells. 

They are present within cytoplasmic vesicles called Weibel-Palade bodies.

Normal Platelet count, Prolonged BT, Normal PT, and Prolonged aPTT are seen in von-Willebrand disease. Factor VIII is found bound to the Von-Willebrand factor (vWF)  in the blood. Deficiency of vWF results in Factor VIII deficiency and prolongation of aPTT in this disease. Prolonged BT is due to abnormal platelet-mediated hemostasis.

vWF is also found in

  • Platelet granules (Less as compared to endothelial cells)
  • Subendothelium, where it binds to collagen

Von Willebrand disease is the most common inherited bleeding disorder in humans. The bleeding tendency is usually mild and manifests during surgical or dental procedures. The most common presenting symptoms are spontaneous bleeding from mucous membranes (epistaxis), excessive bleeding from wounds, or menorrhagia.

It is usually transmitted as an autosomal dominant disorder, but rare autosomal recessive variants can be seen.

Three types are recognized, with phenotypic variations:

Type 1 and type 3 von-Willebrand disease are associated with quantitative defects in vWF.

Type 1 is an autosomal dominant disorder characterized by a mild to moderate vWF deficiency, accounting for about 70% of all cases. It is associated with mild disease.

Type 3 disease is an autosomal disorder resulting in little to no vWF synthesis. Because vWF stabilizes factor VIII in the circulation, factor VIII levels are also reduced in type 3 disease and the associated bleeding disorder is often severe.

Type 2 von-Willebrand disease is characterized by qualitative defects in vWF. Type 2A is the most common. It is inherited as an autosomal dominant disorder.

questions.text: A 46-year-old male presents with mild fever, pain and difficulty in swallowing for the past one week. The upper GI endoscopy picture shows the following finding. Biopsy specimens taken from this lesion show nuclear inclusions within a rim of degenerating epithelial cells. What can be the most likely diagnosis in this case?
questions.solution:
Based on this patient's clinical findings, the patient has herpetic (HSV) esophagitis. Herpes viruses typically cause punched-out or volcanic ulcers as shown in the image.

Biopsy specimens will show nuclear viral inclusions within a rim of degenerating epithelial cells at the margin of the ulcer.

Herpes simplex virus type 1 or 2 can cause esophagitis. Vesicles on the nose and lips may coexist and are suggestive of a herpetic etiology.

Varicella-zoster virus can also cause esophagitis in children with chickenpox or adults with zoster. The characteristic endoscopic findings are vesicles and small, punched-out ulcerations. Because herpes simplex infections are limited to squamous epithelium, biopsies from the ulcer margins are most likely to reveal the characteristic ground-glass nuclei, eosinophilic Cowdry’s type A inclusion bodies, and giant cells.

Diagnosis: Culture or polymerase chain reaction (PCR) assays are helpful to identify acyclovir-resistant strains.

Treatment: Acyclovir (200 mg orally five times a day for 7–10 days) can be used for immunocompetent hosts, while immunocompromised patients are treated with acyclovir (400 mg orally five times a day for 14–21 days), famciclovir (500 mg orally three times a day), or valacyclovir (1 g orally three times a day). 

Other options:

  • Eosinophilic esophagitis is an acute eosinophil-dominated esophageal inflammation associated with atopic disease. On endoscopy, the esophagus shows stacked circular rings (feline esophagus), strictures, and linear furrows.
  • CMV causes shallower ulcerations especially in immunocompromised hosts and on HPE characteristic nuclear and cytoplasmic inclusions within capillary endothelium and stromal cells are seen. CMV lesions appear as serpiginous ulcers in an otherwise normal mucosa, particularly in the distal esophagus.
  • Candidiasis of the esophagus is characterized by adherent, gray-white pseudomembranes composed of densely matted fungal hyphae and inflammatory cells covering the esophageal mucosa.

questions.text: A 35-year-old female patient complains of a change in her voice for the past 1 week. She had a thyroidectomy performed for thyroid carcinoma 8 days back. Which of the following nerves is more prone to injury that led to her current condition?
questions.solution:
The clinical vignette describes a case of vocal cord paresis. The left recurrent laryngeal nerve is more prone to injury, causing a vocal cord paralysis.

  • The left recurrent laryngeal nerve is more prone to injury because
    • It is longer as it loops around the arch of the aorta to climb back to the larynx.
    • It is related to with more structures in the mediastinum.
  • The right recurrent laryngeal nerve loops around the subclavian artery, therefore it is shorter and safer.

Etiology of vocal cord paresis - 

  • Iatrogenic – Endotracheal intubation, surgical procedures of the neck, skull base, or chest.
  • Malignancy – In skull base, neck, or chest.
  • Trauma – Including the neck and chest in addition to the larynx.
  • Neurological – Bulbar palsies, including stroke (specifically lateral medullary syndrome), and demyelinating diseases.
  • Idiopathic – Diagnosis of exclusion

questions.text: A patient with leprosy comes to the primary health centre with multiple cuts and abrasions on his feet. He reports having reduced sensation in his feet. After addressing the wound, he is referred to another centre to receive microcellular rubber footwear. Which of the following is incorrect regarding this scenario?

choices.text: The ministry of health and family welfare has sponsored this program
The aim is to reduce the complications of this disease
This is a tertiary level of prevention
The district hospital will supply the microcellular footwear

questions.solution:
The incorrect statement regarding this scenario is that the district hospital will supply the microcellular (MCR) footwear. The district nucleus supplies the MCR footwear, not the district hospital. 

In the given scenario, the patient has developed multiple abrasions and cuts secondary to insensitive feet suggestive of neuropathy. To reduce further complications this patient is referred to the district nucleus to receive the MCR footwear. This is a form of tertiary prevention since it reduces the number and impact of complications. 

National Leprosy Eradication Programme (NLEP) is a program of the ministry of health and family welfare, the government of India. It is sponsored centrally and the program has the following components: 

  • Case detection and management   
  • Disability prevention and medical rehabilitation (DPMR)   
  • Information, education and communication (IEC) including behaviour change communication (BCC)
  • Human resource and capacity building   
  • Program management

During the year 2017-2018, India reported 1,26,164 new cases with an annual new case detection rate (ANCDR) of 9.27/1,00,000 population.

questions.text: A 22-year-old mother wants to get her 2-day-old newborn to be screened for hypothyroidism as she had read on the internet that it is a common cause of preventable mental retardation. Which of the following strategies is most commonly followed for the screening process?

choices.text: A fresh blood sample and screen first for TSH levels
A fresh blood sample and screen first for T4 levels
A dried blood sample and screen first for TSH levels
A dried blood sample and screen first for T4 levels

questions.solution:
The most commonly followed strategy for newborn screening of congenital hypothyroidism is using a dried blood sample and screening it first for TSH.

Congenital hypothyroidism is the most common preventable cause of mental retardation. Screening of children for congenital hypothyroidism is very important, as early diagnosis and treatment can help in normal intellectual development. Children diagnosed beyond the neonatal period have a poor outcome.

Screening is usually done between day 2 - day 4 postnatally using dried blood samples for this. The most commonly used strategy is screening for TSH first as they have higher sensitivity compared to the T4-based approach. Although the TSH-based approach is better, it doesn't identify central hypothyroidism, which can be identified by the T4-first approach. But, the T4-based approach misses out on the cases of compensated hypothyroidism.

The incidence of congenital hypothyroidism is 4 times higher in India compared to western countries. Thyroid dysgenesis has emerged as the most common cause of congenital hypothyroidism in India.

Clinical features of hypothyroidism:

Congenital Acquired
Open posterior fontanel Growth retardation
Umbilical hernia Delayed skeletal maturation
Characteristic edematous facies Delayed dental development
Constipation Delayed puberty
Pallor Myopathy and pseudohypertrophy
Hypothermia Enlarged sella
Large tongue Pseudotumor cerebri
Rough dry skin  
Hypotonia  
Large abdomen  

Management is by thyroid replacement soon after the diagnosis. Thyroxine of dose 10-15 μg/kg/day should be started and adjusted to achieve the normal free T4 range. TSH may be elevated up to 2 years of age with a reset of the hypothalamic-pituitary axis.

questions.text: IPC section 313 deals with _____

choices.text: Death of mother due to miscarriage
Preventing the child being born alive or to cause it to die after birth

questions.solution:
IPC Section 313 deals with causing miscarriage without consent.

IPC Section 313 penalizes causing miscarriage of a pregnant woman (whether she has attained the stage of quickening or not) without her consent. It relates to the commission of an offense of causing miscarriage of a woman when the woman, who primarily interested in the result, is not a consenting party to the act.

Here, only the person procuring the abortion will receive punishment, which is imprisonment of either description extendable to 10 years and liability to fine.

questions.text: A 62-year-old female with history of ovarian carcinoma in the mother achieved menopause with smooth transition. And she is on hormone replacement therapy. She developed abdominal pain and on examination the right adnexal mass was palpable, non tender. On USG examination she has a 3 X 3 cm smooth cyst in her ovary. Which is the next step

choices.text: Reassure and advice regular follow up once in 6 months
Confirm USG findings by ordering CT scan
Do an exploratory laparoscopy to visualise the nature of cyst
Do CA-125 levels, if normal advise regular check up

questions.solution:
Doing a CA-125 level measurement is the next best step according to the latest RCOG guidelines for Post-menopausal Ovarian cyst.

Initial steps in management include the following:

  • Estimate CA – 125 level
  • USG
  • Calculating Risk of Malignancy index
    • RMI = U x  M  x  Ca-125
    • U – Ultrasound score
    • M – Menopausal status
    • Ca 125 – Serum levels

Option B : CT scan is not recommended in initial evaluation.

Option C : Laparotomy/laparoscopy only indicated if size > 5 cm or RMI > 200.

questions.text: A 22-year-old male patient complains of pruritis. He feels intense pruritus and has painful, red streaks between his fingers and in the groin area. He states that the itchiness is worse at night. Other students from his college dormitory also present with similar complaints. An image of his skin on physical examination is shown below. Which of the following can be used for the treatment of this patient?
questions.solution:
The clinical vignette describes a case of scabies. Management of scabies involves topical application of 5% permethrin cream.

The image shows a magnified view of a burrowing trail of the scabies mite. The scaly patch on the left was caused by the scratching and marks the mite's entry point into the skin. The mite has burrowed to the top-right, where it can be seen as a dark spot at the end. Burrow is the characteristic lesion of scabies.

Scabies is an ectoparasitic infestation caused in humans by the Sarcoptes scabiei var. hominis.

The characteristic symptoms of a scabies infection include intense itching and superficial burrows. Burrows present as slightly raised brownish tortuous lesions. It is created by the excavation of the adult mite in the epidermis. In most people, the trails of the burrowing mites are linear in the skin.

Typical locations of lesions are the finger webs, the flexor surfaces of the wrists, the elbows, the axillae, the buttocks and genitalia, and the breasts of women.

Other treatment options - topical application of 1% lindane lotion, benzyl benzoate, esdepalletrin (bioallethrin), crotamiton, and precipitated sulfur.

Other options:

Option B- Oral albendazole is used in the treatment of larva currens and cutaneous larva migrans. They present as pruritic erythematous papules at the site of penetration of the hookworms with an erythematous serpiginous larva track.

The image below shows cutaneous larva migrans:

 

The image below shows larva currens:

 

Option D- Topical corticosteroids are used in certain cases of bed bugs. They present as pruritic maculopapular lesions with a visible hemorrhagic punctum in the center. Three or four lesions may be arranged in a line or a curve pattern which is called breakfast‐lunch‐dinner alignment.

questions.text: A 14-year-old patient presents to the clinic with midline swelling in the neck. He recently had an episode of sore throat, following which the swelling became painful and red. The swelling moves upwards on swallowing and tongue protrusion. Which of the following is the definitive management of this condition?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario and the image are suggestive of a thyroglossal cyst. Sistrunk's operation is the definitive management for this condition.

Thyroglossal cysts represent the persistence of the tract through which the thyroid gland descends from the base of the tongue to the lower part of the neck. The definitive management of a thyroglossal cyst involves the excision of this tract. This includes the removal of the body of the hyoid bone, and the suprahyoid tract from the base of the tongue (foramen cecum) to the vallecula along with a core of normal tissue from either side. This process is known as Sistrunk's operation. 

Thyroglossal duct cysts present as a midline neck swelling that moves upwards with swallowing and tongue protrusion. They can become infected when an upper respiratory tract infection spreads to the cyst. During such episodes, they may burst onto the surface of the skin, leading to the formation of a thyroglossal fistula.

The recurrence rate with simple excision (option B) is far higher than Sistrunk's operation, so it is not preferred. Total thyroidectomy (option D) is only indicated if papillary thyroid carcinoma has developed in the thyroglossal cyst. There is no role of percutaneous aspiration (option A) in the definitive management of thyroglossal cysts.

questions.text:
A 60-year-old man is being treated for a longstanding venous ulcer that fails to heal even after multiple treatment modalities. You see the junior resident probing for a detailed history again. Which of the following factors from the patient's history lead to delay in wound healing?
  1. Diet rich in vitamin C
  2. Smoking 2 cigarettes a day 
  3. High protein intake in diet
  4. Poor glycemic control
  5. Patient is taking steroids for some chronic disease
questions.solution:
Delayed wound healing is seen with:

  • Diet deficient in protein and vitamin C
  • Steroids. 
  • Smoking
  • Poor glycemic control

Related Pearl: Factors Influencing Healing

  • Infection: one of the most important causes of delay in healing; prolongs inflammation; increases the local tissue injury
  • Diabetes: most important systemic cause of abnormal wound healing
  • Nutritional status: protein deficiency and vitamin C deficiency inhibit collagen synthesis and retard healing.
  • Glucocorticoids (steroids): anti-inflammatory effects; results in weakness of the scar due to inhibition of TGF-β production and diminished fibrosis
  • Mechanical factors: such as increased local pressure or torsion; may cause wounds to pull apart or dehisce
  • Poor perfusion: due to arteriosclerosis, diabetes, or obstructed venous drainage; also impairs healing
  • Foreign bodies: such as fragments of steel, glass, or even bone; impede healing
  • Type and extent of tissue injury: affect subsequent repair;
  • Location of the injury and the character of the injured tissue: also important

questions.text:
A 23-year-old woman comes to the clinic with lower abdominal pain for the last three days. Her last menstrual period was 7 days ago and the pain started subsequently. The pain is bilateral and increases in intensity on sexual intercourse. On examination,
Vital Signs  
Temperature 99°F
Pulse Rate 90/minute
Respiratory Rate 17/minute
Blood Pressure 140/90 mm Hg
SpO2 98% on room air

Abdominal examination shows abdominal tenderness to palpation. Pelvic examination shows acute cervical motion tenderness. 

 Lab Investigation  Value  Normal Range
Hb (g/dL)  10.5  12-15
Leukocyte Count  16,000  4,000-10,000
 ESR (mm/hr)  32  <11 
 CRP (mg/L)  12  <10 

Recurrent episodes would likely result in all of the following complications except?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario describes a case of pelvic inflammatory disease. Recurrent disease will lead to all the mentioned complications except for Leiomyoma uteri. 

Risk factors for PID:

  • Douching
  • Substance abuse
  • Multiple sexual partners
  • Lower socioeconomic status
  • Substance abuse
  • Recent new sexual partners
  • Younger age (10 to 19 years)
  • Other sexually transmitted infections
  • No contraceptive use

Criteria to diagnose PID:

Definitive criteria

  • Histopathologic evidence of Endometritis on biopsy
  • Imaging study (TVS/MRI) evidence of thickened fluid filled tubes = tuboovarian abscess
  • Laparoscopic evidence of PID

Minimum criteria

  • Lower abdominal tenderness
  • Adnexal tenderness
  • Cervical motion tenderness

Additional criteria

  • Oral temperature >38.3 oC
  • Mucopurulent cervical or vaginal discharge, Cervical friability
  • Raised ESR or CRP
  • Laboratory documentation of positive cervical infection with Gonorrhea or C.trachomatis

Presumptive treatment for PID can be started in sexually active women if they meet at least one of the minimum criteria

Treatment

  • OPD management of PID is:
    • Inj.Ceftriaxone 250 mg IM single dose + Doxycycline 100 mg BD x 14 days + Metronidazole 500 mg BD x 14 days.
  • Parenteral treatment for PID is:
    • Inj Cefotetan 2g IV BD + Doxycycline 100 mg BD or
    • Inj Cefoxitin 2g IV QID + Doxycycline 100 mg BD

To minimize disease transmission, women should be instructed to abstain from sexual intercourse until therapy is completed, symptoms have resolved, and partners have been adequately treated.

Chronic PID:

The previous history of pelvic infection indicates the diagnosis of chronic PID. Symptoms can include low backache, abdominal pain, deep dyspareunia, rectal irritation, congestive dysmenorrhea, etc.

Complications of chronic/recurrent PID:

  • Infertility
  • Hydrosalpinx
  • Chronic pelvic pain
  • Ectopic pregnancy
  • Ovarian cancer

Related Pearl: Syndromic Management of Sexually Transmitted Infections

Partner Management when asymptomatic is not required for Gardenella vaginalis, Candida and Herpes infections.

questions.text: An autopsy is being performed on the corpse of a 50-year-old HIV-infected patient. The forensic medicine resident uses a technique of in situ dissection combined with en block removal of organs. This technique is known as_____
questions.solution:
Rokitansky's technique involves performing in situ dissection combined with en block removal of organs.

It is considered the ideal method for patients affected with highly contagious illnesses like HIV and hepatitis B.

Related Pearl: Autopsy Techniques

  • Virchow's technique: Organs are removed one by one from the body to be examined. Here the cranial cavity is opened first, then the spinal cord, followed by thoracic, cervical, and abdominal organs in that order.
  • Ghon's technique: Here the organs are removed 'en bloc'. The thoracic, cervical, pelvic, and abdominal organs are removed as organ blocks.
  • Rokitansky's technique: This is characterized by 'in situ' dissection in part combined with en bloc removal like Ghon's technique. The dissection begins at the neck and slowly works its way down the body and the organ is removed as a bloc. A cut is first made at the larynx to separate the esophagus from the pharynx. The larynx and trachea are pulled downward and using a scalpel, the chest organs are cut. The diaphragm is cut to expose the abdominal organs. Other organs like the bladder and rectum are separated from the body by using a scalpel to cut the pelvic ligaments.
  • Letulle's technique: Thoracic, cervical, abdominal, and pelvic organs are removed 'en masse' meaning as one big organ block. It allows the body to be made available for examination in less than 30 minutes as the process of removing the organs is much quicker.

questions.text: A patient presents with a sudden onset of nausea and pain in his right eye associated with blurring of vision and halos. On examination, ciliary congestion, corneal oedema, and a mid-dilated pupil are observed. Gonioscopy reveals a closed angle of the anterior chamber. All of the following are sequelae to this episode except _____.
questions.solution:
All of the above are sequelae to this episode, except iris bombe as it is implicated in the pathogenesis of angle closure glaucoma, not a sequel.

The clinical vignette of acute onset ocular pain with nausea or vomiting, blurring of vision with halos with ciliary congestion, corneal edema, and a mid-dilated pupil on examination are all indicative of acute angle-closure glaucoma.

It is an ocular emergency that causes acute red-eye and is associated with at least two of the following symptoms: acute onset ocular pain with nausea or vomiting, intermittent blurring of vision with halos, photophobia, or loss of vision.

It is also associated with three of the following signs: ciliary congestion, corneal edema and subsequent haziness, fixed and mid-dilated, usually oval pupil, a shallow anterior chamber, and intraocular pressure elevated above 40 mmHg.

The clinical status of the eye subsequent to an attack of acute angle-closure glaucoma is considered as the sequelae of the attack, regardless of whether the patient has been treated or not. These include:

  1. Post-surgical acute primary angle-closure
  2. Spontaneous angle reopening
  3. Ciliary body shut down
  4. Vogt's triad, which includes glaukomflecken i.e anterior subcapsular lenticular opacity, patches of iris atrophy, and slightly dilated non-reacting pupil.

Iris bombe is not a part of the sequelae of acute angle-closure glaucoma. It refers to the collection of aqueous in the posterior chamber pushing the peripheral flaccid iris anteriorly resulting in appositional angle closure.

The below image shows features of angle closure glaucoma.

The management of acute angle-closure glaucoma includes:

  • Immediate medical management to lower IOP- oral acetazolamide or intravenous mannitol is used first. Tricyclic antidepressants, drugs having significant anticholinergic action should be avoided or used with extreme caution in patients prone to developing acute angle-closure glaucoma.
  • Definitive treatment with laser peripheral iridotomy.
  • Prophylaxis of the fellow eye followed by long-term glaucoma surveillance and management of intraocular pressure of both eyes.

Related Pearl: Antiglaucoma drugs: Mechanism of lowering intraocular pressure (IOP) at a glance

Drugs that increase trabecular outflow

  • Miotics (e.g., pilocarpine)
  • Epinephrine, dipivefrine
  • Bimatoprost
  • Rho-kinase inhibitor (Netarsudil)

Drugs that increase uveoscleral outflow

  • Prostaglandins (latanoprost)
  • Epinephrine, dipivefrine
  • Brimonidine
  • Apraclonidine

Drugs that decrease aqueous production

  • Carbonic anhydrase inhibitors (e.g., acetazolamide, dorzolamide)
  • Alpha receptor stimulators in ciliary process (e.g., epinephrine, dipivefrine, clonidine, brimonidine, apraclonidine)
  • Beta-blockers

Hyperosmotic agents - (e.g., glycerol, mannitol, urea)

questions.text: A 26-year-old female is being evaluated for post-partum hemorrhage in the labor room. She had an uncomplicated pregnancy and delivered a 2.7 kg baby boy by normal vaginal delivery. Her past surgical history includes a fibroid that was removed by myomectomy two years previously. On examination. there is profuse vaginal bleeding. Ultrasound examination shows an intracavitary mass with thickened endometrial echo. Doppler examination shows increased vascularity. Appropriate management is started and nitroglycerin fails to provide adequate benefit. Which of the following anesthetic agents will offer an additional obstetric benefit to this patient?
questions.solution:
The given clinical vignette describes a case of post-partum hemorrhage due to retained placenta. General anesthesia with an inhalational agent will offer the obstetric benefit of relaxing the uterus.  

Such bleeding most often is the result of:

  • Abnormal involution of the placental site
  • Retention of a placental fragment 
  • Uterine artery pseudoaneurysm
  • Placental polyp: Usually, retained products undergo necrosis with fibrin deposition and may eventually form a polyp. As the eschar of the polyp detaches from the myometrium, hemorrhage may be brisk.
  • May also be caused by von Willebrand disease or other inherited coagulopathies.

Related Pearl: Obstetrics Indication for GA

  • Fetal distress during 2nd stage of labour
  • Tetanic uterine contractions
  • Breech extraction
  • Version and extraction
  • Manual removal of a retained placenta
  • Replacement of an inverted uterus
  • Uncontrollable psychiatric patients
  • LSCS in patients with rheumatic heart disease and mitral valve stenosis

Related Pearl: Obstetric Anesthesia

  • N2O is avoided in early pregnancy because of possible teratogenic effects
  • Anesthesia is dangerous in all trimester but comparatively, 2nd trimester is the safest
  • Supine hypotension syndrome: In 3rd-trimester circulatory collapse occurs due to diminished venous return because of the pressure of gravid uterus over IVC in the supine position.
  • Best uterine relaxant is halothane, so uterine tetanic contractions are most rapidly treated by halothane.
  • M.C. cause of death during GA in obstetrics is Mendelson’s syndrome. This is prevented by empty stomach, H2 blockers, SELLICKS maneuver i.e. backward pressure on the cartilage
  • Contraindications:
    • Gallamine crosses the placenta.
    • Morphine causes respiratory depression in mother and baby. For treatment naloxone, 0.01mg/kg is given through the umbilical vein.

questions.text: Identify the maneuver shown in the image below:
questions.solution:
The above image depicts the Ritgen’s maneuver.

Ritgen’s maneuver:

  • The right hand is draped with a sterile towel.
  • The fingers of the right hand pressing posterior to the rectum exerts upward pressure to the chin and extends the head. The extension of the head prevents the head from slipping back in between the contractions.
  • The left hand placed over the occiput exerts a downward counter pressure to prevent the rapid extension of the head
  • The ritgen’s maneuver thus helps in the controlled delivery of the head of the fetus.

Other options:

Option b: Pinard’s maneuver is used to facilitate the delivery of legs in case of frank breech presentation.

Option c: Lovset’s maneuver is used to facilitate the delivery of arms in breech presentation.

Option d: In zavanelli maneuver the fetal head is rotated to the pre restitution position and pushed back into the pelvis. The fetus is then delivered by caesarean section.

questions.text:
A 48-year-old employee presented to the ESI hospital with resting tremors, slowness of movements, depression, dementia, and a shuffling, short-stepping gait. He has been working in the same factory for the past 11 years and his monthly income is Rs 20,000. Which of the following is incorrect regarding the benefits he can avail of under the ESI Act?

ESI: Employees' State Insurance Act

choices.text: Outpatient care by a specialist and supply of drugs free of cost
An extended sickness benefit for 3 years.
Inpatient care by a specialist and supply of drugs free of cost

questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario is suggestive of a patient with Parkinson's disease. He can avail of the extended sickness benefit, which is payable only for 2 years (not 3 years) under the ESI Act. 

ESI act covers all employees getting income up to Rs.21,000/- per month. Employer contributes 3.25% of the total wage bill. An employee contributes 0.75% of wages. State and Central governments share medical expenditure in the ratio of 1:7.

Extended sickness benefit is payable for 2 years for a set of 34 diseases such as TB, leprosy, malignant diseases, diabetes, Parkinson's, myasthenia gravis, glaucoma, coronary artery disease, etc.

Few important points to be known about the ESI Act:

Medical benefit comprises complete medical care including hospitalization, free of cost which includes:

  • Out-patient care
  • Supply of drugs and dressings
  • Specialist services in all branches of medicine
  • Pathological and radiological investigations
  • Domiciliary services
  • Antenatal, natal, and postnatal services
  • Immunization services
  • Family planning services
  • Emergency services
  • Ambulance services
  • Health-education
  • In-patient treatment.

Related Pearl: ESI ACT, 1948

Employees State Insurance Act, 1948 (Revised in 2019)

Scope: It is applicable to all factories in India excluding:

  • Defence 
  • Railway  
  • Mines 

Finance Contribution

  • It covers all employees getting income up to Rs.21,000/- per month.
  • Employee – 0.75% of his daily wage.
  • Employer – 3.25% of the employees' daily wage.
  • Medical benefit – 1/8th by the state government and 7/8th by the ESI Corporation.

Benefits

To the Employees

  • Medical Benefit- full medical care is provided free of cost in case of sickness, employment injury, and maternity.
  • Sickness Benefit- is given at 70% of average daily wages for a duration of 91 days in one year. In order to qualify for sickness benefit, the worker is required to contribute for 78 days in a period of 6 months.
    • Extended sickness benefit – 80% of the daily wages for a duration of 2 years, for 34 specified diseases such as TB, leprosy, malignant diseases, diabetes, Parkinson's, myasthenia gravis, glaucoma, coronary artery disease, etc.
    • Enhanced sickness benefit – at full wages for sterilization procedure; for a duration of 7 days post-vasectomy and 14 days post tubectomy. 
    • The total amount payable is double the standard sickness benefit rate, that is, equal to full wages.
  • Maternity Benefit – benefit is payable at full wages for 26 weeks (6.5 months) for pregnancy, 6 weeks following a miscarriage, and 30 days for sickness arising out of pregnancy. It also covers the premature birth of a child born to an insured woman.
  • Dependance Benefit– in case of death, as a result of employment injury, the dependents of an insured person are eligible for periodical payments. Pension at the rate of 90% of the wages is payable, shared by dependants in a fixed ratio, on monthly basis in accordance with the prescribed share. An eligible son or daughter is entitled to the dependant's benefit up to the age of 18; the benefit is withdrawn if the daughter marries earlier.
  • Disablement Benefits–
    • Temporary disability- at 90% daily wages as long as the person is disabled.
    • Permanent disability- lifetime pension. It also covers occupational diseases.
  • Funeral Benefit – a maximum of Rs.15,000/-.
  • Rehabilitation Benefit- on payment of Rs.10, the insured person and his/her family continue to get medical treatment after permanent disablement or retirement.

To the Employers

  • Exemption from Workman Compensation Act.
  • Exemption from Maternity Benefit Act.
  • Income tax rebate on the amount contributed towards the scheme.
  • Exemption from payment of medical allowance to employees and their dependants, or arranging for their medical care.
  • Healthy-work force.

questions.text:
A 2-week-old infant with ambiguous genitalia (as shown in the picture) presents with an episode of dehydration and shock, requiring hospitalization. Levels of which of the following would be increased in the infant?
  1. Cortisol
  2. Adrenocorticotropic hormone (ACTH)
  3. 17-hydroxyprogesterone
  4. Serum androgens
  5. Plasma renin
questions.solution:
Ambiguous genitalia (virilization) with dehydration and shock (salt-wasting crisis) suggests the diagnosis of congenital adrenal hyperplasia due to 21-hydroxylase deficiency. Lab investigations would reveal cortisol to be decreased while 17-hydroxyprogesterone, ACTH, serum androgens, and plasma renin would be increased.

Congenital adrenal hyperplasia (CAH) is a set of autosomal recessive disorders characterized by impaired synthesis of cortisol. This cortisol deficiency increases the secretion of ACTH, which leads to adrenocortical hyperplasia.

21-hydroxylase deficiency is the most common cause of CAH. The synthesis of both cortisol and aldosterone requires 21-hydroxylation, hence both hormones are deficient. These babies present at 10–14 days of age with progressive weight loss, weakness, anorexia, vomiting, dehydration, hypoglycemia, and hypotension. Without treatment, shock, cardiac arrhythmias, and death may occur within days or weeks.

questions.text:
You are the resident on the team performing a vaginal hysterectomy. Some of the steps of the procedure are given below.
  1. Patient is placed in standard dorsal lithotomy position
  2. Anterior peritoneum is entered 
  3. The bladder is drained
  4. The posterior vaginal wall is retracted
  5. The anterior vaginal wall is retracted
  6. The anterior and posterior cervical lips are grasped

Which of the following instruments may be used to perform 'Step 4' of this procedure?
questions.solution:
The instrument used to retract the posterior vaginal wall is an Auvard's weighted speculum which is marked as "C" in the image above.

Auvard speculum retracts the posterior vaginal wall during vaginal hysterectomy and is self retractory due to circular structure at handle which is heavy.

Image "A" is a towel-holding clip. Used to secure drapings and towel during surgery.

Image "B" is Vulsellum forceps used to grasp the cervical lip and steady cervix during vaginal surgery. It is a long instrument with a gentle curve so that the line of vision is not obstructed

Image "C" is Auvard's weighted speculum

Image "D" is Green armytage forceps. The tips are broad as shown in the image and hence can compress a wide area. It is used as a hemostat in caeserian sections. In LSCS (Lower segment Caesarean section), the cut uterine edges can bleed and Green armytage forceps are applied to the edge of the incision for hemostasis.

questions.text: A 30-year-old man presents with nasal stuffiness. He also states that he's had a few episodes of epistaxis in the past. On physical examination, a leafy, polypoidal, pink to purple mass attached to the nasal septum and hanging behind the soft palate is observed. The biopsy finding of the mass is shown in the image below. Which of the following is the best treatment modality for this patient?
questions.solution:
The clinical vignette describes a case of rhinosporidiosis. Surgical management (excision of the lesion with cauterization of the base) is the treatment of choice in rhinosporidiosis.

No drug treatment has proved effective, although dapsone is tried in some cases. Followup of the patient after surgical management is necessary, as recurrence is common.

Related Pearl: Rhinosporidiosis

  • It is a chronic granulomatous condition caused by Rhinosporidium seeberi which is recently reclassified as a member of the protistan Mesomycetozoa
  • It is more common in the southern states of India
  • It affects immunocompetent individuals
  • Most commonly a waterborne disease
  • Clinical features: Blood tinged nasal discharge, frank epistaxis, nasal stuffiness
  • Findings: 
    • Leafy, polypoidal mass, pink to purple in color and attached to the nasal septum or lateral wall
    • Sometimes, it extends into the nasopharynx and may hang behind the soft palate
    • The mass is very vascular and bleeds easily on touch
    • Its surface is studded with white dots representing the sporangia
  • Diagnosis: Biopsy which shows sporangia

Histologic section showing sporangium (arrow) which is fully packed with immature sporoblasts at the periphery and mature ones at the center

Treatment: Complete excision of the mass with diathermy knife and cauterization of its base. Recurrence may occur after surgical excision. Dapsone is also used.
