questions.text: Which of the following is a clinical application of the effect shown in the given picture?
questions.solution:
The given image depicts the Bragg peak effect. The Bragg peak effect is pronounced for protons. Proton therapy can be used to deliver precise radiation dosage for CNS malignancies.

Protons and the Bragg peak effect:

The Bragg curve plots the energy loss of ionizing radiation during its travel through matter.

The proton is a heavy and charged particle that gradually loses its speed as it interacts with human tissue. It is easily controlled and delivers its maximum dose at a precise depth and can go as far as 32 cm. The proton is very fast when it enters the patient’s body and deposits only a small dose on its way. The absorbed dose increases very gradually with greater depth and lower speed, suddenly rising to a peak when the proton is ultimately stopped. This is known as the Bragg Peak.

The behavior of the proton can be precisely determined and the beam can be directed so the Bragg peak occurs exactly within the tumor site. Immediately after this burst of energy, the proton completely stops to irradiate and the particles come to rest. 

Proton therapy therefore allows to target tumors inside the body, precisely localize the radiation dosage, and spare the patient’s healthy cells, offering a much less invasive alternative to treat cancer.

questions.text:
A 36-year old patient comes to the clinic with pain and tingling sensation in his left arm while overhead lifting. A radiograph of the cervical spine and shoulder is shown in image A . The physician performs the test labeled B in the image below on this patient. Pick the correct statements about this patient's condition.
  1. The given test is Adson's test
  2. The image finding in A is absolutely necessary for the development of this condition
  3. Sensory abnormalities involving T1 are common in this condition
  4. Symptoms involving compression of arteries are the most common
  5. All patients are managed with surgery
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario points to the diagnosis of thoracic outlet syndrome. The radiograph shows the presence of a cervical rib and "B" shows Adson's test performed to diagnose this condition. The presence of a cervical rib is not an absolute requirement for the development of TOS and it may occur in patients with muscular anomalies and following injury. Only patients with vascular TOS and severe neurogenic TOS are managed with surgery, not all patients. 

Thoracic outlet syndrome (TOS) is a neurovascular syndrome caused due to compression of the lower trunk of the brachial plexus and subclavian vessels in the thoracic outlet between the clavicles, the first rib, and scalene muscles. 

The causes of TOS vary and can include abrupt movements, hypertrophy of the neck musculature, and anatomical variations in which the brachial plexus roots pass-through this musculature, cervical rib, edema, pregnancy, repeated overhead motions, or abnormal posture.

Individuals with TOS typically experience upper limb pain, numbness, tingling, or weakness that is exacerbated by shoulder or neck movement. They may complain of pain during activities that include reaching overhead (eg, brushing the hair, holding a telephone to the ear, getting objects from a cabinet), overhead lifting, and prolonged typing or working at a computer, or driving. Sensory abnormalities involving T1 are commonly seen in neurogenic TOS.

It can be diagnosed with electrodiagnostic testing, imaging for identifying bony abnormalities, vascular anomalies, and vascular compression. The provocative tests for thoracic outlet syndrome include Adson's test, Wright's test, and Roos's test.

Several treatment options are available like physical therapy, interscalene injection of anesthetic agents, and steroids. Surgery is done in cases of vascular compression and failure of non-operative therapy.

Related Pearl: Thoracic outlet syndrome and its tests:

Thoracic outlet syndrome (TOS) is a neurovascular syndrome caused due to the compression of the lower trunk of brachial plexus (C8 and T1) and subclavian vessels in the thoracic outlet between the clavicle, the first rib, and scalene muscles.

Clinical features due to compression of:

  • Brachial plexus: Pain and paraesthesia along the ulnar aspect of the arm.
  • Subclavian vessels: Cyanosis, cold fingers, pallor and Raynaud's phenomenon.

Provocative tests: Adson's test, Halstead's maneuver, Wright's test, Roos test.

Adson’s test: The examiner locates the radial pulse while arm is held in extension, external rotation, and slight abduction. The patient is instructed to take a deep breath and turn head towards the test arm while extending the neck. This manoeuvre will tense the anterior and middle scalenes. If there is outlet obstruction, the radial pulse will get diminished or absent on that side. 

Halstead maneuver (reverse Adson's): The examiner palpates the radial pulse and applies downward traction on the tested extremity while the patient’s neck is hyperextended and rotated to the opposite side. Diminished or absent pulse indicates a positive test.

Wright’s hyperabduction test: The examiner palpates the radial pulse and hyper-abducts the arm. The patient takes a deep breath and may rotate or extend his neck for additional effect. Absence of pulse indicates a positive test.

Roos test: The patient abducts the shoulders to 90 degrees and flexes the elbow to 90 degrees. The patient is made to open and close the hand repeatedly for three minutes. The test is positive if the patient is unable to complete the test or experiences cramping, pain, numbness, on the affected side.

questions.text: You are evaluating a 17-year-old boy for Marfan's syndrome. You notice the following appearance of the chest as shown in the image below. This finding is called:
questions.solution:
The given image shows forward protrusion of the sternum and the adjacent costal cartilages. This finding is called pectus carinatum.

Pectus carinatum is also known as pigeon chest. It is seen in conditions such as Marfan’s syndrome, rickets, and childhood asthma.

Marfan's syndrome is an autosomal dominant connective tissue disorder caused by a mutation in the fibrillin-1 (FBN1) gene on the long arm of chromosome 15. Skeletal manifestations of Marfan's syndrome include:

  • Tall stature and long limbs; upper segment to lower segment ratio is reduced.
  • Pectus carinatum 
  • Pectus excavatum or cobbler chest or funnel chest 
  • Long and slender fingers (arachnodactyly)
  • Joint laxity 

The image given below shows the pectus excavatum, characterized by an increased hollowness in the lower part of the sternum.

 

The images below show two important signs seen in Marfan's syndrome: 

  • Image a shows positive wrist sign - the ability to join the thumb and fifth finger around the wrist
  • Image b shows positive thumb sign - the thumb tip extends from the palm of the hand in a closed fist.

 

Cardiovascular manifestations of Marfan's syndrome include mitral valve prolapse progressing to mitral regurgitation, aortic root dilation leading to aortic regurgitation, aortic dissection, and rupture. Ocular manifestations include ectopia lentis, where there is upward and temporal dislocation of the lens and myopia.

Other options: 

Option B: Harrison’s sulcus refers to the indrawing of ribs resulting in horizontal grooves along the lower border of the chest due to the pulling of the diaphragm on a weak chest wall. It occurs in chronic respiratory disease in childhood, childhood asthma, and rickets.

questions.text: A 35-year-old male patient presents to the emergency room with severe, upper abdominal pain that radiates to the back. The patient does not smoke or drink alcohol. Lab investigations reveal gross elevations in triglycerides and of the component shown in the image below. He gives a family history of abnormal lipid profiles. Which of the following is the likely defect in this patient?
questions.solution:
The given clinical vignette describes a case of acute pancreatitis. This patient's serum triglycerides are grossly elevated, and the image shows a schematic representation of a chylomicron which is elevated in familial chylomicronemia (type 1 dyslipidemia). This is caused due to lipoprotein lipase (LPL) deficiency, abnormal LPL, or apo C-II deficiency.

Lipoprotein lipase is required for the degradation of triglycerides in chylomicrons and VLDLs. Familial chylomicronemia follows an autosomal recessive pattern of inheritance. These patients show slow clearance of chylomicrons and VLDL (rather than increased production), and low levels of LDL and HDL. It is usually not associated with premature atherosclerosis. Patients usually present due to acute pancreatitis. Other clinical features include hepatosplenomegaly and eruptive/ pruritic xanthomas. 

Chylomicrons transport dietary lipids from the intestine to the peripheral tissues. They are synthesized in the intestine by assembling apo B-48 with lipids (mainly triacylglycerol). This is called a nascent chylomicron, which upon receiving apo C-II and apo E from HDL is remodeled into a mature chylomicron. Apo C-II activates lipoprotein lipase present on the endothelium. Lipoprotein lipase hydrolyzes the triacylglycerols into fatty acids and glycerol which are either used for storage or energy. Therefore, patients who are deficient in lipoprotein lipase or apo C-II (type I hyperlipoproteinemia) show increased levels of chylomicrons in the plasma after a fatty meal.

questions.text:
A 55-year-old obese male patient is being evaluated for abdominal pain after undergoing the procedure shown below. On examination, his vitals are as given below. Which of the following is the next step in the management of this patient?
Temperature 101°F
Pulse Rate 125/minute
Blood Pressure 100/70 mm Hg
Respiratory Rate 20/minute
SpO2 95% on Room air

choices.text: Obtain an abdominal CT scan with contrast
Obtain a tagged red cell study
Observe the patient for a few hours

questions.solution:
The above image shows the Roux-en-Y gastric bypass procedure. The given clinical scenario is suggestive of an anastomotic leak. The next best step in the management is an abdominal CT scan with contrast. 

Anastomotic leak is one of the common complications of Roux-en-Y bypass surgery. It is more common in gastrojejunostomy. It is one of the important causes of life-threatening complications and death. Patients usually present with fever, unexplained tachycardia and/or hypotension, and abdominal pain. The symptoms depend on the size of the leak, the location of the leak, and the degree of spread.

If an anastomotic leak is suspected, computed tomography should be obtained, which may show indirect evidence of a leak, such as pneumoperitoneum, extraluminal contrast, inflammatory stranding, fluid collections, and/or abscess. Contrast studies, such as an upper gastrointestinal series with gastrografin, may show the leak directly.

Management of the leak:

  • Broad-spectrum antibiotics should be started as soon as the leak is confirmed.
  • Percutaneous drainage can be carried out in a stable patient with contained collections.
  • If non-operative management is unsuccessful at controlling the leak, the patient is hemodynamically unstable, or diffuse intra-abdominal contamination is suspected, the patient has to be shifted to the operating room, and exploration, drainage, and anastomotic revision have to be done.

Other complications of the Roux-en-Y gastric bypass procedure are:

  • Stricture
  • Obstruction
  • Afferent and efferent loop syndrome
  • Internal hernia
  • Marginal ulcer
  • Dumping syndrome
  • Post-vagotomy diarrhea
  • Gastric stasis
  • Alkaline gastritis
  • Gallstones
  • Peptic ulcer

questions.text: A 39-year-old male patient who works at a smelter presented with headache, fever, sweating, muscle pain, joint pains, and chest tightness and discomfort. He had returned to work only that morning after taking a long weekend off for Holi. He was symptomatically managed, and his condition improved remarkably within a couple of days. Which of the following substances is most likely to be implicated in this scenario?
questions.solution:
The clinical scenario is suggestive of Monday morning fever (Smelter shakes/ Brass chills/ Metal fume fever), which is used to describe the symptoms associated with zinc poisoning.

Symptoms of metal fume fever occur 4–24 hours after exposure to zinc oxide fumes. It presents as an influenza-like illness with headache, fever, sweating, chest tightness and discomfort, and joint pains. Typically, symptoms appear after the weekend, thereby giving rise to the term ‘Monday morning fever’. Zinc toxicity resembles malarial chills. Exposure to zinc chloride ammunition bombs (hexite) has led to the development of fatal adult respiratory distress syndrome.

It has been shown that inhalation of zinc oxide fumes is associated with a dose-dependent marked inflammatory response in the lung even if clinical symptoms do not occur. The illness usually has a good prognosis, and the symptoms often improve towards the end of the working week as some short-term immunity from previous symptoms usually develops. The pathogenesis is not known but is thought to result from endogenous pyrogen release due to cell lysis.

Other metals that produce this condition may include copper, magnesium, iron, chromium, cadmium, nickel, manganese, mercury, cobalt, lead, antimony, silver and aluminum, etc.

Other options:

In acute poisoning with phosphorus, the vomitus and stools will be luminous in the dark. The stools may give rise to faint fumes, constituting the smoky stool syndrome.

  • Acute poisoning: 
    • Resembles cholera
    • Associated with garlicky odor
  • Chronic poisoning:
    • Raindrop pigmentation is seen on temples, eyelids, and neck
    • Aldrich-Mees' lines (transverse white striae on the fingernails)
    • Hyperkeratosis of palms and soles
    • Painful paresthesia of hands and feet
    • Red velvety appearance of the stomach
    • Blackfoot disease - a gangrenous condition affecting the extremities

questions.text: A 26-year-old female patient with a history of seizure disorder is brought to the emergency room with acute abdominal pain. The pain started a few hours ago and has been sudden, severe, and diffuse. She also complains of numbness and tingling in her lower extremities and difficulty falling asleep for the last few days. On examination, she has tachycardia. Physical examination reveals distension of the bladder and reddish urine. A diagnosis is established by measuring urinary porphyrins and urinary porphobilinogen, both of which are elevated. Her physician immediately stops one of the seizure medications she is taking. This drug's effect on which of these enzymes precipitated her condition?
questions.solution:
The clinical vignette describes a case of acute intermittent porphyria. The administration of barbiturates is contraindicated in acute intermittent porphyria as they induce the enzyme δ-aminolaevulinic (ALA)-synthase. This results in increased synthesis of porphyrins and precipitation of acute intermittent porphyria.

Acute intermittent porphyria is an autosomal dominant disorder.It occurs due to the deficiency of HMB synthase enzyme. The common precipitating factors include endogenous and exogenous steroids, porphyria precipitating drugs, alcohol ingestion, and low-calorie diets, usually instituted for weight loss.

  • Muscle weakness
  • Dysuria, and urinary retention
  • Peripheral neuropathy
  • Anxiety, insomnia, depression, disorientation,hallucinations, and paranoia can occur in acute attacks.
  • Seizures

Diagnosis: Increased ALA and PBG levels in plasma and urine, especially during acute attacks.

questions.text: A 55-year-old locomotive operator presents with complaints of worm-like swelling over his right leg. During clinical examination, a Brodie Trendelenburg test is performed. Which of the following statements is false regarding the test?

choices.text: A tourniquet can be used for occluding the saphenofemoral junction
Rapid filling  from above indicates saphenofemoral incompetence
Gradual filling  from below upwards indicates saphenopopliteal incompetence
Positive Brodie Trendelenburg test indicates a need for surgery

questions.solution:
The gradual filling of veins from below upwards indicates the perforator incompetence. Brodie Trendelenberg test is performed to test for the incompetence of the saphenofemoral valve and the communicating system.

1. Trendelenburg’s test - Lay the patient down and elevate the leg. Empty the vessels and tie a tourniquet below the SFJ. Ask the patient to stand up:

  • Trendelenburg’s test part ll - Here the tourniquet is not released. A gradual filling from below to upwards indicates perforator incompetence.
  • Trendelenburg’s test part l - Here the tourniquet is released. A rapid filling from above shows the saphenofemoral incompetence.

2. Morrisey’s cough impulse: the patient is asked to cough. A cough impulse at the saphenofemoral junction indicates SFJ incompetence.

3. Schwartz test: If a thrill is felt at SFJ on tapping over the incompetent vein, indicates SFJ incompetence.

4. Modified Perthes test: A tourniquet is tied below SFJ and the patient is asked to walk. An increase in pain and prominence of dilated veins indicate DVT.

5. Fegan’s method - Mark the places of excessive bulges within the varicosities. Ask the patient to lie down and empty the varicose vessels. Palpate along the marked area to look for gaps and pits in the deep fascia, which indicates perforator incompetence.

questions.text: A 15-year-old child presents with hair loss. The pattern of hair loss is shown in the image below. The hair pull test is negative in other sites. Physical examination also shows cervical lymphadenopathy. Which of the following is the best treatment for this patient's condition?
questions.solution:
The given image shows alopecia with multiple black dots which is suggestive of tinea capitis. It has to be treated with oral itraconazole.

Tinea capitis is a dermatophyte infection primarily occurring in children. Clinical features of tinea capitis are patchy hair loss, scaling, tender lymphadenopathy, and in severe cases, there might be pustules and crusting of the affected area.

The clinical variants of tinea capitis are:

  • Endothrix - a non-inflammatory type in which multiple black dots are present within the areas of alopecia. It is most commonly caused by T. tonsurans and T. violaceum.
  • Ectothrix - a mild inflammatory type in which single or multiple scaly patches with hair loss are seen.
  • Kerion - a severe inflammatory type that presents with an inflammatory mass with thick crusting and matting of hair with pus and sinus formation.
  • Favus - is characterized by the presence of yellowish, cup‐shaped crusts known as scutula that develop around hair follicles.

Other options - 

Option A and C  - Intralesional glucocorticoid and observation are applicable for alopecia aerata. It presents with patchy hair loss and the hair pull test is positive. Observation is also be applicable for telogen effluvium where again there is diffuse hair thinning and positive hair pull test. Both these conditions do not present with lymphadenopathy.

Option D - Minoxidil is used for the treatment of androgenic alopecia which presents with hair loss on the vertex and central region. Additionally, it is unlikely to present at such a young age or with lymphadenopathy.

questions.text: A 50-year-old man had a recent episode of syncope while putting on his tie over a tight collar. The episode was not preceded by a feeling of warmth or any prodromal symptoms. He did not have any convulsive actions nor did he have any neurological deficits. Vital signs are within normal limits. The physician runs several investigations and concludes that the syncope was due to pressure over his carotid baroreceptor. Which of the following represents the changes caused by the receptor responsible for his syncope?
questions.solution:
The given clinical vignette represents a case of reflex syncope due to carotid sinus stimulation. The carotid sinus baroreceptor causes decreased sympathetic and increased parasympathetic discharge to the heart. 

Baroreceptors are stretch receptors located in the heart and the adventitia of the blood vessels. They are of two types - carotid sinus and aortic arch receptors (high-pressure regions) and cardiopulmonary receptors (low-pressure regions). 

Afferents

  • Carotid sinus receptor – a branch of the glossopharyngeal nerve (IX CN) – the carotid sinus nerve (sinus nerve of Hering)
  • Aortic arch receptor – a branch of the vagus nerve (X CN) – aortic depressor nerve

Center for Reflex - Medulla (Nucleus Tractus solitarius)

Efferents- Sympathetic and parasympathetic neurons to heart and vasculature

They are  sensitive to mean arterial pressure. The threshold for excitation is 50-60 mmHg. They show maximal activity at around 180 mmHg. 

Carotid sinus reflex - Baroreceptors within the carotid sinus and aortic arch control blood pressure and heart rate. Pressure applied to the carotid sinus or an increase in blood pressure increases the baroreceptor firing rate and vagal activity, thereby slowing the heart rate and reducing the blood pressure. Baroreceptor stimulation, by distension of the structures they are located in, inhibits the tonic discharge of sympathetic nerves and excites the vagal(parasympathetic) innervation of the heart. Thus leading to:

  • Vasodilation and venodilation
  • Hypotension
  • Bradycardia(increased PR interval)
  • Decrease in cardiac output

Clinical presentation of carotid sinus reflex - an abrupt loss of consciousness after pressure is over carotid baroreceptor. No prodromal symptoms are seen.

questions.text: A 33-year-old patient with Hodgkin’s lymphoma is noted to have Pel Ebstein fever. Which of the following is an accurate description of the fever pattern expected in this patient?

choices.text: Temperature remains elevated above normal without touching the baseline and the fluctuation does not exceed 0.6°C
Fever lasting 3–10 days is followed by afebrile periods of 3–10 days
Temperature fluctuation exceeds 0.6°C , but without touching the baseline.
Fever lasts for 2–3 days followed by a remission lasting for 2 days and the fever reappears and continues for 2–3 days

questions.solution:
Fever lasting 3–10 days is followed by afebrile periods of 3–10 days is known as Pel Ebstein fever.

 

Continuous Fever 

The temperature remains elevated above normal without touching the baseline and the fluctuation does not exceed 0.6°C. This type of fever is seen in the cases of lobar pneumonia, infective endocarditis, enteric fever, etc.

In Remittent Fever, temperature fluctuations exceed 0.6°C, but without touching the baseline.

Relapsing Fever is characterized by several days of fever followed by several days of afebrile period and then the cycle repeats., e.g. Borrelia infection, rat bite fever.

Tertian fever occurs on the first and third day, e.g. Plasmodium vivax, ovale, falciparum.

Quartan fever occurs on the first and fourth day, e.g. Plasmodium malariae.

In Saddleback fever, which is seen in Dengue,  initially, fever lasts for 2–3 days followed by a remission lasting for 2 days and the fever reappears and continues for 2–3 days.

In the case of Cyclic neutropenia, Cyclic neutropenia accompanied by fever occurs every 21 days.

choices.text: BP following fluid bolus being stable at 94/64 mm Hg
Rising lactate levels on repeat lab testings

questions.solution:
The given clinical vignette describes a patient with extensive injuries following a road traffic accident. The patient has hypothermia and hypotension on admission. Laboratory investigations show evidence of metabolic acidosis and sepsis (pH and rising lactate), abnormal coagulation profile, and low hemoglobin. FAST scan shows evidence of bleeding from injuries in the liver and spleen. Abdominal x-ray shows free air under the diaphragm indicating hollow viscus perforation. This patient may require damage-control surgery performed in stages to correct the abnormalities above in his initial state. However, if the patient's blood pressure improves to >90/60 mm Hg, he needs to be re-evaluated as he may no longer be a candidate.

Damage control surgery is minimal intervention done to stabilize the patient and do the definite surgery later. It centers on coordinating staged operative interventions with periods of aggressive resuscitation to salvage trauma patients sustaining major injuries.

3 Phases  :

Phase I (Initial Exploration) -

This phase consists of an initial operative exploration to attain rapid control of active hemorrhage and contamination.

Phase II (Secondary Resuscitation) -

This phase focuses on secondary resuscitation to correct hypothermia, coagulopathy, and acidosis. 

Phase III (Definitive Operation) -

It consists of planned re-exploration and definitive repair of injuries. This phase typically occurs 48 to 72 hours following initial and after successful secondary resuscitation.

 

Related Pearl: Damage Control Surgery

Five stages of damage control surgery:

1. Patient selection
2. Control of hemorrhage and control of contamination
3. Resuscitation continued in the intensive care unit
4. Deﬁnitive surgery
5. Abdominal closure

Phases of Damage Control Surgery:

Phase 0: Identification of patient for damage control surgery in emergency room
Phase 1: Emergency laparotomy to stop bleeding and prevent contamination
Phase 2: ICU care for resuscitation
Phase 3: Re-laparotomy for definitive repair

Indications for damage control surgery:

Anatomical

  • Inability to achieve haemostasis
  • Complex abdominal injury, e.g. liver and pancreas
  • Combined vascular, solid and hollow organ injury, e.g. aortic or caval injury
  • Inaccessible major venous injury, e.g. retrohepatic vena cava
  • Demand for non-operative control of other injuries, e.g. fractured pelvis
  • Anticipated need for a time-consuming procedure

Physiological (decline of physiological reserve)

  • Temperature <34ºC
  • pH <7.2
  • Serum lactate >5 mmol/L (normal is <2.5 mmol/L)
  • Prothrombin time (PT) >16 s
  • Partial thromboplastin time (PTT) >60 s
  • Blood transfusion approaching 15 units
  • Systolic blood pressure <90 mmHg for >60 min

Environmental

  • Operating time >60 min
  • Inability to approximate the abdominal incision
  • Desire to reassess the intra-abdominal contents (directed relook)

questions.text: A 24-year-old design intern was brought to casualty by his colleagues with a history of acute onset euphoric excitement followed by weariness, headache, giddiness, and intense drowsiness. The pupils were bilaterally constricted, the face and lips cyanosed.  As per his friends, he had a substance abuse issue and often stayed at late-night parties. His vitals which were normal on arrival are recorded as follows after a short duration. PR-80bpm, RR-10/min, BP- 88/58mmHg. He gradually passes into a deep coma, with fixed pinpoint pupils, and the breathing pattern is as shown in the graph. Which of the following can cause symptoms as described?
questions.solution:
The clinical scenario showing the stage of euphoria, stupor, and narcosis with pinpoint pupils and Cheyne-Stokes breathing is suggestive of Morphine or Opioid toxicity.

Characteristics of opioid (morphine) toxicity:

  • Stage of Excitement 

Characterized by a euphoric feeling of well-being initially which is of short duration due to effects on the limbic system. The breath may smell of opium.

  • Stage of Stupor 

The stage of excitement is followed by weariness, headache, giddiness, heaviness in limbs, decreased sensibility, and increased sleepiness from which the patient can be aroused by applying external stimuli. The pupils are constricted, the face and lips cyanosed. The pulse and respiration are normal in this stage.

  • Stage of Narcosis 

The patient passes into a deep coma from which he cannot be aroused. The muscles are relaxed and the reflex absent. The pupils are constricted to pinpoint and unresponsive to light (due to the depression of supranuclear inhibition of the pupillary constrictor tone). The blood pressure falls and the pulse is weak. Decreased motility of the GIT occurs with constipation and anorexia. Emptying of the stomach is also delayed.

The breathing is slow and irregular and the respiratory rate may fall to 2 to 4 per minute. This results from a decreased response of the brainstem to carbon dioxide tension and is known as Cheyne Stokes Breathing. The temperature is decreased, and the skin cold and sweaty. Death usually occurs from asphyxia due to respiratory paralysis, which may be preceded by convulsions.

Note:

Miosis is not universally present from intoxication with every opioid; normal or even enlarged pupils have been documented secondary to diphenoxylate, meperidine, morphine, pentazocine, and propoxyphene toxicity. Opioid-induced acute lung injury, previously known as non-cardiogenic pulmonary edema, is an uncommon complication associated with heroin overdose. Black/ grayish postmortem lividity is seen in the case of opium poisoning.

Cocaine is a CNS stimulant. CNS stimulation (anxiety, hyperactivity), CVS overactivity(tachycardia, hypertension), and increased respiratory rate are seen in poisoning with cocaine causing sympathetic toxidrome.

The water-soluble form(-hydrochloride) can be injected or snorted. Tattoos may be made to cover the injection marks. Whilst another form (-sulphate), can be smoked. It gives a cracking sound when burnt

It inhibits the uptake of Dopamine, Norepinephrine and Serotonin. It hence presents with the action of these neurotransmitters

At lower doses-it produces confidence, alertness but at higher doses- it produces stereotyped behaviour, involuntary actions, paranoia. There is a transient euphoria, which makes the person crave for more. The hallucination of tactile type may occur with impaired judgement. There is a dose-dependent increase in heart rate and BP and may cause arrhythmias. It causes dilation of pupils and is associated with chills and perspiration. Ultimately, the patient goes into a stage of depression with loss of reflexes, paralysis of muscles, cardiorespiratory failure and coma.

Initial management involves the administration of activated charcoal and gastric lavage if it has been ingested.

Treatment involves the administration of benzodiazepines to control heart rate/seizures, propanolol to control cardiac arrhythmia and haloperidol to treat psychosis. Counselling needs to be done to avoid resist the urge for repetitive usage. 

The image shows Erythroxylum cocca. Cocaine is the principal alkaloid found in these plants.

Tetrahydrocannabinol is obtained from cannabis. Cannabis addiction is a chronic poisoning state resulting from continued use of the drug in any form and is characterized by anorexia, loss of weight, weakness, tremors, impotence, and moral deterioration.

The victim might become lethargic, apathetic, and disinterested to work and suffer from poor concentration. This is called Amotivational syndrome. In acute poisoning, few individuals may turn violent and go into a state called run amok.

The image shows cannabis plant.

Jimson weed (Datura stramonium) and angel’s trumpet (Datura candida).

All Datura species contain the anticholinergic alkaloids atropine, scopolamine, and hyoscyamine. Seeds or other parts of the plant can be ingested or smoked and produce delirium, hallucinations, and seizures along with other classic anticholinergic effects, such as mydriasis, tachycardia, dry mouth and skin, blurred vision, urinary retention, and hyperthermia. Gastric emptying is often delayed, and the small, plentiful seeds can become trapped among the gastrointestinal folds after ingestion; thus gastric decontamination can be an important therapy.

Physostigmine, a reversible acetylcholine esterase antagonist, is an effective treatment for severe anticholinergic poisoning.

questions.text: An international traveler wants to get vaccinated against typhoid. Which of the following is true when concerning the safety of the Ty21a vaccine?

choices.text: It can be given simultaneously with other live vaccines
It can be given to patients taking anti-bacterial drugs
It is efficacious in patients having acute diarrhoea
It can be given safely to HIV patients with CD4 <200 as long as they are asymptomatic

questions.solution:
Other live vaccines can be given simultaneously with the Ty21a typhoid vaccine. 

Ty21a is a live-attenuated oral vaccine for individuals ≥5 years of age.

  • The regimen is 1st, 3rd, and 5th day - 3 doses.
  • Repeat every 3 years for endemic areas, and every year for traveling individuals. 

Not recommended in:

  • Patients on antimitotic drugs and immunosuppressants
  • Acute febrile illness
  • Acute intestinal infestation
  • Congenital or acquired immunodeficiency

Ty21a vaccine can be administered in an HIV-positive asymptomatic patient as long as the CD4+ count is >200/ cubic mm. 

Proguanil and antibacterial drugs should be stopped from 3 days before to 3 days after the vaccine. 

The vaccine is unlikely to be effective if it is administered at the time of ongoing diarrhea.

Other available vaccines against typhoid include:

  • Inactivated whole cell vaccine
  • Injectable Vi polysaccharide vaccine
  • Vi-rEPA vaccine

questions.text: A 55-year-old male patient comes to the clinic with a history of hematuria. He has had rapid weight loss over the last few months. Physical examination reveals a cachectic male patient with a palpable abdominal renal mass. Work-up reveals a malignant renal mass extending into the infra-diaphragmatic inferior vena cava and invading its wall. You would classify this patient to be having a T stage of ____________
questions.solution:
The tumor is extending into the infra-diaphragmatic inferior vena cava which would generally mean it should be classified as T3b but the additional feature of vascular wall invasion of the IVC makes it T3c instead.

The clinical vignette describes a case of renal cell carcinoma. The classical triad of flank pain, hematuria, and a palpable abdominal renal mass is seen is a small subset of patients such as this patient.

  • T2a: Tumor confined to the kidney, >7 cm but < 10 cm
  • T2b: Tumor confined to the kidney, >10 cm

  • T3a: Tumor grossly extends into the renal vein or its segmental (muscle-containing) branches, or tumor invades perirenal and/or renal sinus fat but not beyond the Gerota's fascia

questions.text:
A 47-year-old male patient comes to the clinic with complaints of abdominal pain, intense pruritus, and weight loss for the past four months. Further evaluation reveals the laboratory findings:
Liver Function Tests Values Normal Range
Bilirubin (mg/dL) 6 0.2-2
Aspartate aminotransferase (U/L) 65 5-30
Alanine aminotransferase (U/L) 55 5-30
Alkaline phosphatase (U/L) 450 5-100

His MRCP appears as shown in the image. Which of the following is false about this patient's condition?

choices.text: c-ANCA is a commonly associated antibody in this condition
This patient should be evaluated for the presence of inflammatory bowel disease
Osteoporosis is a complication of advanced disease
The only curative option for this patient is liver transplantation

questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario is suggestive of primary sclerosing cholangitis and it is commonly associated with p-ANCA antibody, not c-ANCA.

Primary Sclerosing Cholangitis (PSC) is characterized by inflammatory strictures involving intrahepatic and extrahepatic biliary tree. It eventually leads to secondary biliary cirrhosis. It affects the age group 30–45 years with a male: female ratio of 2:1. It is associated with ulcerative colitis, Riedel’s thyroiditis, and retroperitoneal fibrosis. Patients may also develop cholangiocarcinoma. 

Clinical features of a patient with PSC include:

  • Intermittent jaundice
  • Fatigue
  • Weight loss
  • Pruritus
  • Abdominal pain

Liver function tests show a cholestatic pattern with an elevation of ALP and GGT and smaller rises in the aminotransferases. Bilirubin values may be variable. There is hypergammaglobulinemia.

Endoscopic retrograde cholangiography (ERC) is a gold standard in diagnosis and shows multiple dilatations and strictures (beading) of both intra and extrahepatic biliary tree.

Currently, there is no known effective medical therapy. Surgical management with resection of extrahepatic biliary tree and hepaticojejunostomy has shown reasonable effects. For patients with sclerosing cholangitis with advanced liver disease, liver transplantation is the only available option that is curative. A long-standing complication of this condition includes osteoporosis, cirrhosis, and cholangiocarcinoma.

The below image shows a cholangiogram of primary sclerosing cholangitis. There are diffuse strictures of intrahepatic and extrahepatic bile ducts with dilatation of the areas in between:

questions.text: A nephrectomy specimen of a 40-year-old man showed the following histological picture. The tumor cells are positive for CK7. Which of the following is incorrect regarding this type of renal carcinoma?

choices.text: Originates from intercalated cells of collecting duct

questions.solution:
The given image is of chromophobe renal cell carcinoma (RCC), which is most commonly associated with Birt-Hogg-Dubé syndrome and not von Hippel–Lindau (VHL) syndrome. VHL syndrome is associated with clear cell RCC.

Chromophobe carcinoma is composed of cells with prominent cell membranes and pale eosinophilic cytoplasm, usually with a halo around the nucleus. It shows large cells having a plant-cell-like appearance with a perinuclear halo. They are arranged in solid sheets with a concentration of the largest cells around blood vessels.

Chromophobe RCC cannot be histologically graded because of its innate nuclear atypia.

Cytogenetic examination of the tumor shows multiple chromosome losses and extreme hypodiploidy. The tumor is thought to grow from the intercalated cells of the collecting ducts. It has an excellent prognosis compared to clear cell and papillary cancers.

Close differential diagnoses are as follows:

  • Oncocytoma: Perinuclear halo is not seen.
  • Clear cell RCC: CK7 is diffusely positive in chromophobe RCC which distinguishes it from clear-cell RCC.

  • Poor prognosis
  • Originates from distal nephron
  • Associated with sickle cell anemia

Note: Sarcomatoid change can occur infrequently in all types of renal cell carcinoma (RCC) and is an ominous feature.

questions.text: A 23-year old African – American male who recently visited India, presented to the clinic with complaints of lower backache and passing dark red-colored urine. A few days back, he had come to the OPD with complaints of intermittent fever with fever spikes every third day with chills and rigors, abdominal pain, and easy fatiguability. After a peripheral blood examination, he was administered a combination-based antimicrobial therapy and he improved. Currently, he was subjected again to a peripheral blood smear examination, the findings of which are given below in the image. The most likely mode of inheritance of this disease would be?
questions.solution:
The given clinical condition is highly suggestive of G6PD deficiency (Glucose-6-phosphate dehydrogenase deficiency) and it is inherited as an X-linked recessive trait.

G6PD is an enzyme belonging to the hexose monophosphate shunt (HMP) pathway.

African – American race origin people are susceptible to develop G6PD deficiency. Past clinical history symptomatology is highly suggestive of Plasmodium infection leading to malaria, considering the tertian fever with chills and rigors, diagnosis being made using as a smear, and that he is a visitor to India. One of the common antimalarial drugs causing hemolysis in G6PD individuals is Primaquine. It causes oxidative stress, leading to hemolysis.

The peripheral smear shows characteristic "bite cells" or degmacytes or blister cells. In G6PD deficiency, uncontrolled oxidative stress causes hemoglobin to denature and form Heinz bodies. Bite cells result from the removal of Heinz bodies by macrophages in the spleen. Heinz bodies can be appreciated by Supravital staining – crystal violet.

Individuals with G6PD deficiency are prone to oxidative stress of RBC leading to hemolysis due to a decrease in NADPH and reduced glutathione.  Certain factors can provoke oxidative stress and these include:

  • Drugs – Sulfa drugs, antimalarials, Dapsone, Methylene Blue, Rasburicase, L- Dopa
  • Infection – Salmonella, E – Coli, Rickettsia infections
  • Favism – Fava Beans DKA

questions.text: A 65-year-old male patient comes to the clinic with a history of frank blood in urine for the last few weeks. He is a chronic smoker with a 30-pack-year smoking history and has a history of myocardial infarction two years ago. Workup with cystoscopy and biopsy shows the findings below in the bladder. He is started on a standard MVAC chemotherapy regimen for his condition which includes Anthracycline. Which of the following non-invasive imaging modalities may be beneficial in this patient, given his age and history of infarction?
questions.solution:
The given clinical complex describes a case of urothelial carcinoma of the bladder. This patient presents with grossly bloody urine with a 30-pack-year smoking history should be evaluated for bladder cancer with cystoscopy and biopsy. The histopathological image confirms the diagnosis. Anthracycline-based (DNA-intercalating) chemotherapy has been implicated in heart failure with significant morbidity and mortality.

Hence, all patients being started on this class of chemotherapeutic agents would benefit from baseline screening and monitoring with 3-D echocardiography, cardiac MRI, or nuclear imaging modalities such as a MUGA (multi-gated acquisition scan) which helps to evaluate the structural and dynamic properties of the heart.

MUGA scans are particularly beneficial in this setting because of the high-reproducibility of LVEF, but carry the disadvantage of repeated radiation exposure. 

MUGA Scan or radionucleotide ventriculography (RVG) or gated equilibrium radionucleotide angiography (ERNA). MUGA is a nuclear medicine imaging modality that helps to evaluate the structural and dynamic properties of the heart. Relies on radioactive isotopes administered and tagged to RBCs. Isotopes capture photons emitted by these isotopes using a gamma camera

Indications:

  1. Assessment of cardiac function in patients who are to receive chemotherapy, which may be potentially cardiotoxic
  2. Assessment of the orientation of the heart and great vessels in the chest
  3. Undiagnosed ischemic disease in the absence of myocardial infarction with hypodynamic wall motion
  4. Determination of systolic or diastolic dysfunction in undiagnosed congestive heart failure patients by viewing ventricular filling and contraction
  5. Evaluation of valve motion and associated ventricular function
  6. Evaluation of cardiac function in a patient with chronic obstructive pulmonary disease (COPD)
  7. Assessing for any intracardiac shunts

Other options:

Thallium scan (Option 2) is performed to detect reversible myocardial ischemia. Infarct appears as a cold spot on Thallium perfusion scanning. Reversible ischemia will be cold on exercise and normal on rest while irreversible infarct will reveal cold spot during rest as well as exercise. Hence thallium determines the reversibility of a lesion. 

Coronary angiogram (Option 1) is used to evaluate the vessel involved in cases of myocardial infarction and also to obtain cardiac filling pressures. Although it may be used to obtain information on this patient's ejection fraction, it is an invasive method.

Electrocardiogram (Option 4) is not sensitive or specific for cardiac changes in anthracycline toxicity.

questions.text:
During the internship, a senior resident asks you to plot partographs to monitor the progress of labour. Which of the following statements is/are incorrect regarding the partographic monitoring of a patient in labour?
  1. Fetal heart rate should be recorded every 1 hour
  2. The pulse should be recorded every 30 min
  3. Blood pressure should be recorded every 3 hours in a normal patient
  4. Uterine contractions should be recorded every 30 min
  5. Blood pressure should be recorded every 1 hour in a preeclampsia patient
questions.solution:
Assessment of progress of labor is best done by partograph. The fetal heart rate is recorded every 30 mins, not every 1 hour. Blood pressure should be monitored every 30 mins in patients with hypertensive disorders, not once an hour. 

Components of partograph:

  • Patient identification
  • Fetal heart rate recorded every 30 min
  • Pulse recorded every 30 min
  • Blood pressure and temperature recorded every 4 h
  • Uterine contractions recorded every 30 min
  • Oxytocin-dose and concentration
  • Urine analysis
  • Vaginal examination is done every 4 hours
  • State of membranes and color of the liquor
  • If patient has a hypertensive disorder or pre-eclampsia record BP every 30 minutes.

 

Related Pearl: Partograph

Partograph types:

WHO Modified Partograph (2000)

  • No latent phase
  • Vaginal examination: This should be done no less than every 4 hours to assess cervical dilatation, descent of the fetal head, and moulding of skull bones. More frequent examination is only undertaken if indicated.
  • Charting starts at 4 cm of cervical dilation.
  • Colour of liquor mentioned as C-clear, B-blood stained, M-meconium stained.
  • Moulding mentioned:
    • bones are separated and sutures can be easily felt - (0)
    • bones touching (1+)
    • bones overlapping but can be reduced(2+)
    • bones severely overlapping and irreducible ( 3+).
  • Alert line reflects the average rate of cervical dilation of the slowest quintile of term primigravidas, if dilation slows or ceases, the partograph plot will cross the alert line.
  • Alert line: at 4 cm dilation and expected dilation of 1 cm/hour.
  • Action line is 2–4 hours after the alert line, which prompts interventions to accelerate labor or perform cesarean delivery.
  • Higher rates of perinatal mortality are associated with delays of 4 hours or more after the alert line.
  • Contractions measured for a span of 10 min (duration noted) and measured every 30 min (1 square = half hour).
  • Pulse: record every 30 minutes and mark with a dot (•).
  • Blood pressure: record every 4 hours and mark with arrows, unless the patient has a hypertensive disorder or pre-eclampsia, in which case record every 30 minutes.
  • Temperature: record every 4 hours.

WHO Composite Partograph: It is same as modified except for it has latent phase and charting done at 3 cm.

WHO Simplified Partograph: WHO further modified the partograph for use by skilled attendants in health centers. This simplified partograph is colour coded.

  • The area to the left of the alert line in the cervicograph is coloured green, representing normal progress.
  • The area to the right of the action line is coloured red, indicating dangerously slow progress in labour.
  • The area in between the alert and action line is coloured amber, indicating the need for greater vigilance.

questions.text:
Read the following statements about different types of abortions and pick out the correct match from the options below.
  1. Vaginal bleeding, closed cervical os, USG shows fetal cardiac activity
  2. No vaginal bleeding, closed cervical os, USG reveals an empty sac
  3. Vaginal bleeding, dilated cervical os, POC felt above cervical os on pelvic exam
  4. History of vaginal bleeding/cramping and POC expulsion, closed cervical os

POC = Products of conception

USG = Ultrasonography
questions.solution:
A patient with a history of vaginal bleeding, open cervical os on examination, and products of conception felt above the cervical os is a likely case scenario for an inevitable abortion

Inevitable miscarriage

  • It is the clinical type of abortion where changes have progressed to a point from where continuation of pregnancy is impossible
  • Clinical features:
    • Increased vaginal bleeding
    • Colicky abdominal pain
    • Dilated cervical os through which the products of conception are felt
    • In the second trimester, patients may have rupture of membranes
  • Management:
    • Bleeding controlled with methergine 0.2 mg if the cervix is dilated and the size of the uterus is less than 12 weeks
    • Definitive management before 12 weeks is dilatation and evacuation followed by curettage. Suction evacuation may also be done
    • After 12 weeks, the uterine contraction should be augmented with oxytocin, and the fetus is allowed to expel completely. Manual removal of the placenta may be required with an ovum forceps

Other types of abortion

  • Complete: Vaginal bleeding is trace or absent, the POC are expelled en masse and the cervical os is closed. USG reveals empty uterine cavity.
  • Threatened: Slight brownish bleeding per vaginum, mild backache, closed cervical os on examination
  • Incomplete: Persistent vaginal bleeding, history of expulsion of a mass, patulous cervical os on exam which admits the tip of a finger
  • Missed: The fetus is dead and retained inside the uterus for a variable period. USG shows an empty sac early in the pregnancy or the absence of fetal cardiac activity and fetal movements.

questions.text:
As a radiology resident, you are asked to explain the radiological images given below to medical students with an appropriate clinical scenario. Some common clinical scenarios are listed below. Match the radiological images with their most likely clinical scenario.
  1. A 67-year-old male patient with chronic constipation
  2. A 46-year old woman with bloody diarrhea and weight loss for the last 2 years
  3. An 8-month-old infant who has recently been weaned off breast milk
  4. A 55-year-old male patient with weight loss, constipation and anemia
questions.solution:
A-1, B-3, C-4, D-2 is the correct option among those given.

A 67-year-old male patient with chronic constipation could develop sigmoid volvulus which is identified by the coffee bean sign on an x-ray shown in A. 

A 46-year old woman with bloody diarrhea and weight loss for the last 2 years has ulcerative colitis that could be complicated by toxic megacolon identified by grossly dilated loops of bowel seen in D. 

An 8-month-old infant who has recently been weaned off breast milk has intussusception that is identified by a target sign on ultrasound seen in B. 

A 55-year-old male patient with weight loss, constipation, and anemia have colon cancer that is identified by apple-core lesion seen on barium studies as in C.

 

Image A (X-ray):

Sigmoid volvulus, most likely to be seen in an elderly male with chronic constipation leading to intestinal obstruction

Volvulus is a condition in which the bowel becomes twisted on its mesenteric axis, resulting in partial or complete obstruction of the bowel and impairment of its blood supply. The condition usually affects the colon, most commonly the sigmoid colon. Less frequently, the right colon and terminal ileum (referred to as cecal volvulus), the cecum alone and rarely, the transverse colon can also be affected.

Patients may present as acute or subacute intestinal obstruction with a sudden onset of severe abdominal pain, vomiting, and obstipation. The abdomen is generally markedly distended and tympanitic.

Plain abdominal X Rays typically reveal a markedly dilated sigmoid colon resembling a bent inner tube, with the apex in the right upper quadrant- Coffee bean sign or Bent inner tube sign. An air-fluid level may be visualized in the dilated loop of colon, and the rectum usually does not contain gas.

A contrast enema typically shows the pathognomonic bird’s beak deformity or bird of prey sign at the point of obstruction.

CT is not required for diagnosis but demonstrates a characteristic mesenteric whorl.

Treatment of the sigmoid volvulus involves appropriate resuscitation, followed by nonoperative decompression in most cases. Resection can be done as an elective procedure.

 

Image B (Ultrasound):

Target sign of intussusception, most likely seen in infants during the weaning period due to hypertrophy of the Payer's patches

USG image depicts target sign in intussusception. The target sign of intestinal intussusception is also known as the doughnut sign or bull's eye sign. The appearance is generated by concentric alternating echogenic and hypoechogenic bands. The echogenic bands are formed by mucosa and muscularis whereas the submucosa is responsible for the hypoechoic bands.

Ultrasound signs include:

  • Target sign (Also known as the doughnut sign)
  • Pseudokidney sign: this is seen in the longitudinal section of the bowel. The edematous bowel resembles renal parenchyma and the mesentry which is dragged into the intussusception resembles renal hilum.
  • Crescent in a doughnut sign.

 

Image C (Barium study X-ray):

Apple core lesion of colon cancer, most likely seen in elderly males with weight loss, anemia and constipation

Apple core sign/ napkin ring sign - Describes a short segment irregular circumferential stricture of the large bowel that has abrupt “shouldered” margins resembling an apple core. The appearance is classically described on contrast enema studies and is almost always due to a stenosing annular colon carcinoma.

The appearance of the apple-core lesion of the colon also can be caused by other diseases :

  • Villous adenoma
  • Lymphoma with colonic involvement
  • Crohn's disease
  • Chronic ulcerative colitis
  • Ischaemic colitis
  • Chlamydia infection
  • Colonic tuberculosis
  • Helminthoma
  • Colonic amoebiasis
  • Colonic cytomegalovirus

 

Image D (X-ray):

Grossly dilated bowel loops of toxic megacolon, most likely seen in a middle-aged woman with blood diarrhea and weight loss

The X-ray image shows a dilated loop of the transverse colon. The history of bloody diarrhea since many days is highly suggestive of ulcerative colitis. Sudden onset of fever, abdominal pain with dilated loops of bowel in a patient of ulcerative colitis is highly suggestive of toxic megacolon.

A plain abdominal X-ray film may indicate the severity of ulcerative colitis in the acute setting and is particularly valuable in demonstrating the development of toxic megacolon.
Feces are present only in parts that are normal or only mildly inflamed. Mucosal islands can sometimes be seen. Small bowel loops in the right lower quadrant maybe a sign of severe disease.

questions.text: Which of the following statements is incorrect regarding the method for antibiotic susceptibility testing shown below?

choices.text: It is an example of disc diffusion method.
Minimum inhibitory concentration can be calculated by this method.
The inoculated organism is spread as a lawn culture on a solid medium like Mueller- Hinton Agar.
Zone of  inhibition around each disc shows antibiotic sensitivity.

questions.solution:
The image shown above is Kirby Bauer's disc diffusion method and Minimum inhibitory concentration(MIC) cannot be calculated by this method. 

Kirby Bauer’s disc diffusion method: The inoculated organism is grown as a lawn culture on a specific medium (Cation adjusted Mueller-Hinton Agar) and various antibiotic discs are placed on its surface. The zone of complete growth inhibition around each disc is measured. Each measurement is then interpreted to deduce to which antibiotics the organism is resistant or sensitive.

Laboratory testing for antibiotic sensitivity can be done by:

  • Diffusion tests: Kirby-Bauer disk diffusion method, Stokes disk diffusion method
  • Dilution tests: Broth dilution method, Agar dilution method
  • Diffusion and dilution method: E–test (Epsilometer)

Note: Minimum inhibitory concentration (MIC) is the lowest concentration of an antimicrobial agent that will inhibit the growth of the microorganism. Kirby–Bauer test cannot be used for calculating MIC.

questions.text: An elderly man presented with a sad mood, anhedonia, and decreased sleep. He further reports that he believes that everything is coming to an end. He feels his organs are rotting. Additionally, he believes he has a disease that can spread and kill all humans on the planet, and he attempted suicide to prevent this from happening. What is the diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The clinical vignette describes a case of Cotard syndrome.

Cotard syndrome or delire de negation or nihilistic delusion disorder: Patients complain that they have lost all their possessions, status, their entire being, and even their internal organs. They also feel that the world has reduced to nothingness. They might believe that they are dead and stop eating. It is commonly seen in patients with severe depression.

Other options:

Option A: In Fregoli Syndrome, the patients have a delusion that the familiar person can assume the appearance of (or disguised as) strangers. 

Option B: In Capgras syndrome (illusion des copies), the patients believe that their family members or other familiar people have been replaced by identical-looking imposters.

Option D: In Othello syndrome, the patient has delusions, which are predominantly jealousy and infidelity involving the spouse. This syndrome is named after the character in Shakespeare's play. 

Related Pearl: Types of delusions

THE TYPES OF DELUSIONS

Delusion of control

False belief that a person’s will, thoughts, or feelings are being controlled by external forces.

Delusion of grandeur or Megalomania 

Exaggerated conception of one’s importance, power, or identity.

Delusion of infidelity or morbid jealousy or Othello syndrome

False belief that one’s lover is unfaithful. Sometimes called pathological jealousy.

Delusion of love or erotomania

False belief that another person is in love with them. In De Clerambault syndrome, the woman believes that a man, frequently older and of higher status, is in love with her.

Delusion of misidentification 

Capgras syndrome: Belief that a familiar person has been replaced by an exact double i.e. an impostor.

Fregoli syndrome: Person holds a delusional belief that different people are in fact a single person who changes his or her appearance or is in disguise.

Nihilistic delusion 

False belief that oneself, others or the world, is non-existent or about to end. When nihilistic delusion is accompanied by ideas concerning bodily function failure e.g. putrefaction of intestine etc, it is called Cotard syndrome.

Delusion of infestation 

False belief that one is infested with small but visible organisms. As a monosymptomatic delusional disorder, this is called Ekbom syndrome. 

Delusion of persecution

The most common delusion. False belief of being harassed or persecuted.

Delusion of poverty

The person strongly believes they are financially incapacitated.

Delusion of reference

False belief that the behavior of others has a particular and unusual significance, usually of a negative nature. The person may falsely feel that others are talking about them (e.g. the people on television are talking to or about the person).  

Delusion of self-accusation

False feeling of remorse and guilt. Seen in depression with psychotic features.

Related Pearl: Disorders of thought and perception

DISORDERS OF THOUGHT

DISORDER OF STREAM OF THOUGHT

(A) Disorder of tempo

(i) Flight of Ideas

Continuous flow of rapid speech that jumps from topic to topic

  • "I like mangoes, the weather is nice, India is great"

(ii) Retardation of thinking

Slow speed of speech and a prolonged latent period before a response

  • "I went to the market (pause)......... the shop was closed"

(iii) Circumstantialities

Inclusion of irrelevant details and going on in a roundabout manner, but their thought ultimately reaches the answer

  • Doctor: "How did you get that bruise?"

  • Patient: "I woke up and had a cup of coffee, read the newspaper and went for a walk. It was a wonderful day in the park. I returned home and watched the TV. I took a nap in the afternoon after lunch. I slipped and fell in the bathroom. The fall gave me this bruise."

(iv) Clang associations

Jumping from one word to another irrelevant rhyming word

  • I am Sam...I like jam...I travel in a tram"

(B) Disorder of continuity

(i) Perseveration

Repetition of out of context words, phrases, or ideas beyond the point of relevance.

  • Q1. What's your name?: "Rahul"

  • Q2. Where are you from?: "Rahul"

  • Q3. How old are you?: "Rahul"

(ii) Thought blocking

A sudden disruption of thought or a break in the flow of ideas

  • "I went to the market (extreme silence)...................."

DISORDER OF FORM OF THOUGHT

(i) Tangentiality

In response to a question, the patient gives a reply that is appropriate to the general topic but does not answer the question exactly. The speech moves away from the actual answer.

  • Doctor: "Have you had any trouble sleeping lately?"
  • Patient: "I usually sleep in my bed, but now I'm sleeping on the sofa"

(ii) Derailment

A breakdown in both the logical connection between ideas and the overall sense of goal-directedness. The words make sentences, but the sentences do not make sense.

  • "Some people just don't understand why I had breakfast in America during the first world war"

(iii) Neologisms

Bringing in new words that do not exist.

  • The world is not 'gooder' for people like me"

(iv) Desultory thoughts

Speech is grammatically correct, however, sudden unrelated ideas force their way in from time to time.

  • My actual problem is that the people never understand me and my stomach feels like an empty bucket"

(v) Word salad

Using a mixture of unintelligible meaningless words and sentences

  • Tree bus rain food home car tiger"

DISORDER OF POSSESSION OF THOUGHT
A. Thought alienation

(i) Thought insertion

Thoughts are being inserted into the patient's mind and they recognize them as being foreign and coming from without any stimulus

  • "I have repeated thoughts of killing my neighbors and I believe aliens are putting these ideas into my head at night"

(ii) Thought withdrawal

Delusion that someone or something is removing from one's mind and the patient has no power over this.

  • "Lately, I am losing all my memories and I believe that the 'government agents' are stealing them when I go to sleep"

(iii) Thought broadcasting

Belief that one's thoughts are quietly escaping from one's mind and that other people might be able to access them and hear or see them.

  • "I believe my exact thoughts appear on the TV and the internet and I think I can broadcast them globally" 

(iv) Thought echo

Patient hears the 'echo' of his own thoughts in the form of a voice after he has made the thought.

  • "I thought of making a sandwich in the morning and surprisingly a voice, from nowhere, told me to make a sandwich out loud" 

 B. Obsessions and Compulsions

1. Obsessions

Recurrent and persistent thoughts, impulses. or images that cause distress to oneself.

  • Fear of dirt or contamination
  • Fear of becoming ill
  • Constant thoughts of a certain number
  • Need for symmetry or exactness
  • Worry about whether something has been done "right"
  • Forbidden sexual or religious thoughts

2. Compulsions

Repetitive behaviors or actions that the person feels driven to perform in response to an obsession

  • Washing hands
  • Blinking eyes
  • Counting items, such as currency
  • Checking to see if doors are locked
  • Arranging items in a certain way
  • Requiring constant approval from people around them

 
 DISORDER OF CONTENT OF THOUGHT

(i) Phobias

Persistent fear of an object or situation, typically disproportional to the actual danger posed, in which the sufferer goes to great lengths in avoiding it

  • Arachnophobia - fear of spider
  • Barophobia - fear of gravity
  • Cynophobia - fear of dogs
  • Hemophobia - fear of blood
  • Nosocomephobia - fear of hospitals

(ii) Religious preoccupations

Thoughts involving religious themes or subject matter.

  • "I get instructions from God on how to make my country great"

(iii) Ideas of hopelessness

Thoughts of complete despair where the patient strongly believes that the circumstances will never get better for him.

  • "I am never going to pass my final exams, no matter how hard I study"

(iv) Antisocial urges

Thoughts of indulging in some behaviors or actions that harm or lack consideration for the well being of others.

  • "I have these urges to go rob a bank or blackmail my neighbors for their money"

(v) Delusions

False beliefs that are strongly held and unchangeable in the face of refuting evidence and that are not consistent with the person's educational, social and cultural background.

The three main criteria for a belief to be considered a delusion are:

  • Certainty (held with complete confidence)
  • Incorrigibility (not changeable by proof to the contrary)
  • Impossibility or falsity of content (implausible, bizarre or patently untrue)
 DISORDERS OF PERCEPTIONS

  • Illusion: Misinterpretation of real external stimuli.

  • Hallucination: False sensory perception, externally.

  • Pseudohallucination: False sensory perception from within and having an insight.

  • Depersonalization: Feeling as if one is disconnected from reality, feeling detached from one's own thoughts and one's own physical body.

    "I sometimes drift into a dream-like state where I lose contact with my own self"

  • Derealization: Alteration in the perception or experience of the external world so that it seems unreal.

    "The world and everything around is nothing but just a dream"

questions.text: A 25-year-old woman at the onset of labor is wheeled into the CHC. On examination, multiple painful vesicles are present on the labia and on probing into history reveals she has had a burning sensation in the genital area for the past few days. The close-up view of the lesions is as in the image below. What is the management protocol to be followed for this patient?

choices.text: Deliver vaginally and administer the newborn with prophylactic acyclovir
Administer IM benzyl-penicillin to the mother and proceed with vaginal delivery
Deliver the baby by caesarean section
Proceed with vacuum or forceps delivery

questions.solution:
The lesions suggest genital herpes and women who present with these lesions at the onset of labor should be delivered by cesarean section to prevent neonatal herpes.

All pregnant women should be asked about the history of genital herpes and looked for herpetic lesions on examination. Pregnant women who have the first episode of genital herpes or severe recurrent herpes can be treated with oral acyclovir.

Pregnant women who do not have any prodrome or signs and symptoms of genital herpes can deliver vaginally.

Related Pearl: Syndromic Management of Sexually Transmitted Infections

Partner Management when asymptomatic is not required for Gardenella vaginalis, Candida and Herpes infections.

Related Pearl: Indications & contraindications for induction of labor

Indications:
  • Uncontrolled maternal diabetes mellitus
  • Gestational hypertension
  • Pre-eclampsia
  • Post-term pregnancy
  • Abruption placentae
  • Premature rupture of membranes
  • Rh-isoimmunization
  • Intra-uterine growth restriction (IUGR)
  • Intra-uterine death (IUD)
  • Oligohydramnios
Contraindications:
  • Contracted/distorted pelvis and cephalopelvic disproportion
  • Placenta previa or vasa previa
  • Active genital herpes
  • Pelvic tumor & carcinoma cervix
  • Transverse lie or footling breech
  • Appreciable macrosomia
  • Severe hydrocephalus
  • Umbilical cord prolapse
  • High-risk pregnancy with fetal compromise
  • Previous classical cesarean or hysterotomy
  • Previous history of uterine rupture
  • Pelvic surgeries like vesicovaginal fistula/rectovaginal fistula/pelvic floor repair (third or fourth-degree perineal tears repair)
  • Previous 3 or more lower transverse cesarian sections.

questions.text: A 25-year-old female patient with major depressive disorder on fluoxetine complains of sexual dysfunction. She is a smoker and her medical history includes bulimia nervosa and diabetes mellitus. Her physician plans to stop fluoxetine and switch to bupropion, due to its low incidence of sexual side effects. However, which of the following could be a reason to avoid bupropion in this patient?
questions.solution:
Bupropion is associated with an increased risk of seizures in patients with bulimia nervosa or anorexia nervosa. For this reason, bupropion is contraindicated in these patients.

Selective serotonin reuptake inhibitors (SSRIs), such as fluoxetine are the first-line management of the major depressive disorder. The most common adverse effect of SSRIs is sexual dysfunction. Among the second-line drugs, bupropion has a low incidence of sexual side effects. But, bupropion increases the risk of seizures in patients with bulimia nervosa.

Buproprion is an atypical antidepressant that inhibits the reuptake of norepinephrine and dopamine. It is also used for the treatment of attention deficit hyperkinetic disorder, obesity, smoking dependence, and peripheral neuropathy.

Buproprion is the most anxiogenic antidepressant. Adverse effects of bupropion include stimulant side effects like tachycardia, insomnia, headache, and seizures in anorexic/bulimic patients. It decreases the risk of sexual dysfunction and weight gain compared to other antidepressants.

Atypical anti-depressants such as mirtazapine and bupropion do not cause sexual dysfunction.

Other options:

Option A: A history of smoking would further prompt the use of bupropion in this patient because it aids in smoking cessation.

Options C and D: Diabetes mellitus and age are not contraindications for the use of bupropion.

questions.text: A 30-year-old female patient presents with episodic headaches, sweating, and palpitations. She has no shortness of breath or chest pain. Her blood pressure was recorded as 167/110 mmHg and lab investigations revealed elevated plasma metanephrines. An adrenal mass was seen on an abdominal CT scan and a biopsy confirms the diagnosis. Which clinical feature would you not expect to see in this patient?
questions.solution:
The clinical vignette with a patient having the given symptoms with elevated plasma metanephrines, and an adrenal mass is suggestive of a diagnosis of pheochromocytoma. Polyuria (not oliguria) is an expected clinical finding.

Pheochromocytoma is a catecholamine-secreting tumor derived from the chromaffin cells of the adrenal medulla. 

Clinical features of pheochromocytoma are due to the autonomic effects of excess epinephrine and norepinephrine. 

  • Weight loss (option A) is due to the increase in catecholamines which increase basal metabolism.
  • Pallor (option B) is due to alpha 1-mediated vasoconstriction. 
  • Abdominal pain (option C) with nausea and vomiting is commonly seen.

Diagnosis of pheochromocytoma requires biochemical testing followed by imaging.

  • Urinary and plasma levels of catecholamines and metanephrines 
  • MRI is the investigation of choice for localizing the tumor 
  • MIBG Scintigraphy and PET Scans like Ga- DOTATE, DOPA- or FDG- PET can be used for extra-adrenal tumors and metastases

Treatment of pheochromocytoma:

Surgical resection of the tumor is the definitive treatment. Preoperatively, an alpha-receptor blocker (phenoxybenzamine) is given to control the effects produced by excess catecholamines. Beta-blockers are used to control tachycardia after adequate alpha blockade is achieved. This is to prevent unrestricted alpha-mediated vasoconstriction. Following surgery, lifelong yearly follow-ups should be done.

Related Pearl: Clinical features of Pheochromocytoma (By frequency of occurrence)

  • Classical triad of symptoms:
    • Headaches – most common symptom
    • Profuse sweating
    • Palpitations and tachycardia
  • Hypertension (sustained or intermittent) – most common sign
  • Anxiety, panic attacks
  • Hyperglycemia
  • Hypercalcemia
  • Pallor - due to alpha-1 mediated vasoconstriction
  • Polyuria and polydipsia 
  • Orthostatic hypotension
  • Dilated cardiomyopathy
  • Erythrocytosis, high hematocrit (hemoconcentration)
  • Constipation
  • Abdominal pain
  • Weakness
  • Weight loss
  • Nausea

questions.text: A 35-year-old male presents with a deformed eye. He was treated for a corneal ulcer 2 weeks back which took a long time to heal despite antibiotics treatment. His physical examination is remarkable for findings shown in the image. Which of the following options represents the layers involved by the disease seen in this patient?
questions.solution:
The clinical vignette is suggestive of a diagnosis of anterior staphyloma and it commonly involves the uveal tissue with the cornea.

Staphyloma (a bunch of grapes) is a clinical condition characterized by ectasia of the outer coats (cornea, or sclera or both) of the eye, with the involvement of the uveal tissue. The basic underlying pathology is the weakening of the eyewall, which can be caused by many inflammatory or degenerative diseases involving these structures.

Types of staphyloma

  • Anterior staphyloma: an ectasia of the pseudocornea, which results from the total sloughing of the cornea. It is lined internally by the iris and externally, by the newly formed epithelium.
  • Intercalary staphyloma: This is located at the limbus and is lined by the root of the iris.
  • Ciliary staphyloma: Ectasia of weak sclera lined by the ciliary body. This affects the ciliary zone that includes the region up to 8 mm behind the limbus.
  • Equatorial staphyloma: This occurs at the equatorial region up to 14 mm behind the limbus of the eye.
  • Posterior staphyloma: This affects the posterior pole of the eye.

Note: 

  •  The most common cause for anterior staphyloma is sloughing corneal ulcer.
  •  The most common cause for posterior staphyloma is degenerative high axial myopia.

Image showing the types of staphyloma.

questions.text: A 71-year-old man presents with a cough and shortness of breath. He does not complain of fever or sputum production. He quit smoking for the past several years, before which he had smoked half a pack of cigarettes for 5 years. Vital signs are within normal limits. Physical examination is remarkable for crepitations in bilateral lung fields. The physician conducts a pulmonary function screening test in his office, and the patient generates the maximum expiratory flow-volume curve shown to the right of the normal curve in the diagram below. Which of the following results most likely represents the pulmonary function testing values (as a percentage of normal) in this patient?
questions.solution:
The graph in the question shows a restrictive pattern on the flow-volume curve. The most likely pulmonary function testing findings in a person with restrictive lung disease is a normal or increased FEV1/FVC and a decreased FVC.

 

 

FVC (Forced vital capacity) is the maximum volume of air that can be expired forcefully after a maximal inspiration. It is decreased in both restrictive and obstructive diseases

FEV1 (Forced expiratory volume in first second) is the fraction of forced vital capacity expired during the first second of forced expiration.

Pulmonary function tests can be used to differentiate between restrictive and obstructive diseases.

  • In obstructive lung diseases, the obstruction in the airways reduces both FEV1 and FVC. However, the decrease in FEV1 is greater than the reduction in FVC. As a result, the ratio FEV1/FVC also decreases. The total lung capacity is normal or elevated.
    Ex: Asthma, COPD, Bronchiectasis.

 

  • In restrictive diseases the FVC is reduced. However, the patient's airflow is fast initially, which soon levels out with the FVC. As a result, the FEV1/FVC is normal or increased. The total lung capacity is reduced.
    Ex: Pulmonary fibrosis, pneumoconiosis, sarcoidosis.
