questions.text:
A 45-year-old female patient presents with weakness and dizziness. She has low blood pressure, but no diarrhea or fever. She has a history of vitiligo and Hashimoto's thyroiditis. Her examination findings and investigations are given below. Which of the following is the reason for her adrenal insufficiency?

Lab results show: 

Cortisol level- low, ACTH level- raised

Serum Electrolytes Values Normal Range
Sodium (mmol/L)  130  135-145 
Chloride (mmol/L)  100 95-105
Potassium (mmol/L)  5.3 3.5-5 
Bicarbonate (mmol/L)  20 18-22
questions.solution:
This patient with weakness, low blood pressure, hyperpigmentation, hyponatremia, hyperkalemia, and raised ACTH levels with decreased cortisol levels points to a diagnosis of primary adrenal insufficiency. The most common cause of primary adrenal insufficiency is autoimmune adrenal insufficiency, especially in this patient as she has other underlying autoimmune conditions such as Hashimoto's thyroiditis and vitiligo. 

Primary adrenal insufficiency Secondary adrenal insufficiency
Decreased cortisol and elevated ACTH Decreased cortisol and ACTCH
Hyperpigmentation present Hyperpigmentation absent
Causes: Autoimmune, TB, adrenal metastasis Causes: Chronic glucocorticoid therapy, pituitary lesions


Primary adrenal insufficiency:

The common causes of Addison’s disease are:

  • Tuberculosis in developing countries
  • Autoimmune (Idiopathic atrophy) in developed countries
  • Metastasis to adrenal glands

Clinical features - lethargy, weight loss, nausea/vomiting, hyperpigmentation in an exposed area, postural hypotension, hyponatremia, hyperkalemia, eosinophilia, and hypoglycemia may be seen.

Diagnosis - Cosyntropin stimulation test, plasma ACTH and cortisol levels, plasma renin and aldosterone levels.

Treatment - glucocorticoid, mineralocorticoid, and androgen replacement therapy.

Other options:

Options B and D - are both causes of secondary adrenal insufficiency. 

Option C - Adrenal metastasis is rare compared to autoimmune causes. Additionally, the metastatic disease will have signs of the primary tumor, weight loss, etc.

Related Pearl: Causes of Adrenocortical Insufficiency

Primary adrenal insufficiency:

  • Anatomical destruction of gland
  • Autoimmune (Addison's disease)
  • Isolated autoimmune adrenalitis (polygenic)
  • Infections - HIV, tuberculosis, fungi
  • Surgical removal
  • Acute hemorrhagic necrosis (Waterhouse-Friderichsen syndrome)
  • Amyloidosis, sarcoidosis, hemochromatosis
  • Metastatic carcinoma
  • Cytotoxic agents – mitotane
  • Enzyme inhibitors – metyrapone, ketoconazole
  • Congenital adrenal hypoplasia
  • Autoimmune polyendocrinopathy syndrome type 1 (AIRE1 gene on 21q22)
  • Autoimmune polyendocrinopathy syndrome type 2 (polygenic)
  • X-linked adrenal hypoplasia (DAX1 gene on Xp21)
  • Adrenoleukodystrophy (ALD gene on Xq28)

Secondary adrenal insufficiency:

Hypopituitarism due to hypothalamic or pituitary disease

  • Neoplasm
  • Infiltration (sarcoidosis)
  • Infection (tuberculosis, pyogenic, fungal)

Suppression of HPA axis

  • By endogenous steroids from tumor
  • By exogenous steroids

questions.text: A 45-year-old man sustained a closed, diaphyseal tibial fracture of the left leg in a road traffic accident. As he had no distal neurovascular deficits or any open wound, he was managed conservatively with a cast for 6 weeks. After this period, he noticed a significant reduction in the girth of his left calf compared to the right. What is the type of atrophy likely to be responsible for this?
questions.solution:
Disuse atrophy due to decreased workload is seen in this scenario. Disuse atrophy occurs in a limb that has been immobilized following a fracture.

Physiologic atrophy:

  • Loss of hormonal stimulation: Atrophy of the uterus after parturition; atrophy of the endometrium, vaginal epithelium, and breast after menopause.
  • During embryonic development: Certain structures, like the notochord and thyroglossal duct, undergo atrophy during fetal development.

Pathologic atrophy:

  • Disuse Atrophy (decreased workload): e.g., atrophy in a limb that has been immobilized following a fracture
  • Denervation atrophy (loss of nerve supply): e.g., skeletal muscle atrophy following nerve injury
  • Ischemic atrophy: e.g., senile atrophy of the brain and heart due to atherosclerosis
  • Inadequate nutrition: e.g., severe muscle wasting in marasmus
  • Pressure atrophy: e.g., atrophy of surrounding uninvolved tissues caused by an enlarging benign tumor 

Mechanisms of atrophy:

  • Decreased protein synthesis because of decreased metabolic activity
  • Increased destruction of proteins by the ubiquitin-proteasome pathway

questions.text: A 32-year-old primigravida at 30 weeks of gestation comes with complaints of absent fetal movements over the last week. Examination shows absent fetal heart sounds. Ultrasonographic examination shows overlapping of skull bones and no fetal movements. Which of the following is false about this likely condition?

choices.text: Robert's sign may be seen as early as 12 hours
Spalding's sign may be seen on USG
Spontaneous expulsion rarely occurs in these patients and induction is required
Infection by gas-forming organisms is likely after rupture of membranes

questions.solution:
The given clinical vignette describes a case of intrauterine fetal death (absent fetal heart sounds, no fetal movements and Spalding's sign on ultrasound). The false statement is spontaneous expulsion is rare and induction is required.

It is an antepartum death occurring beyond the period of viability. In most of these cases, spontaneous expulsion occurs within 10-14 days. 

The causes of intrauterine fetal death are given below -

  • Maternal - Hypertensive disorders in pregnancy, diabetes in pregnancy, maternal infections, APLA, hyperpyrexia, thrombophilias, abnormal labour, post-term pregnancy, SLE
  • Fetal - Chromosomal abnormalities, structural abnormalities, infections, Rh-incompatibility, non-immune hydrops, growth restriction
  • Placental - Antepartum hemorrhage, cord accident, twin transfusion syndrome, placental insufficiency
  • Iatrogenic - External cephalic version, drugs
  • Idiopathic 

Sonographically, fetal heartbeat and fetal movements are absent. Overlapping of skull bones irregularly on one another known as Spalding's sign can be seen. Also, a gas shadow in the chambers of the fetal heart and great vessels called Robert's sign is seen as early as 12 hours.

Complications like infection following rupture of membranes with gas-forming organisms such as Clostridium welchii, and blood coagulation disorders may occur.

Management includes early intervention for psychological issues, signs of uterine infection, prolonged retention beyond two weeks, and falling fibrinogen levels. The first-line choice for induction of labor in such cases is a combination of mifepristone and prostaglandins, although misoprostol and oxytocin infusion can also be utilised effectively.

Note: The period of viability is when the fetus is capable of independent existence. The WHO defines it to be 24 weeks while the Indian definition is 28 weeks.

Related Pearl: Radiological features of Intrauterine Death

  • Robert's sign - The presence of a gas shadow within the chambers of the heart or the greater vessels like aorta, in cases of foetal death in utero
  • Spalding sign - Loss of alignment and over-riding of bones of cranial vault and overlapping of skull bones due to shrinkage of brain after death
  • Deuel’s halo sign – Increased pericranial fat
  • Hyperflexion of spine and crowding of ribs

questions.text: A 40-year-old female graduate student had an excruciating headache. When she looked in the mirror, she noticed that her right eyelid was drooping; when she lifted the eyelid, she saw that her eyeball was looking down and out and her pupil was dilated. She complained of both blurred and double vision. A magnetic resonance angiogram shows an aneurysm of the cerebral arterial circle. Which artery gives rise to the offending aneurysm?
questions.solution:
The clinical vignette with ptosis, down and out eyes with a dilated pupil describes a case of oculomotor nerve palsy secondary to a posterior communicating artery(PCom) aneurysm which is marked as '1' on the circle of Willis

The oculomotor nerve [III] provides motor fibers to the ocular and extra-ocular muscles. Third nerve palsy involving the nucleus of the oculomotor nerve [III] spares the pupil and is painless. The autonomic fibers of the Edinger–Westphal nucleus, which pass through the ciliary ganglion supply the pupillary reflexes. Pressure on the nerve from a posterior communicating artery aneurysm is a common cause of third nerve palsy. It leads to a predominance of the loss of pupillary function over general function. The aneurysm was imaged with an angiogram. Imaging modalities include CT, MRI, and digital subtraction angiogram. 

Circle of Willis or circulus arteriosus: Large arterial anastomosis that unites the internal carotid and vertebrobasilar systems. It lies in the subarachnoid space within the basal cisterns that surround the optic chiasma and infundibulum.

The anterior cerebral arteries are derived from the internal carotid arteries and are linked by a small anterior communicating artery.

Posteriorly, the two posterior cerebral arteries are formed by the division of the basilar artery. They are joined to the ipsilateral internal carotid artery by a posterior communicating artery.

Oculomotor Nerve - 

Clinical features of CN III palsy - dilated pupil, down and out eyes, ptosis, loss of normal pupillary reflex, 

The course of oculomotor nerve -  Emerges from the midbrain and passes along the lateral dural wall of the cavernous sinus and divides into two branches -superior and inferior. The two divisions enter the orbit through the superior orbital fissure. The superior division of the oculomotor runs above the optic nerve to supply superior rectus and levator palpebrae superioris. The inferior division of the oculomotor nerve divides into medial, central, and lateral branches. The medial branch supplies the medial rectus; the central branch supplies the inferior rectus; the lateral branch supplies the inferior oblique and also provides parasympathetic fibers to sphincter pupillae and the ciliary muscle .

Causes of injury -

  1. Ischemia - most common etiology in adults. Pathology is microvascular and it is seen in diabetes and hypertension.
  2. Trauma - associated with a skull fracture or loss of consciousness.
  3. Migraine - ophthalmoplegic migraine can affect the third nerve.

questions.text: An elderly diabetic patient presents with a black, foul-smelling nasal discharge and suppuration of the eye with visual impairment. On examination, there is black eschar on the nasal mucosa. On Sabouraud agar, the colonies formed are grey-white with thick cottony, fluffy surfaces. What is the finding seen on microscopic examination?

choices.text: Broad, ribbon-like hyphae with irregular branching
Spherical yeast with a thick capsule on India ink staining
Oval, budding yeast cells with germ tube formation

questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario is suggestive of mucormycosis. Under the microscope, it is seen as broad, ribbon-like aseptate hyphae with irregular branching. 

Mucormycosis (zygomycosis) is an opportunistic infection caused by species of rhizopus, mucor, and absidia. Among them, the most prevalent species are Rhizopus oryzae and R. delemar. It is seen in patients with diabetes mellitus, leukemias, lymphomas, long-term corticosteroid use, severe burns, and immunodeficiencies.

The common clinical form is rhino-orbital-cerebral mucormycosis in which there is an invasion of the blood vessels in the nasal cavity, eyes, and brain causing thrombosis, infarction, and necrosis. They invade the tissues of patients, enter the blood vessels and proliferate in the walls of blood vessels, particularly paranasal sinuses and orbit. The blackish discoloration is due to arterial and venous thrombosis leading to gangrene.

Diagnosis- They can be stained with 10% potassium hydroxide and can be cultured. On Sabouraud agar at 30-37°C, they appear as grey-white colonies with a thick cottony, fluffy surface. Under the microscope, they appear as nonseptate or sparsely septate, irregularly branched broad hyphae with aerial sporangiophores which end in a sporangium (a sac containing spores). 

Treatment: Surgical debridement and amphotericin B administration.

The below image shows broad aseptate and irregularly branched hyphae seen in mucormycosis.

Other options:

Option A-Long conidiophores with terminal vesicles are seen with aspergillus 

Option C- Spherical budding yeast surrounded by a thick capsule on India ink stain is seen with cryptococcus neoformans

Option D- Oval, budding yeast cells with germ tube formation is seen with candida.

Related Pearl: Classification of fungus based on morphology

Fungi are classified into 4 types based on their morphology:

  • Yeast
  • Yeast-like
  • Molds
  • Dimorphic fungi

Yeast:

  • Unicellular fungi
  • Reproduces by budding
  • Oval to round forms
  • Example: Cryptococcus, Saccharomyces.

 

Yeast like:

  • Unicellular fungi
  • Reproduces by budding or binary fission
  • Spherical or oval forms
  • Pseudohyphae may be seen.
  • Example: Candida, Malassezia furfur.

 

Molds/filamentous fungi:

  • Have hyphae which may be septate or aseptate
  • Aseptate or coenocytic hyphae – Rhizopus, mucor, Lichtheimia.
  • Septate hyphae – Penicillium, Dermatophytes, Aspergillus, fusarium.

 

Dimorphic fungi

  • Filamentous forms in the culture at 220C – 250C and in the environment.
  • Yeast form in the culture at 370C and in tissues.
  • Examples – Histoplasma capsulatum, Blastomyces dermatitidis, Coccidioides immitis, Paracoccidioides brasiliensis, Talaromyces marneffei, Sporothrix schenckii.

A 63-year-old male patient complains of intermittent epigastric pain that is worse with food intake for 5 months. Physical examination is remarkable for mild epigastric tenderness. Endoscopy reveals gastric ulcers and urease breath test is positive. Which of the following is not a recommended treatment regimen for eradicating the causative organism?

PPI- Proton pump inhibitor
questions.solution:
PPI + amoxicillin + nitroimidazole is not a recommended treatment regimen for eradicating the causative organism in this patient.

The clinical vignette with epigastric pain, melena, weight loss, and a positive urease breath test is suggestive of a gastric ulcer due to H. pylori. Among the options listed PPI + amoxicillin + nitroimidazole is not a standard treatment regimen. questions.text:
A 65-year-old male patient comes to the clinic for a follow-up visit. He was admitted to the hospital one month ago with acute decompensated heart failure. An echocardiogram revealed an ejection fraction of 35% and he was discharged on medication. He now comes to the clinic with persistent symptoms of breathlessness and swelling in his feet. He is unable to walk more than 100m without symptoms and is comfortable only at rest. The cardiologist decides to add another drug to his regimen. The patient currently takes drugs with the following mechanism of action -
  1. A drug that acts by inhibiting the luminal Na-K-Cl cotransporter in the thick ascending limb of the loop of Henle
  2. A pro-drug that upon activation blocks the action of neprilysin and prevents the breakdown of natriuretic peptides
  3. A drug that acts on the RAAS system and blocks the angiotensin-II receptor
  4. A drug that binds to the receptors at the aldosterone-dependent Na-K exchange sites in the DCT of the nephron

What is the combination of drugs that this patient is taking, respectively?
questions.solution:
The clinical scenario describes a patient with heart failure with reduced ejection fraction. This patient presents with persistent symptoms while on first-line management of HFrEF and continues to have NYHA class III symptoms (inability to walk >100 m and is comfortable at rest). This patient is on furosemide, sacubitril-valsartan, and spironolactone (second-line drug)

Heart failure may be either right-sided or left-sided. Sometimes, patients may have both types. In right-sided failure, patients typically have symptoms of fluid overload such as edema and hepatic congestion, while in left-sided failure they have symptoms of low cardiac output and elevated pulmonary venous pressure. Patients present with shortness of breath and exertional dyspnoea.

Framingham Criteria is said to be positive if 1Major + 2 minor features are present.

Major criteria include:

  • Paroxysmal nocturnal dyspnea
  • Neck vein distension
  • Abdomino-jugular reflex
  • Cardiomegaly
  • Audible S3
  • Lung crepitations
  • Pulmonary edema on CXR

Minor criteria include

  • Dyspnea
  • Ankle edema
  • Nocturnal cough
  • Palpable hepatomegaly
  • Pleural effusion
  • Tachycardia 

 

Note:

Sacubitril is a neutral endopeptidase (neprilysin) inhibitor. Sacubitril is a prodrug that is activated to sacubitrilat. It can inhibit the enzyme neprilysin (neutral endopeptidase), which is responsible for the degradation of atrial and brain natriuretic peptide (reduction of blood volume). Thus, it increases the levels of atrial and brain natriuretic peptide and lowers blood pressure. Sacubitril is approved in combination with valsartan, at a ratio of 1:1. The combination is approved for use in chronic heart failure. Sacubitril/valsartan combination in the ratio 1:1 was approved by the FDA for chronic heart failure on 7th July 2015.

NYHA functional classification of cardiovascular disability:

Class I - Patients with cardiac disease but without resulting limitations of physical activity. Ordinary physical activity does not cause undue fatigue, palpitation, dyspnea, or anginal pain.

Class II - Patients with cardiac disease resulting in slight limitation of physical activity. They are comfortable at rest. Ordinary physical activity results in fatigue, palpitation, dyspnea, or anginal pain.

Class III - Patients with cardiac disease resulting in marked limitation of physical activity. They are comfortable at rest. Less-than-ordinary physical activity causes fatigue, palpitation, dyspnea, or anginal pain.

Class IV - Patients with cardiac disease resulting in inability to carry on any physical activity without discomfort. Symptoms of cardiac insufficiency or of anginal syndrome may be present even at rest. If any physical activity is undertaken, discomfort is increased.

questions.text: As a medical officer posted in rural service, you have been asked to supervise the various preventive measures being taken in your region against malaria. According to the programme whose logo is shown below, you would be correct to advise all of the following except:

choices.text: Two rounds of spraying with DDT should be done to provide protection during the entire transmission season.
Long Lasting Insecticide Nets (LLIN) should be provided in areas with Annual Parasite Index ≥ 5.
Indoor Residual Sprays are not suitable for vector control in rural areas.
In case of DDT resistance, 3 rounds of spraying with Malathion should be done to provide protection during the entire transmission season.

questions.solution:
Under the Integrated vector management initiative, Indoor Residual Sprays are the main method of vector control in rural areas. 

National Vector Borne Disease Control Programme (NVBDCP) is the nodal agency for the prevention of control of the following vector-borne diseases:

  • Kala-azar (also called visceral leishmaniasis)
  • Malaria
  • Dengue
  • Filariasis
  • Japanese encephalitis
  • Chikungunya. 

 

Integrated Vector Management:

  • For adult mosquitoes:
    • Indoor residual Sprays are used. It is the main method of vector control in rural areas.
    • DDT is the insecticide of choice.
    • Two rounds of spraying are done with DDT and in DDT resistant areas, three rounds of spraying are done with Malathion (if DDT resistant).
  • For the larvae: Larvivorous fish and larvicides are used. This is the main method of vector control in urban areas.
  • For personal protection: 
    • Insecticide-treated bed nets are supplied in areas with Annual Parasite Index (API) ≥ 2.
    • Long-Lasting Insecticide Nets (LLIN) are provided in areas with API ≥ 5.

 

The Drug distribution centres only dispense the anti malarial drugs under the NVBDCP for Malaria. 

Important points about the organisation for the anti Malaria programme:

  • Central Government: Supplies DDT and larvicides.
  • State government: Procures the Indoor Residual Sprays (IRS) for the districts.
  • District Malaria Office: Key unit for the implementation of the programme.
  • District Malaria Officer: Has direct responsibility of IRS spraying operations and is assisted by one Assistant Malaria Officer and Malaria Inspectors. 
  • Medical officer of the PHC:  Has the overall responsibility for the surveillance and laboratory services.
  • Multi Purpose Workers and ASHAs: Carry out surveillance and case detection in community.
  • Drug Distribution Centres: Only dispensing the antimalarial drugs.
  • Fever Treatment Depots: Dispense the anti malarial drugs and collect the blood slides.

Related Pearl: Mosquito Control Measures

  • Anti-larval measures
    • Environmental control
      • This is done by source reduction by eliminating breeding places through appropriate methods for the different species.
      • Intermittent irrigation is also a method of environmental control
    • Chemical control
      • Mineral oils: Oldest known larvicidal method. Oils that are used are diesel oil, kerosene, crude oil fractions. Disadvantage is that it kills fish.
      • Paris green: Copper acetoarsenite is an emerald green, micro-crystalline powder and is insoluble in water. It is a stomach poison to larvae. It is not harmful to man or animals. Very effective against Anopheles as they are surface feeders.
      • Synthetic insecticides: Organo-phosphorous compounds like fenthion, chlorpyrifos and abate are larvicidal. Abate is least toxic.
    • Biological control
      • The fish species Gambusia affinis and Lebister reticulatus (Barbados millions) feed on mosquito larvae.
      • These are used in conjunction with other methods.
  • Anti-adult measures
    • Residual sprays
      • Adult mosquitoes can be controlled by spraying with residual insecticides like DDT, Malathion, propoxur and gamma-HCH (lindane)
      • Resistance to DDT has been shown by mosquitoes
    • Space sprays
      • Space sprays are those in which insecticides are sprayed into the atmosphere in the form of a mist or fog.
      • Pyrethrum is a contact, nerve poison and is the most common insecticide used as a space spray. Its active principle is pyrethrin.
      • Ultra-low volume space spraying (ULV) is done with Malathion and fenitrothion.
    • Genetic control by sterile male technique, cytoplasmic incompatibility, sex distortion, etc.
  • Protection against bites
    • Usage of mosquito nets, building screens and repellants like diethyltoluamide (deet), indalone, dimethylphthalate, dimethyl carbate, etc.

Related Pearl: Insecticides

Contact poisons

  • Natural: Pyrethrum, rotenone, derris, nicotine, mineral oils
  • Synthetic:
    • Organo-chlorine compounds: DDT, methoxychlor, HCH, lindane, chlordane, heptachlor, dieldrin, aldrin, toxaphene, kepone, mirex.
    • Repellants: Benzyl benzoate, indalone, meta-diethyltoluamide, dimethyl phthalate, ethyl hexanediol.
    • Organo-phosphorus compounds: Chlorthion (aryl), diazinon (aryl), demethoate, malathion (alkyl), fenthion, parathion (aryl), trichlorfon (alkyl), runnel, abale, naled, chlorpyrifos, fenitrothion, dicapthon.
    • Carbamates: Carbaryl, dimetilan, propoxur, pyrolan.
    • Synthetic pyrethroids: Prothrin, resmethrin, bioresmethrin, permethrin, proparthin, tetramethrin
  • Stomach poisons: Paris green, sodium fluoride.
  • Fumigants: Hydrogen cyanide, methyl bromide, sulphur dioxide, carbon disulphide.
Specific Insecticides Comments
DDT (Dichloro-diphenyl-thrichloroethane) Insecticidal properties were discovered by Swiss scientist, Paul Muller. Most widely used insecticide. Attacks nerves of insects but doesn’t cause immediate death. White amorphous powder. Contains 70 – 80% of para-para isomers, which is the most active fraction of DDT. Has residual action up to 18 months. Used as a residual spray.Least toxic organo-chlorine compound.
HCH (hexachlorocyclo-hexane) Synthesized by Michael Faraday. Normal HCH contains 13 – 16% of gamma isomer. Gamma-HCH or lindane has 99% gamma isomer.Short residual action – 3 months.
Malathion Least toxicity of all organophosphorus compounds. Used as an ultra-low volume spray.
Fenthion Also called baytex. Used as a residual spray.
Pyrethrum Vegetable origin – Chrysanthemum cinerariafolium. Nerve poison and is excellent as a space spray.No residual action.Synergistic action with DDT as space spray.

questions.text: A 42-year-old HIV-positive patient presented with fever and breathlessness. He has been on antiretroviral therapy for the past 2 weeks and his  CD4 count is 45 cells/cu mm. Imaging shows a lesion in the middle lobe of the lung.  The lung biopsy shows the following findings. What is the likely diagnosis in this case?
questions.solution:
The given clinical details and the characteristic histological image is suggestive of cytomegalovirus (CMV) pneumonia. The image shows a cytomegalic pneumocyte containing characteristic intranuclear basophilic inclusion seperated from the nuclear membrane by a halo (owl’s eye appearance). Within the cytoplasm of infected cells, smaller basophilic inclusions can also be seen

CMV causes an asymptomatic or mononucleosis-like infection in healthy individuals but devastating systemic infections in neonates and in immunocompromised people. In healthy individuals, acute CMV infection induces transient but severe immunosuppression by infecting dendritic cells which causes impairment of antigen processing and T cell stimulation. In immunosuppressed individuals (e.g., transplant recipients, HIV- infected individuals), serious, disseminated CMV infections primarily affect the lungs (pneumonitis) and gastrointestinal tract (gastritis and colitis).

Other options:

Option A: Cryptogenic organizing pneumonia is seen as a response to infection or inflammation to the lungs by virus, bacteria, inhaled toxins and drugs. Histologically COP is characterized by the presence of Masson bodies. These are polypoid plugs of loose organizing connective tissue within alveolar ducts, alveoli and bronchioles along with foci of fibrosis. Patients present with cough and dyspnea and have patchy subpleural or peribronchial areas of consolidation radiographically.

Image showing alveolar spaces filled with balls of fibroblasts (Masson bodies).


Option C: Cryptococcal pneumonia is a fungal infection caused by cryptococcus neoformans predominantly in immunosuppressed individuals and rarely in the immunocompetent population. Pulmonary cryptococcosis in AIDS/immunosuppressed patients presents as an interstitial lung disease with lymph node enlargement. The histopathological diagnosis is made by identifying encapsulated yeast forms within sections of the inflammatory lung tissue.

Option D: Giant cell pneumonia is a fatal but rare complication of measles, which is seen in children with immunodeficiency or severe malnutrition. The lymphoid organs, lungs and sputum typically show multinucleate giant cells, called Warthin-Finkeldey cells, which have eosinophilic nuclear and cytoplasmic inclusion bodies.

The image below shows Warthin–Finkeldey giant cell with large grapelike clusters of inclusion bodies.

Related Pearl: AIDS-defining opportunistic infections and neoplasm

Infections:

  • Protozoal and helminthic infections-
    • Cryptosporidiosis or Isosporiasis (cystoisosporiasis) - Chronic intestinal
    • Toxoplasmosis (pneumonia or CNS infection)
  • Fungal infections-
    • Candidiasis (esophageal, tracheal, or pulmonary)
    • Cryptococcosis (CNS infection)
    • Coccidioidomycosis (disseminated)
    • Pneumocystosis (pneumonia or disseminated infection)
    • Histoplasmosis (disseminated)
  • Bacterial infections-
    • Mycobacteriosis (“atypical,” e.g., Mycobacterium avium-intracellulare) disseminated or extrapulmonary
    • Mycobacterium tuberculosis (pulmonary or extrapulmonary)
    • Nocardiosis (pneumonia, meningitis, disseminated)
    • Salmonella infections, disseminated
  • Viral infections-
    • Cytomegalovirus (pulmonary, intestinal, retinitis, or CNS infections)
    • Herpes simplex virus (localized or disseminated infection)
    • Varicella-zoster virus (localized or disseminated infection)
    • Progressive multifocal leukoencephalopathy

Neoplasms:

  • Kaposi sarcoma
  • Primary lymphoma of brain
  • Invasive cancer of uterine cervix 

Related Pearl: Opportunistic Infections/HIV related conditions and ART initiation

Clinical scenario Action 
Any undiagnosed active infection with fever Diagnose and treat first; start Anti-Retroviral Therapy (ART) when stable
Tuberculosis (TB) Start TB treatment first; start ART as soon as possible after 2 weeks and before 2 months. For those with CD4 less than 50/cmm, start ART within 2 weeks Caution is needed for PLHIV with TB meningitis, since immediate ART is associated with more severe adverse events than initiating ART 2 months after the start of TB treatment

Pneumocystis pneumonia (PCP)

 Treat PCP first; start ART when PCP treatment is completed
Invasive fungal diseases: Oesophageal candidiasis, penicilliosis, histoplasmosis Start treatment for oesophageal candidiasis first; start ART as soon as the patient can swallow comfortably. Treat penicilliosis, and histoplasmosis first; start ART when the patient is stabilized or opportunistic infection treatment is completed.
Cryptococcal meningitis Treat cryptococcal meningitis. ART initiation should be deferred until there is evidence of sustained clinical response to anti-fungal therapy and after 4 weeks of induction and consolidation treatment with amphotericin B containing regimen.
Bacterial pneumonia Treat pneumonia first; start ART when treatment is completed
Malaria Treat malaria first; start ART when treatment is completed
Acute diarrhoea which may reduce absorption of ART Diagnose the cause and treat diarrhoea first; start ART when diarrhoea is stabilized or controlled
Non-severe anaemia (Hb< 9 g/dl) Start ART if no other causes for anaemia are found (HIV is often the cause of anaemia) 
Skin conditions such as PPE and seborrhoeic dermatitis, psoriasis, HIV-related exfoliative dermatitis Start ART (ART may resolve these problems) 
Suspected Mycobacterium Avium Complex (MAC), Cryptosporidiosis and Microsporidiosis Start ART (ART may resolve these problems)
Cytomegalovirus retinitis Start treatment for CMV urgently and start ART after 2 weeks of CMV treatment 
Toxoplasmosis Treat toxoplasmosis; start ART after 6 weeks of treatment and when the patient is stabilized

questions.text: A 40-year-old woman presents with complaints of swelling of the right breast over the past 15 days. On examination, there was local rise of temperature, and the swelling was mobile over the chest wall. What is the likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
In the given scenario, the rapid onset of the disease and the examination findings are suggestive of inflammatory carcinoma of the breast.

Inflammatory breast cancer is the most aggressive subtype of breast cancer. It mimics acute mastitis. The hallmark of inflammatory breast carcinoma is the diffuse tumor involvement of the dermal lymphatics within the breast and the overlying skin, often without a discrete underlying tumor mass (peau d' orange appearance). The patient presents with rapidly progressive swelling of the breast, warmth, erythema and edema. A breast lump may or may not be present. 

A diagnosis of inflammatory breast carcinoma should be suspected when a patient with rapidly progressive swelling with inflammatory skin changes does not respond to antibiotics. The imaging features with ultrasound and a mammograph is non-specific due to the underlying erythema and edema. A biopsy should be done to confirm the diagnosis. 

Treatment includes combined-modality treatment:

  • Neoadjuvant chemo­therapy
  • Mastectomy
  • Radiation therapy
  • Hormonal therapy- for ER-positive tumors
  • Trastuzumab for HER-2-positive tumors

Option B: Giant fibroadenomas occasionally occur during puberty. These are benign solid encapsulated slow-growing tumors over 5 cm in diameter. It presents as a painless lump in the breast. They are managed by excision via a submammary incision.

Option C: Phyllodes tumors usually occur in women over the age of 40 years but can appear in younger women. Phyllodes tumor is mostly benign even though it is also called cystosarcoma phyllodes. It presents as a large tumor with an unevenly bosselated surface. They are usually mobile over the chest wall despite their large size. This tumor does not infiltrate the skin. Nipple retraction is not seen in this condition. Benign lesions can be treated with enucleation or wide local excision. Massive tumours, recurrent tumours and malignant lesions are treated with a mastectomy.

Option D: Galactocele are the most common benign breast lesions in lactating women. It is a cystic enlargement of the mammary gland containing milk. They are mostly detected during lactation or in the third trimester of pregnancy but rarely, may also present after stopping breastfeeding. Clinically, the mass is usually firm and non-tender and presents as a solid tumour-like lesion on physical examination. The patient usually notes the lesion during lactation or some period after lactation. Needle aspiration, followed by excision should it recur, is the standard method of treating galactocele.

questions.text: The forensic department has received the post-mortem remains of a partly decayed body recovered from the outskirts near an international airport. The cephalic index of the skull is 82 and the hair appears circular on the cross-section. Dental examination shovel-shaped upper incisors and enamel pearls. What will be your inference about the race from these findings?
questions.solution:
The cephalic index of the skull being 82 (Brachycephalic), the hair being circular on cross-section, and the dentition showing characteristic shovel-shaped upper incisors and enamel pearls is suggestive of a Mongoloid race.

Features of Mongoloid dentition:

  • Shovel-shaped upper central incisors - Posterior surfaces of these teeth have a depression centrally
  • Enamel pearls - Small nodules of enamel on the tooth surface
  • The pulp cavity of molars is wide and deep
  • A congenital lack of the third upper molar is common but nonspecific.

Negroid races tend to have large teeth and often have more cusps on their molars, even up to eight, with two lingual cusps on the mandibular first premolars as an additional common finding.

In Caucasian races, the lateral incisors in the upper jaw are usually smaller than the central. They also have long pointed canine roots. Small nodules on the lingual surface of maxillary molars, called ‘Carabelli’s cusp’, are most common in Caucasian races.

Race determination from Hair:

Race Hair cross-section
Negroids Elliptical
Caucasoids Round to Ovoid
Mongoloids Circular


The Cephalic Index is used to determine the race of the individual.

Cranial index = Maximum skull breadth x 100 / Maximum skull length

There are three main racial groups: Caucasian, Mongoloid, and Negroid. All the skulls cannot be accurately differentiated into the 3 broad categories because of racial mixing.

The skull offers the best evidence of racial origins.

Type of skull Cephalic index Race(s)
Dolichocephalic 70-75 Pure Aryans, Aborigines, Negroes
Mesaticephalic 75-80 Europeans, Chinese, Indians
Brachycephalic 80-85 Mongolian


The skull of an Indian is said to be 'Caucasian with a few Negroid features'. 

Race determination from other bones

  • Upper limb bones - Brachial index
  • Lower limb bones - Crural index
  • Both upper and lower limb - Intermembral index ie, (Length of humerus + radius/Length of femur + tibia) x 100

questions.text:
A 27-year-old patient presents with a high-grade fever with chills, headache, fatigue, and weakness for the past 6 days. Laboratory investigations reveal low hemoglobin level, reticulocytosis, and increased unconjugated bilirubin level. The microscopic examination of the thin blood smear is given below. Which of the following statements are correct regarding this disease?

1. It is transmitted by ixodid tick.

2. Sporozoites are the infective form for humans.

3. Man is the definitive host.

4. The ring forms are rarely seen.

5. Schizonts and gametocytes are absent.
questions.solution:
The given clinical history and the microscopic image showing tetrads arranged in Maltese cross formation, which is pathognomonic of babesiosis. The correct statements regarding babesiosis are 1, 2, and 5.

Babesia:

Babesia, a genus of protozoan organisms that includes Babesia microti and Babesia duncani, are responsible for babesiosis. Ixodid ticks are the definitive host. Man is an intermediate host. Sporozoites are the infective form for humans.

The mode of infection is through a tick bite. Occasionally it can also be through blood transfusion.

The majority of the clinical symptoms are predominantly caused by hemolysis of the infected erythrocytes. The illness develops 1-6 weeks after the tick bite. It might be a mild, self-limiting, asymptomatic, or severe sickness that resembles malaria.
Malaise, exhaustion, high-grade fever (38°C to 40.6°C) with chills and sweating, myalgia, arthralgia, a dry cough, and anorexia are symptoms of acute illness.

Complications of acute babesiosis include renal failure, disseminated intravascular coagulation (DIC), acute respiratory distress syndrome (ARDS), and congestive cardiac failure (CCF).

Diagnosis is made by the examination of blood films stained with Leishman or Giemsa stain.

  • Babesia appears as intraerythrocytic pyriform, or ring form simulating Plasmodium falciparum
  • The ring forms are the most common and lack the central hemozoin deposit.
  • Other distinguishing features are the absence of schizonts and gametocytes and the presence of tetrads (Maltese crosses), which are pathognomonic of B. microti or B. duncani.

Treatment of B. microti infection

  • Mild infection is treated with atovaquone along with azithromycin
  • Severe infections are treated with azithromycin along with atovaquone or clindamycin along with quinine
  • Exchange transfusion is required in patients with high-grade parasitemia (≥10%), severe anemia, and pulmonary, hepatic, or renal compromise.

Other Babesia infections are treated with a combination of clindamycin and quinine.

questions.text: A patient recently returned from a tour to Egypt and presents with painless haematuria. This structure was found on microscopy of urine. Which of the following is incorrect regarding the life cycle of the causative organism?

choices.text: Cercaria larva are the infective form.
Metacercaria stage is seen in the snail.

questions.solution:
Eggs with terminal spine and a history of painless hematuria are suggestive of infection with Schistosoma haematobium.

Points in favor: Ovoid, (about 150 μm by 50 μm) non-operculated, with a brownish-yellow transparent shell carrying a terminal spine at one pole. The terminal spine being characteristic of the species.

Schistosoma haematobium primarily causes genito-urinary schistosomiasis. The adult worms live in the veins of urinary bladder.

Cercaria larva are the infective form of schistosomes. Cercaria infects man by penetrating the skin which can lead to intense irritation and skin rash at the site of cercarial penetration (known as swimmer's itch).

After penetrating the skin, the cercariae lose their tails and become schistosomulae which travel through peripheral venules to systemic circulation, to the inferior mesenteric veins, finally reaching the vesical and pelvic venous plexuses, where they mature and lay eggs. The eggs that are passed in urine are embryonated and hatch in water under suitable conditions to release the free-living ciliated miracidia.

Miracidia penetrates into tissues of the snail and reaches its liver. Large numbers of cercariae are produced by asexual reproduction and are released into the water.

Metacercaria and redia stages are not seen in schistosomes.

Praziquantel is the drug of choice for schistosomiasis.

The following are the unique features distinguishing schistosomes from other trematodes:

  • Only one intermediate host
  • They produce non- operculated eggs.
  • They have no redia stage in larval development
  • Mode of infection is by penetration of intact skin with the help of forked tails of cercariae

NOTE: 

Infective forms of most trematodes (Eg. Fasciola hepatica, Fasciola buski, Clonorchis sinensis) to humans are metacercaria larva.

Species differentiation of Schistosoma can be done based on the location of spine as follows.

  • Terminal spine: Schistosoma hematobium
  • Lateral spine: Schistosoma mansoni
  • Round with small lateral knob or Rudimentary spine: Schistosoma japonicum.

questions.text: A 26-year-old primigravida is being followed up in a primary health center in rural Karnataka. She is at 34-weeks gestation. She has no complaints today. Physical examination is unremarkable for her gestational age and fetal heart sounds are normal. Her obstetrician is following the 2016 WHO ANC model for her check-up visits. According to this model, when should this woman be called for her next visit considering that she will only be completing the minimum number of required visits during her pregnancy?
questions.solution:
According to 2016 WHO ANC model, the minimum number of antenatal visits should be 8. As she is currently at her 34th week of gestation, the next visit should be at 36 weeks.

  • Contact 1: Upto 12 weeks
  • Contact 2: 20 weeks
  • Contact 3: 26 weeks
  • Contact 4: 30 weeks
  • Contact 5: 34 weeks
  • Contact 6: 36 weeks
  • Contact 7: 38 weeks
  • Contact 8: 40 weeks

Return for delivery at  41 weeks if not delivered yet. The trimester-wise contacts would be 1 contact in the first trimester, 2 contacts in the second trimester and 5 in the third trimester. 

The generally recommended ideal number of antenatal visits is 12-14:

  • Monthly visits upto 28 weeks
  • Two weekly visits between 28-36 weeks
  • Weekly visits from 36 weeks onwards

This means a total of 12-15 visits.

The older, Focussed Antenatal Care (FANC) guidelines by the WHO recommended a minimum of 4 visits as given below

  • 1st visit: Within 12 weeks preferably as soon as pregnancy is suspected, for the registration of pregnancy and 1st antenatal check-up.
  • 2nd visit: Between 24-26 weeks
  • 3rd visit: At 32 weeks
  • 4th visit: Between 36-38 weeks

Return for delivery at  41 weeks if not delivered yet.

A booked case is one that has at least 3 antenatal visits with two visit in the third trimester.

questions.text: A 47-year-old female patient comes to the clinic for evaluation of constant dribbling of urine. Upon performing the following test, the swab labeled "B" is stained blue. Which of the following statements are true?

choices.text: Marshall-Marchetti-Krantz operation is done for this condition
The test is called the Q-tip test
Keigel's exercises is the first-line management for this condition
Latzko procedure can be done to treat this condition

questions.solution:
The given clinical complex describes a case of vesicovaginal fistula which is diagnosed using a methylene blue3 swab test in which the middle swabs stains with methylene blue. Latzko's procedure is done for this condition.

The preferred technique of repair of the vesicovaginal fistula which occurred post-hysterectomy is Latzko's procedure.

Latzko's procedure: It is done by denudation of vaginal epithelium around fistulous edges, freshening the edges, and approximation of raw surface with absorbable sutures. This technique is suited for post-hysterectomy fistula that is caused by cancer cervix. It can lead to narrowing of the vagina or vaginal atresia.

Fistula located at the vaginal vault post hysterectomy is the most difficult to treat, this technique is suited for such cases.

In case of an established fistula, it is better to wait for about 3 months for all tissue inflammation to subside, before surgery is undertaken.

Most vesicovaginal fistulae are repaired per vaginally.

The various surgeries done for the repair of VVF (vesicovaginal fistula) are as follows:

  • Latzko procedure
  • Chasser Moir technique
  • Ureteric implantation

 The image below shows the swab test for VVF

Other Options:

Marshall-Marchetti-Krantz operation (Option 1) is a surgical management option for genuine stress incontinence

Q tip test (Option 2) is done for stress incontinence.

  • A Q-tip cotton swab stick dipped in Xylocaine jelly placed in urethra
  • The patient is asked to strain or cough. Initially the stick will be parallel to the floor
  • Normally the stick will reach an angle of around 10-15
  • This angle increases by 20 or more in cases suffering from GSI
  • A positive test indicates sufficient degree of bladder neck descent. Unfortunately, all patients with GSI may not have a positive test.
  • This test is not very specific.

Keigel's exercises (Option 3) are the conservative management modality for young women with urge incontinence

questions.text: A middle-aged woman presents with right groin pain. She is a known case of systemic lupus erythematosus for which she has been on steroids for several years. On examination, there is decreased passive and active range of motion of the right hip. You suspect avascular necrosis of the femoral head but the X-ray findings are inconclusive. Which of the following would be the investigation of choice in this scenario?
questions.solution:
The clinical vignette of a patient on systemic steroids with groin pain and reduced range of motion in the hip but a normal radiograph is indicative of avascular necrosis of the femoral head. The investigation of choice to diagnose early avascular necrosis is MRI.

MRI allows the identification of avascular necrosis of the femoral head in earlier stages and also helps determine the exact stage and extent of the pathologic process.

Avascular necrosis or osteonecrosis is a degenerative bone condition caused by interruption of the blood supply. It commonly affects the epiphysis of long bones that make up weight-bearing joints. 

The common areas that are affected by avascular necrosis are: 

  • Head of the femur after a fracture of the neck of the femur or hip dislocation
  • Proximal scaphoid after a scaphoid waist fracture
  • Lunate bone after a dislocation
  • Body of the talus after a fracture of the neck of the talus

It is considered to be an early complication of injury, however, it is not clinically evident until weeks to months after the inciting event. There are generally no symptoms associated with avascular necrosis. However, if the fracture does not unite, then there will be a pain. 

An X-ray will reveal increased density. This occurs due to disuse osteoporosis in the surrounding areas and the collapse of trabeculae compacts the bone. There may also be deformity due to the collapse of necrotic bone and osteoarthritis. 

In osteonecrosis of the femur, an X-ray will reveal a crescent sign which is pathognomonic. The sign refers to the subchondral fracture that overlies the necrotic segment of the femoral head. 

The X-ray below shows flattening of the femoral head and degenerative changes associated with osteonecrosis.

The image below shows a crescent sign. 

A bone scan may reveal a 'cold area' before radiological features are evident. MRI is the imaging modality of choice in avascular necrosis as it allows for staging and determination of the extent of involvement. 

It is treated depending on the joint involved. Weight-bearing should be delayed until it is revascularized, a process that may take 6-8 months. Revascularization can be done by using vascularized bone grafts taken from the greater trochanter in the case of a fracture of the femur neck. The avascular segment should be excised followed by a total joint replacement. 

Related Pearl: Avascular Necrosis (AVN)

It is a rare but severe complication of certain fractures when the blood supply to a segment of bone is affected. 

Common sites of AVN are:

  • Head of the femur in fracture neck of femur and posterior dislocation of the hip
  • Body of talus in a fracture through the neck of talus
  • Proximal pole of the scaphoid in a fracture through the waist of the scaphoid
  • Head of the humerus
  • The capitulum

Non-traumatic causes of AVN are:

  • Idiopathic
  • Steroids
  • Sickle cell disease
  • Caisson's disease
  • Gaucher's disease
  • Lupus Erythematosus
  • Radiation therapy
  • Alcoholism
  • Hyperlipidemia

Important signs related to avascular necrosis:

  • Crescent sign- Seen in osteonecrosis of the femoral head. It is a subchondral fracture overlying the necrotic segment of the femoral head.
  • Hawkin's sign- Seen secondary to the fracture of the neck of the talus. It refers to subchondral lucency of the dome of the talus due to subchondral atrophy. The presence of this sign indicates that the blood supply to the talus is adequate and chances of avascular necrosis are low.

questions.text: During the clinical examination of a 16-year-old female, you notice the following peculiar abnormality of the iris. This is called as
questions.solution:
Normally the pupil is placed slightly nasal to the center. This image shows an abnormally eccentrically placed pupil. This is called corectopia.

Corectopia is usually benign, non-progressive, and doesn't require any treatment. Treatment is required if it is associated with symptoms such as iritis, visual loss, etc

Option B: The presence of more than one pupil is called polycoria which is shown in the image below 

Option D: The congenital absence of an iris is known as aniridia. Complete absence is referred to as true aniridia and in the presence of a peripheral rim of the iris, it is known as clinical aniridia. Aniridia is shown in the image below

questions.text: In a village with a given population, the total number of births in a year is 5100. There were 100 stillbirths. 25 newborns died within the first 7 days of life whereas 175 died due to various causes between 8 – 28 days of life. There were 50 deaths between the age of 1 month to 6 months of life. What is the neonatal mortality rate in this population?
questions.solution:
Neonatal mortality rate = Number of deaths of children under 28 days of age in a year x 1000/Total live births in the same year

The total live births in this scenario is 5100 – 100 = 5000 live births.

NMR = (25+175) x 1000/5000 = 40.

Note: Still births and deaths after 28 days of life are not considered in Neonatal Mortality Rate.

Related Pearl: Neonatal Mortality Rate

  • Neonatal deaths are those that occur during the neonatal period, commencing at birth and ending at 28 completed days after birth.
  • NMR = Number of deaths of children under 28 days of age in a year x 1000/Total live births in the same year
  • Main causes of neonatal death are prematurity (leading cause), birth asphyxia, intrapartum-related complications, sepsis, pneumonia, congenital anomalies, tetanus, diarrhea, etc.
  • India’s NMR  is 20 per 1000 live births (SRS 2020)

questions.text: A 12-year-old girl presents with severe headache, photophobia and high fever of 101°F. On examination, papilledema and nuchal rigidity was present. Kernig's and Brudzinski signs were positive.  CSF examination shows reduced glucose, increased protein, and increased leukocytes with the predominance of neutrophils. Gram staining of the CSF is shown below. Causative organism is:
questions.solution:
History, physical examination, and CSF findings are suggestive of bacterial meningitis. The given image shows intracellular Gram-negative diplococci i.e. Neisseria meningitidis.

The genus Neisseria consists of Gram-negative, aerobic, non-sporulating, non-motile, oxidase-positive cocci arranged typically in pairs (diplococci). It includes two pathogens: Neisseria meningitidis and Neisseria gonorrhoeae. The important difference is the presence of a polysaccharide capsule in N meningitidis.

The organism enters the body through the nasopharynx. From the nasopharynx, they enter the bloodstream producing bacteremia, and the symptoms may resemble upper respiratory tract infection. Clinical features include fever, convulsions, and signs of meningeal irritation (nuchal rigidity, Kernig's sign, Brudzinski's signs). Fulminant meningococcemia is the severe form, where the patient presents with high-grade fever and hemorrhagic rash due to petechial hemorrhages.

Some patients with fulminant meningococcemia may also develop disseminated intravascular coagulation, and circulatory collapse, a condition known as Waterhouse–Friderichsen syndrome.

The selective medium used is the Modified Thayer-Martin medium (with vancomycin, colistin, and nystatin). The colonies are seen as small, translucent, convex, bluish-grey, with a smooth glistening surface and lenticular in shape on solid media.

Intravenous penicillin G is the treatment of choice. Eradicative therapy is to be given with rifampicin or ciprofloxacin to prevent the carrier state.

Chemoprophylaxis is indicated for the household and close contacts. The preferred antibiotics are rifampin, ciprofloxacin, and ceftriaxone. Monovalent, polyvalent, and conjugate vaccines are available.

Other options:

Option A: Haemophilus influenzae type B is a gram-negative bacillus with considerable polymorphism. In sputum, clusters of coccobacillary forms are seen; In CSF, long bacillary filamentous forms predominate. H. influenzae b grows on chocolate agar (which supplies necessary nutrients from lysed red blood cells) or on blood agar (appear as satellite colonies surrounding β-hemolytic colonies of S. aureus).

Option C: Streptococcus pneumoniae is a gram positive, capsulated, flame shaped or lanceolate shaped diplococci. In culture, the typical morphology may not be apparent and the cocci are more rounded, tending to occurjp short chain

Option D: Listeria monocytogenes is a short, non sporing, gram positive bacillus. It shows characteristic tumbling motility at 25°C, but is non motile at 37°C.

questions.text: A 66-year-old man presents with increasing fatigue, bone pain and is found to be anemic. Physical examination reveals a hard 1-cm nodule in the prostate and the PSA level is elevated. Peripheral blood smear findings include occasional myelocytes, a few tear-drop red blood cells (RBCs)  and two nucleated RBCs per 100 white cells. Erythrocytes are normochromic and normocytic. What is the most likely diagnosis in this case?
questions.solution:
In the given clinical scenario of a patient suspected to have metastatic prostate cancer now presenting with normocytic normochromic anemia with a leukoerythroblastic picture and tear-drop-shaped RBCs on the peripheral smear, a diagnosis of myelophthisic anemia is most likely.

Myelophthisic anemia is a form of marrow failure in which space-occupying lesions replace normal bone marrow elements. The most common cause is metastatic cancer, most often carcinomas arising from the breast, lung, and prostate. Myelophthisic anemia can also be seen in the spent phase of myeloproliferative neoplasms.

Infiltration of the bone marrow leads to fibrosis and structural distortion. This disturbs the normal mechanisms by which RBCs and WBCs come out from the bone marrow into the blood. This leads to the premature release of nucleated erythroid precursors and immature granulocytic forms. This is referred to as a leukoerythroblastic picture. Moreover, dacrocytes (tear-shaped RBCs) are also seen; they are formed due to their deformation during release from the bone marrow.

Due to fibrosis and structural distortion of bone marrow, extramedullary hematopoiesis occurs in the liver and spleen, leading to hepatomegaly and splenomegaly.

The image given below shows a leukoerythroblastic blood picture with nucleated RBCs, tear-drop cells, and immature myeloid cells:

Other options:

Option A: Microangiopathic hemolytic anemia (MAHA) is caused due to trauma to RBCs inside the blood vessels. The hemolysis is a result of the shear forces which act on the RBCs. This occurs in prosthetic heart valves, disseminated intravascular coagulation (DIC), thrombotic thrombocytopenic purpura (TTP), and hemolytic uremic syndrome (HUS). These disorders lead to luminal narrowing and thrombus formation and thus cause mechanical damage to the RBCs. MAHA shows schistocytes or helmet cells on peripheral smear.

Option C: Autoimmune hemolytic anemia is caused by antibody and complement-mediated RBC destruction. The diagnosis of autoimmune hemolytic anemia requires direct and indirect Coombs test.

Option D: Aplastic anemia refers to primary bone marrow failure and consequent pancytopenia. Although aplastic anemia also presents with normocytic normochromic anemia, it will not show a leukoerythroblastic picture in the peripheral smear. Hepatomegaly and Splenomegaly are not seen in aplastic anemia.

questions.text: A 25-year-old patient is brought to the psychiatrist by his mother. She describes him as a strict follower of a rigid schedule every day. He redoes his assignments until they appear perfect to him. He gets annoyed if his schedule is disrupted. The patient bluntly states that he is not doing anything wrong and that his mother is inefficient.  He is unable to complete tasks in time as he strives for perfection. Which of the following is the most probable diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Rigid and perfectionistic behaviour suggests obsessive-compulsive personality disorder.

Patients with obsessive-compulsive personality disorder often have an obsession with rules, details, regulations, neatness, orderliness, and the achievement of perfection. They can work for long periods provided it is routinized as they generally lack flexibility and are intolerant. They have limited interpersonal skills and are formal and serious and often lack a sense of humor. They however try to please those they consider superior to them and carry out their orders in an authoritarian manner. Additionally, they are indecisive as they fear making mistakes.

Differential diagnosis - outpatients with minor obsessive-compulsive personality traits are not occupationally or functionally impaired.

Other options:

Option B - Obsessive-compulsive disorder unlike obsessive-compulsive personality disorder is associated with obsessions that control the patient's actions. Also, it is associated with recurrent obsessions and compulsions.

Option C - Narcissistic personality trait is characterized by an increased sense of self-importance, grandiosity, and lack of empathy.

Option D - Schizotypal personality trait is characterized by eccentric & odd thoughts, perceptions & behavior, magical thinking, ideas of reference, illusions, and peculiar notions.

questions.text: A 40-year-old male complains of fever with chills, sore throat, myalgia, and fatigue for 8 days. He does not complain of any breathlessness. He recently traveled from rural India where he was working in a health camp. His SpO2 is 90%. Physical examination shows pallor. CT scan of the lung shows a CO-RADS score of 5. CBC shows mild anemia.  RT-PCR is positive for COVID 19 and rapid diagnostic test(RDT) with peripheral smear is positive for P. vivax. Which of the following is the drug/drug combination recommended by the MoHFW for the treatment of malaria in this case?
questions.solution:
The clinical vignette describes a case of COVID 19 with malaria(P. vivax) co-infection. The recommended drugs for P. vivax co-infection in COVID-19 is chloroquine and primaquine.

Clinical features of malaria as a co-infection - fever, headache, vomiting, anemia, fits/convulsions, and loss of consciousness. 

Diagnosis -  RDT (bivalent) or microscopic blood smear examination

Management - 

  • Plasmodium vivax (Pv) - 
    Chloroquine(25 mg/kg body weight divided over three days) and Primaquine (0.25 mg/kg body weight divided over for 14 days). Primaquine prevents relapse but is contraindicated in pregnant women, infants, and individuals with G6PD deficiency.
  • Plasmodium falciparum(Pf) - 
    ACT (Artesunate 3 days + Sulphadoxine + Pyrimethamine 1 day) - Artesunate (4 mg/kg body weight daily for 3 days) plus Sulfadoxine (25 mg/kg body weight) and Pyrimethamine (1.25 mg/kg body weight) on day 1. Followed by a single dose of Primaquine (0.75 mg/kg body weight) on day 2.

questions.text: A 4-year-old girl was brought with signs and symptoms suggestive of a bleeding disorder. Laboratory tests revealed normal platelet count,  prolonged bleeding time, and defects in platelet aggregation. The Ristocetin aggregation test was normal. Further studies revealed defects in GP IIb/IIIa receptors. Which of the following drugs act on the same receptor?
questions.solution:
The given clinical complex describes a case of Glanzmann's thrombasthenia caused due to deficiency of the glycoprotein IIb-IIIa receptor. Abciximab is an anti-platelet drug that functions by blocking this receptor. 

Other drugs that act by blocking Gp IIb/IIIa receptors are tirofiban and eptifibatide. 

They are mainly used during percutaneous coronary intervention for acute coronary syndrome. They carry a high risk of bleeding and can cause thrombocytopenia.

Note:

Deficiency of the same receptor, Glycoprotein IIb-IIIa, leads to a condition called immune thrombocytopenic purpura. In immune thrombocytopenic purpura (ITP), antibodies are formed in the spleen against the cell-surface antigens GpIIb/IIIa or GpIb/IX, causing increased peripheral destruction of platelets.

Other options:

Option B: Clopidogrel  is an irreversible inhibitor of the ADP (P2Y12) receptor of platelets.

Option C: Low-molecular-weight heparin is an anticoagulant that acts by inhibiting factors Xa and IIa.

Option D: Rivaroxaban is a direct oral factor Xa inhibitor that inhibits the free and clot-associated factor Xa resulting in reduced thrombin generation.

questions.text:
A 65-year-old female patient presents with a bleed in her eye. The patient says that she noticed it in the morning while brushing her hair. She does not recall any events that may have caused it. She does not have a fever or discharge from the eye. She has a history of hypertension that is not adequately managed. Physical examination is unremarkable except for the findings shown in the image. Which of the following statements regarding the underlying diagnosis is false?

NSAIDs - Nonsteroidal anti-inflammatory drugs

choices.text: Use of NSAIDs and aspirin to treat the condition should be avoided
Recurrent episodes warrant investigations for a bleeding diathesis or leukemia
If there is no resolution in 1 week, further investigation is necessary

questions.solution:
The above clinical vignette and the image showing a homogenous bright red color in the conjunctiva with well-defined limits is suggestive of subconjunctival hemorrhage. The blood gradually changes color and can take 1-3 weeks time to resolve.

A subconjunctival hemorrhage is also called subconjunctival ecchymosis. It is due to the rupture of small blood vessels and can occur spontaneously in elder people with systolic hypertension or after local trauma. They are usually painless.

If the posterior limit is not seen, check for the base of the skull fracture. 

Recurrent episodes warrant investigations for a bleeding diathesis or leukemia. The differential diagnosis includes Kaposi sarcoma.

The use of NSAIDs and aspirin to treat the condition should be avoided since the use of these drugs may increase the risk of subconjunctival hemorrhage.

Artificial tears and ice packs can be used to minimize tissue swelling and provide relief of the discomforts due to subconjunctival hemorrhage.

questions.text: A 2-year-old boy presented with complaints of headache, projectile vomiting, and blurring of vision. On investigating, the presence of Homer-Wright rosettes and a well-circumscribed mass over the cerebellum were seen. According to the WHO grading of brain tumors, this tumor belongs to ______.
questions.solution:
The given clinical features of headache, projectile vomiting, and blurring of vision in a 1-year-old boy with the presence of Hommer-wright rosettes and a well-circumscribed mass over the cerebellum is suggestive of medulloblastoma and medulloblastoma corresponds to WHO grade IV brain tumor.

Medulloblastomas are the most common primary malignant CNS tumor in children. It is often undifferentiated and corresponds to WHO grade IV. It accounts for 20% of brain tumors in children. It occurs predominantly in children and exclusively in the cerebellum (by definition).

It has 3 variants:

  • The classic subtype, tumor cells form Homer Wright rosettes and expression of synaptophysin is seen.
  • The desmoplastic/nodular variant is characterized by internodular areas of stromal response, marked by collagen and reticulin deposition (i.e., desmoplasia), and “pale islands” or nodules that have more neuropil and show greater neuronal differentiation.
  • The large cell/anaplastic variant shows large, undifferentiated anaplastic cells.

Dissemination through the CSF is a common complication and drop metastases are commonly seen in medulloblastoma. Drop metastases refer to the dissemination of the tumor through the CSF to anatomically lower sites like the spinal cord.

Treatment involves surgical resection which may be followed by radiotherapy.

questions.text: A 29-year-old patient is evaluated as he cannot flex the distal interphalangeal (DIP) joint of the index finger. He had a supracondylar fracture of the humerus that was repaired surgically the previous day. The physician concludes that the nerve damage is a result of the fracture. The nerve damaged in this clinical scenario is a branch of which of the following structures?
questions.solution:
The clinical scenario describes a case of a supracondylar fracture with anterior interosseous nerve injury which is a branch of the median nerve marked as 1. 

The most common nerve affected in supracondylar fracture with medial displacement of supracondylar fracture is the anterior interosseous nerve. The anterior interosseous nerve supplies the flexor digitorum profundus muscle of the index finger and damage to the nerve prevents flexion of the index finger.

Relations of the third part of the axillary artery: 

Anterior: Pectoralis major, skin and fascia, the medial root of the median nerve

Posterior: Lower part of subscapularis and tendons of lattisimus dorsi and teres major, radial, and axillary nerves

Lateral: Coracobrachialis, musculocutaneous nerve (for a short distance), Lateral root, and then the trunk of the median nerve

Medial: Axillary vein, medial cutaneous nerve of forearm, Ulnar nerve

Supracondylar fracture of humerus: 

Most commonly seen in children of 5-8 years. Extension type occurs more often than flexion type. Commonly due to a fall on an outstretched hand with the elbow in full extension. On examination, there is an unusual posterior prominence of tip of the olecranon and the three-point bony relationship is maintained with respect to each other but not with respect to the shaft of the humerus.

Nerve injury - Most common nerve to be injured in medial displacement in order of occurrence is - anterior interosseous nerve > Median nerve > Radial nerve > Ulnar nerve. (AMRU). The most common nerve to be injured in posteromedial displacement -Ulnar nerve. Injury to the ulnar nerve leads to sensory involvement of the little and ring fingers along with an ulnar claw hand( hyperextension at the metacarpophalangeal joints and flexion at the proximal and distal interphalangeal joints of the 4th and 5th fingers).

Vessel injury - The most common vessel to be injured is the brachial artery which can can lead to the absence of a radial pulse.

 Complications:

  • Malunion: Posteromedially displaced fracture tend to develop cubitus Varus (Gunstock deformity)
  • Nerve injury: usually neuropraxia, hence transient.
  • Volkmann’s ischemic contracture and compartment syndrome 

Treatment of Supracondylar fracture

  • Closed reduction and K-wire fixation.
  • Tractions used: Dunlop and Smith's.

questions.text: A 54-year-old man comes in for his annual clinical examination. He has no current complaints. He has a history of hypertension that is inadequately managed and his BP is currently 168/104 mm of Hg. Ophthalmologic examination reveals focal arteriolar narrowing and deflection of veins at AV crossings with no other changes. Which stage per the Keith and Wagner classification does this patient fall under?
questions.solution:
The clinical vignette shows a patient with hypertensive retinopathy having Salu's sign seen on fundoscopy. Salu's sign with no additional findings is indicative of stage II hypertensive retinopathy.

Grading of hypertensive retinopathy (Keith-Wagner classification):

  • Grade 1: Mild generalized retinal arteriolar narrowing 
  • Grade 2: Focal arteriolar narrowing and deflection of veins at AV crossings (Salu's sign).
  • Grade 3: Grade 2 plus retinal hemorrhages (dot, blot, flame) or exudates (chronic retinal edema may result in the deposition of hard exudates around the fovea as a "macular star") and cotton wool spots.
  • Grade 4: Severe grade 3 plus optic disc swelling (a marker of malignant hypertension)

questions.text: A 33-year-old female patient comes to the clinic with difficulty swallowing food and liquids for the last two months. She also complains of a sensation of food getting stuck in her throat. She has had an intermittent burning sensation in her throat and chest during the last month. Further evaluation with barium swallow shows the findings below. Which of the following is false about her condition?

choices.text: All patients with this condition should be evaluated for psychiatric conditions
Aperistalsis in the oesophageal body is the characteristic feature
Calcium channel blockers may be tried in mildly symptomatic patients
This condition is seen most often in female patients

questions.solution:
The above clinical picture and barium swallow showing a corkscrew appearance are characteristic of a diffuse esophageal spasm (DES). Aperistalsis of the oesophageal body is a characteristic finding in achalasia cardia, not DES.

Diffuse Esophageal Spasm - It is a poorly understood hypermotility disorder of the esophagus seen more commonly in women.  Patients usually present with dysphagia and chest pain which is caused by spontaneous, abnormal contractions seen more in the distal two-thirds of the oesophageal body. Esophageal contractions are repetitive, simultaneous, and of high amplitude. However, in between the contractions, peristalsis remains normal. This condition is seen most often in female patients

Clinical presentation:

  • Dysphagia for solids and liquids
  • The sensation of food stuck in the throat
  • Retrosternal, noncardiac chest pain as a solitary symptom or accompanying the dysphagia
  • Symptoms of heartburn or regurgitation

Investigations :

A barium swallow shows a corkscrew esophagus. 

Treatment: The mainstay of treatment for DES is nonsurgical modalities with pharmacologic therapy or endoscopic intervention being preferred. All patients with DES should be evaluated for psychiatric conditions like anxiety, depression, psychosomatic complaints etc. Calcium-channel antagonists, vasodilators, and endoscopic dilatation have only transient effects. Surgical treatment includes extended/long oesophageal myotomy, up to the aortic arch, if required. The surgical treatment of DES is more successful in improving dysphagia than chest pain.

Related Pearl: Barium swallow

Diffuse esophageal spasm: Corkscrew appearance

Feline esophagus: Transient transverse bands seen in the mid and lower esophagus on a double-contrast barium swallow. It is seen in active gastroesophageal reflux, hiatus hernia, and eosinophilic esophagitis.

Achalasia: Dilated esophagus with a retained column of barium and bird beak sign.

Zenker's diverticulum: Posterior outpouching of the hypopharynx through a weakness in the muscle layer called Killian dehiscence.

Esophageal carcinoma: Irregular narrowing, mucosal destruction, and shouldered margins.

Schatzki's ring: Thin submucosal circumferential ring in the lower esophagus at the squamocolumnar junction.

Esophageal web in a patient with Plummer Vinson syndrome. Esophageal webs are thin membranes of normal esophageal tissue consisting of mucosa and submucosa. Translucent part denotes esophageal web.

Esophageal leiomyoma is the most common benign tumor of the esophagus. On barium swallow, it is seen as a discrete ovoid mass that is well outlined by barium (smooth submucosal mass). Its borders form slightly obtuse angles with the esophagal wall.

The image below depicts a barium study showing the classic semilunar filling defect.
