questions.text: A 10-year-old boy presents with a generalized rash. He reports pruritus over the affected areas. Physical examination reveals multiple small papules and plaques as shown in the image below. The lesions are primarily present over the trunk and proximal extremities. Which of the following preceding infections might have precipitated this patient's current findings?
questions.solution:
The clinical vignette with physical examination findings showing numerous small, erythematous papules and plaques which are pruritic represents a case of guttate psoriasis. Streptococcal tonsillitis is a common preceding infection for guttate psoriasis.

Guttate psoriasis is characterized by the acute eruption of numerous small, erythematous papules and plaques. The term "guttate" refers to the discrete, drop-like appearance of skin lesions. It is usually seen in children and young adults and is preceded by streptococcal tonsillitis. The infection can also precipitate chronic plaque psoriasis but to a lesser extent. Additionally, perianal streptococcal infections may also cause guttate psoriasis in children.

The lesions are from 2 or 3 mm to 1 cm in diameter, round or slightly oval. They are scattered more or less evenly over the body, particularly on the trunk and proximal part of the limbs.

The diagnosis is made from the nature of the scaling, the general distribution, and the evidence of preceding streptococcal infection.

First-line management for guttate psoriasis involves UV light phototherapy and the use of topical corticosteroids and topical vitamin D analogs such as calcipotriol or calcipotriene.

Image: Guttate Psoriasis

questions.text: Which of the following factors causes increased secretion of aldosterone?
questions.solution:
Hyperkalemia and activation of the renin-angiotensin system are the most potent stimulators of aldosterone secretion.

The following factors are known to affect the regulation of aldosterone: 

  • Hyperkalemia increases aldosterone secretion.
  • Increased angiotensin II concentration increases aldosterone secretion.
  • Hypernatremia slightly decreases aldosterone secretion.
  • ANP secreted by the heart, decreases aldosterone secretion
  • ACTH from the anterior pituitary gland is necessary for aldosterone secretion but has minimal effect in physiological conditions.

Hyperaldosteronism may be primary or secondary.

Primary

  • Primary hyperaldosteronism occurs due to autonomous overproduction of aldosterone, with resultant suppression of the renin-angiotensin system and decreased plasma renin activity.
  • Blood pressure elevation is the most common manifestation of primary hyperaldosteronism
  • Hypokalemia was considered a mandatory feature of primary hyperaldosteronism.
  • The diagnosis of primary hyperaldosteronism is confirmed by elevated ratios of plasma aldosterone concentration to plasma renin activity.
  • When primary hyperaldosteronism is caused by a solitary aldosterone-secreting adenoma, the condition is referred to as Conn syndrome. Aldosterone-producing adenomas show the presence of eosinophilic, laminated cytoplasmic inclusions, known as spironolactone bodies. These spironolactone bodies are found after treatment with the antihypertensive drug spironolactone.

Secondary hyperaldosteronism

  • Aldosterone release occurs in response to the activation of the renin-angiotensin system, and may be seen in cirrhosis, heart failure, and nephrosis.

questions.text:
The following diagram charts the population change over years from 1983 to 1989 in a given place. Choose the correct statements regarding this type of graphical representation.
  1. It is used mainly for nominal or ordinal scale data.
  2. Ogive can be constructed using this.
  3. Used for discrete categories instead of continuous groups.
  4. The mid-points of the columns can be joined to form a frequency polygon. 
  5. It is a compound bar chart
questions.solution:
The given image shows a component bar graph or a component bar chart. The bars can be divided into two or more parts where each part represents a certain item, proportional to the magnitude of that particular item (males and females in this image).

It is used mainly for nominal or ordinal scale data.

The difference between a bar graph and a histogram is that the rectangles are separated by spaces representing data that forms discrete categories instead of continuous groups. Frequency polygon and Ogive can be constructed using a histogram, not a component bar chart

 

The given image shows a multiple bar chart or a compound bar chart where two or more bars can be grouped together (eg: PSA levels along with age groups).

Related Pearl: Graphical Representation of Data

1. Histogram

  • A histogram, by definition, is a graphical representation of frequency distribution that contains rectangles and shows the underlying frequency of a set of continuous, quantitative data.
  • The X or horizontal axis is called the abscissa which usually has the group scores or class intervals of the variables/data and the Y or vertical axis is called the ordinate which usually shows the frequencies at which these variables appear.
  • The following image shows a histogram.

2. Bar Chart

  • It is also called a bar graph.
  • It is used mainly for nominal or ordinal scale data as they are not quantitative and usually qualitative.
  • The difference between a bar graph and a histogram is that the rectangles are separated by spaces representing data that forms discrete categories instead of continuous groups.
  • Bar graphs can be simple, multiple or component bar graphs.

3. Pie Charts

  • Pie charts are also used for nominal or ordinal data.
  • The categorical data are represented as segments of a circle.

4. Frequency polygons

  • Frequency polygons are used for mainly ratio and interval scale data.
  • In a frequency polygon, the mid-points of each class interval are joined together by straight lines.

5. Ogive

  • A frequency polygon which is drawn to represent cumulative frequency distributions form a typical S-shaped curve which is called an ogive. It referred to as a cumulative frequency diagram.

6. Line chart

  • It is also called a line diagram or line graph.
  • Its best use is to show the trend of events or change over passage of time.

questions.text: A primigravida delivered a healthy baby at 39 weeks of gestation. The mother is positive for HBsAg and negative for HBeAg. What is the next most appropriate step for the infant?

choices.text: Both active and passive immunization right after birth
Passive immunization soon after birth and active immunization at 1 year
Only passive immunization soon after birth
Only active immunization soon after birth

questions.solution:
Infants born to HbsAg-positive mothers should receive both Hepatitis B immunoglobulin and HB vaccine.

These have to be administered intramuscularly at separate sites within 12 hours of birth, followed by 2nd and 3rd dose of vaccine at 1 and 6 months respectively.

Mothers with an HBV DNA viral load >200,000 IU/mL should receive an anti-viral such as telbivudine, lamivudine, or tenofovir during the 3rd trimester, especially if they had a previous child who developed chronic HBV after receiving HBIG and the hepatitis B vaccine.

As per the updated recommendations by WHO, pregnant women testing positive for HBV infection (HBsAg+ve) with HBV DNA ≥ 200,000 IU/mL should receive Tenofovir prophylaxis from the 28th week of pregnancy until birth, to prevent mother-to-child transmission of HBV. This is in addition to three-dose hepatitis B vaccination in all infants.

questions.text: Postmortem examination of a body reveals copious froth from the mouth, nose, and air passages. There is hemorrhage into the middle ears, subpleural hemorrhages at the base of the lungs, and emphysema aquosum, prompting suspicion of drowning. Which of the following findings would strongly suggest that the person was alive when he drowned?
questions.solution:
Cadaveric spasm strongly indicates that the person was alive when he drowned because it indicates the struggle of the person for his life. 

Weeds, gravel, grass, sticks, twigs, and leaves present in the water may be firmly grasped in the hands due to cadaveric spasms. 

Autopsy findings in drowning:

  • Froth in the air passages - The most useful autopsy sign in drowning. It consists of a proteinaceous exudate and surfactant mixed with the water of the drowning medium.
  • Waterlogging of the lung - Frothy fluid will exude from the bronchi when the lung is squeezed and from the cut surfaces when they are sectioned with a knife. But the absence of waterlogging by no means excludes true drowning (e.g. dry drowning).
  • Emphysema aqueosum - Overinflation of the lungs
  • Paltauf’s spots - Subpleural hemorrhages that probably reflect hemolysis within intra-alveolar hemorrhages
  • Dilation of the right heart and great veins - This is a very subjective and non-specific finding.
  • Foreign material in the stomach - The stomach may contain watery fluid or even foreign material from the water, such as silt, weed, and sand. This is also not a finding that can diagnose drowning.
  • Hemorrhage into the middle ears and into the temporal bone - This has been postulated as a positive sign of drowning, it is a non-specific finding.
  • Presence of fluid in the middle ear or paranasal sinuses 

Note - The autopsy findings in drowning are mostly nonspecific and none give conclusive evidence of drowning. 

Other options:

Option B: Cutis anserina (goose-skin or goose-flesh), in which the skin has a granular and puckered appearance can be seen on the anterior surfaces of the body, especially on the thighs.  It is produced by the spasm of the erector pilae muscles, attached to each hair follicle, and can occur in the living when the skin comes in contact with cold water. It can occur on submersion of the body in cold water immediately after death, while the muscles were still warm and irritable. It can also be produced by rigor mortis of the erector muscles.

Option C: The presence of sand, fluid, debris, weeds, vegetation, and other foreign material in the nostrils or upper airways is not a sign of antemortem drowning.

Option D: Washerwoman’s hands is a specific change that is seen in the skin of the palm and sole, which comprises of wrinkled, swollen, whitish sodden appearance of hands or feet. It can also be considered as water maceration of the skin of the hand, due to the absorption of water into the outer layers of the skin. Although the changes in washerwomen’s hands and feet are usually seen in dead bodies recovered from the water, this cannot be considered a sign of antemortem drowning.

questions.text: A 66-year-old woman presents to the emergency department after slipping in her bathroom. She now experiences pain in her right hip after the fall and is unable to bear weight. Her menopause began 18 years ago. On physical exam, her right leg is in external rotation and abduction, with visible shortening. X-ray reveals a fracture of the neck of the femur.  Her DXA report indicates her T score is -2.7. Considering the most likely condition that underlies this patient's pathology, what is the recommended age at which screening for the underlying condition should begin?
questions.solution:
The clinical vignette describes a case of femoral neck fracture due to underlying osteoporosis with fragility fracture. Bone mineral density screening begins at 65 years.

Osteoporosis is characterized by increased bone resorption, decreased bone formation, or both. There is also a loss of structural connectivity in the trabecular bones. All these factors lead to loss of bone strength and make them susceptible to fractures.

The clinical diagnosis of osteoporosis is established by

  • Fragility fracture(commonly of the spine, hip, wrist, humerus, rib, and pelvis) - those occurring spontaneously or from minor trauma, such as a fall from a standing height or less.
  • T-score ≤-2.5 standard deviations (SDs)

The criteria for screening for osteoporosis are:

  • Women >65 years of age
  • Men >70 years of age
  • Selected post-menopausal women who are 50–69 years with risk factors for fractures.

World Osteoporosis Day (WOD), on October 20 each year, marks a year-long campaign dedicated to raising global awareness of the prevention, screening, early diagnosis and treatment of osteoporosis.

questions.text: A 24-year-old male presents with fever and pain over his thigh. Physical examination is remarkable for a mid-thigh swelling. X-ray findings are shown below and immune-histochemical staining is positive for MIC-2.  All of the following factors would have prognostic significance except:
questions.solution:
Histologic grade is of no prognostic significance because all Ewing's sarcomas are considered high grade.

A diaphyseal tumor presenting with fever, pain, and swelling suggests Ewing's sarcoma. Classically, Ewing's sarcoma appears radiographically as a destructive lesion in the diaphysis with the lamellar "onion skin" periosteal reaction. Immunohistochemical staining for MIC-2 is specific for Ewing’s sarcoma. It has its highest incidence in the second decade of life.

Indicators of poor prognosis

  • Presence of distant metastasis - Worst prognostic factor
  • Size of the primary lesion
  • Presence of fever, anemia
  • Leukocytosis
  • Raised ESR
  • Raised LDH
  • Male child 
  • Older age at presentation (cut off at 12–15 years)

Note: Beta 2 microglobulin is an indicator of poor prognosis in multiple myeloma.

questions.text: A gardener presents with multiple vesicles on the hands and multiple eruptions along the lymphatic distribution. The lesions are limited to cutaneous tissues. On microscopy of tissue biopsy, flower-like clusters of conidia are seen. Which of the following statements is false about this disease?

choices.text: Medlar bodies are seen in this condition
It is caused by a dimorphic fungus
Itraconazole will be effective in this case
It is an example of subcutaneous mycoses

questions.solution:
The presence of multiple vesicles on the hands and multiple eruptions along lymphatics in a gardener and the microscopic finding of flower-like clusters of conidia are suggestive of sporotrichosis caused by Sporothrix schenckii.  In sporotrichosis, medlar bodies will not be seen. Medlar bodies or sclerotic bodies are seen in chromoblastomycosis.

Chromoblastomycosis is a subcutaneous fungal infection caused by many species. In tissue, the lesions appear as spherical brown cells termed muriform or sclerotic bodies that divide by transverse septation.

S. schenckii is a dimorphic fungus that lives on vegetation such as grasses, trees, rose bushes, etc. It occurs in the yeast phase in tissues and in cultures at 37°C, and in the mycelia phase in nature and cultures at 25°C. The septate hyphae appear very thin and carry flower-like clusters of small conidia borne on delicate sterigmata. Asteroid bodies seen in sporotrichosis consist of a central basophilic yeast cell surrounded by radiating extensions of eosinophilic material.

Following traumatic inoculation into the skin as in thorn prick, S. schenckii causes sporotrichosis, a chronic granulomatous infection. The initial lesion appears following a trauma or thorn prick. The infection then spreads via the lymphatic channels to the lymph nodes. This results in secondary ulcers on the lymph nodes.

Treatment: 

  • Cutaneous form can be treated with oral or topical potassium iodide
  • Lymphocutaneous form – Itraconazole is effective in over 90% of patients with lymphocutaneous infection
  • For disseminated infection, amphotericin B is the drug of choice.

questions.text:
A 7-year-old boy presented with progressive muscular weakness. On examination, it is noted that he uses his hands to walk up the body from a squatting position. His lower limb appears as depicted in the image shown below. Lab testing shows increased CK levels and diagnosis is made based on genetic analysis that shows dystrophin deletion. Which of the following tests must be done periodically as a part of regular surveillance in this patient?
  1. ECG
  2. Echocardiography
  3. Vital capacity
  4. ABG
questions.solution:
The given picture shows pseudohypertrophy of calf muscles, also the child is unable to get up from a squatting position. This is characteristically seen in Duchenne muscular dystrophy. Surveillance testing should include

  • ECG, to monitor for arrhythmia
  • Echocardiography to screen for dilated cardiomyopathy
  • Vital capacity in sitting position - From 5-6 years of age  Monitored on a yearly basis during the ambulatory stage 

 

Salient features of Duchenne muscular dystrophy:

  • Most common hereditary neuromuscular disease.
  • X-linked recessive deletion of dystrophin gene on chromosome Xp21.

Clinical features

  • Progressive weakness, developmental delay, and intellectual impairment
  • In toddlers: delayed walking, falling, toe walking, and trouble running or walking upstairs
  • Common sites of muscular hypertrophy: calf > tongue > forearm
  • Gower's sign: Patient has to use their hands and arms to walk up their own body from squatting position due to the lack of hip and thigh muscle strength due to the weakness of proximal muscles, especially of the lower limbs.
  • Trendelenburg gait/hip waddle
  • Complications: Contractures, scoliosis, cardiomyopathy, malignant hyperthermia after anesthesia.
  • The patient is unable to walk by the age of 12 years and death occurs by 18–20 years of age, due to respiratory failure.

Diagnosis

  • Elevated serum creatine kinase levels
  • Polymerase chain reaction (PCR) analysis for the dystrophin gene
  • If PCR is normal, but clinical suspicion is high, muscle biopsy with dystrophin immunocytochemistry is done.

Surveillance:

  • Electrocardiogram, echocardiography, or cardiac magnetic resonance imaging (MRI) to detect cardiomyopathy.
  • Vital capacity starting at five to six years of age. Once the patient is nonambulatory - seated vital capacity, maximum inspiratory pressure, maximum expiratory pressure, peak cough flow, blood oxygen saturation by pulse oximetry (SpO2), end-tidal or transcutaneous partial pressure of carbon dioxide in the blood (pCO2)

Image: Gower's sign

questions.text: A researcher is studying the calculation for total body water and its distribution into intracellular compartments. Which combination of dyes can she use to measure this?
questions.solution:
Intracellular fluid(ICF) volume can be measured using a combination of inulin and tritium.

Total body fluid (TBW) is distributed between extracellular fluid (ECF) and intracellular fluid (ICF). Extracellular fluid (ECF) can be divided into interstitial fluid and blood plasma. ICF is measured indirectly. 

Intracellular fluid (ICF) = Total body water (TBW) - extracellular fluid (ECF)

Radioactive sodium, radioactive chloride, radioactive iothalamate, thiosulfate ion, and inulin can be used to measure ECF volume. Tritium and deuterium can be used to measure TBW.

  • In ECF, a third specialized compartment, called the transcellular compartment (not shown in flow chart), is quantitatively small and includes the cerebrospinal, pleural, peritoneal, pericardial, synovial, intraocular and digestive fluids. Altogether it constitutes about 1-2 L.
  • The ECF volume/intracellular fluid volume ratio is larger in infants and children than it is in adults, but the absolute volume of ECF in children is, of course, smaller than in adults. Therefore, dehydration develops more rapidly and is frequently more severe in children.
  • All solutes and water that enter or leave the body do so via the ECF.
  • The ICF and ECF are in osmotic equilibrium. Water moves between these compartments only when an osmotic pressure gradient exists.
  • Equilibration of ICF and ECF osmolality occurs primarily by shifts in water and not shifts in solutes.

questions.text: A 33-year-old man with thyroid disease, presents with a history of weakness and fatigue for the past three months. There is no history of alcohol consumption. A complete blood count and peripheral smear show megaloblastic anemia and a normal reticulocyte count. He is found to have vitamin B12 deficiency and on further laboratory testing,  anti-parietal antibodies are present. Which of the following is incorrect regarding this type of gastritis?

choices.text: Adenocarcinoma is a long term complication.

questions.solution:
The given scenario is suggestive of autoimmune gastritis. Autoimmune gastritis typically spares the antrum.

Autoimmune gastritis causes diffuse mucosal damage of the acid-producing mucosa, within the body and fundus. It accounts for less than 10% of cases of chronic gastritis. CD4+T cells directed against parietal cell components, including the H+, K+ - ATPase, are considered to be the principal agents of injury in autoimmune gastritis.

Other characteristic features seen in autoimmune gastritis:

  • Antibodies to parietal cells and intrinsic factor
  • Reduced serum pepsinogen I concentration
  • Hypergastrinemia
  • Endocrine cell hyperplasia → Carcinoid tumors
  • Vitamin B12 deficiency (pernicious anemia)
  • Defective gastric acid secretion (achlorhydria)

questions.text: Which of the following statements is false according to the following table?

choices.text: 92% of people with MI have a positive ECG.
There is a 75 % chance that a person who has a negative ECG actually does not have MI.
There is a 75 % chance that a person who has a positive ECG actually has MI.
90% of people without MI have a negative ECG.

questions.solution:
43% of people without MI have a negative ECG or the specificity of this test is 43%. Specificity is the percentage of healthy individuals who are correctly identified (as healthy).

Solution:

a = 300, b = 100, c = 25, d =75

A. Predictive value of a positive test (PPV) 

= TP/(TP + FP) x 100 = a/(a+b) x 100

=300/(300+100) x 100

= 300/400 x 100

= 75 % 

There is a 75 % chance that a person who has a positive ECG actually has MI in this case.

 

B. Predictive value of a negative test (NPV)

= TN/(FN + TN) x 100 = d/(c+d) x 100

=75/(25+75) x 100

= 75 %

There is a 75 % chance that a person who has a negative ECG actually does not have MI.

 Hence PPV = NPV

 

 In this scenario, sensitivity is 92% and the specificity is 43% as per the following calculation:

Sensitivity = TP/(TP + FN) x 100 = a/(a+c) x100 = 300/(300+25) x100 = 92%

92% of people with MI have a positive ECG.

 

Specificity = TN/(FP + TN) x 100 = d/(b+d) x 100 = 75/(100+75) x100 = 43%

 43% of people without MI have a negative ECG.

Related Pearl: Validity of a Screening Test

  • Validity/ accuracy of a screening test depends upon the sensitivity, specificity, and predictive accuracy of the test.
  • It represents the closeness to a true value/ actual value.
  • These are the inherent properties of a screening test.
  • PPV and NPV are dependent on the Prevalence of disease.
  • Sensitivity & Specificity are independent of prevalence of disease.

Related Pearl: Evaluation of diagnostic tests

Different ways of asking the following parameters:

Sensitivity (True positive rate) 

  • Percentage of diseased individuals who are correctly identified (as diseased).
  • Proportion of all people with the disease who test positive.
  • Probability that when the disease is present, the test is positive.

Specificity (True negative rate) 

  • Percentage of healthy individuals who are correctly identified (as healthy).
  • Proportion of all people without the disease who test negative.
  • Probability that when the disease is absent, the test is negative.

Positive predictive value 

  • Probability that a person who has a positive test result actually has the disease.
  • If the test is positive, what is the probability that the patient has the disease?

Negative predictive value 

  • Probability that a person who has a negative test result actually does not have the disease.
  • If the test is negative, what is the probability that the patient does not have the disease?

questions.text: Which of the following is incorrect regarding atrial myxomas?

choices.text: Stellate or globular cells can be seen
More commonly seen  in the right atrium
Most common primary tumor of the adult heart
Most common site of origin is fossa ovalis in the atrial septum

questions.solution:
Myxomas are the most common primary tumor of the heart in adults and atrial myxoma is most commonly located in the left atrium.

Myxomas are benign neoplasms that arise from primitive multipotent mesenchymal cells. 90 percent of myxoma are located in the atria, sporadic, and are usually single. The left-to-right ratio of the myxoma is approximately 4:1. The most common site of origin is fossa ovalis in the atrial septum. 

They mainly present with symptoms that mimic mitral valve disease. A characteristic low pitched sound, a "tumor plop", is heard on auscultation during early or mid diastole as a result of the impact from the tumor against the mitral valve or ventricular wall.

They also present with constitutional symptoms like fever, cachexia, and malaise due to the elevation of cytokines like interleukin 6. 

Myxomas are composed of stellate or globular myxoma cells embedded within an acid mucopolysaccharide ground substance. Peculiar vessel-like or gland-like structures are characteristically seen along with hemorrhage and mononuclear inflammation.

The image below shows an abundant amorphous extracellular matrix containing scattered multinucleate myxoma cells in various groupings, including abnormal vessel-like formations.

Mobile tumors exert a “wrecking-ball” effect, causing damage to the valve leaflets.

Myoma can be sessile or pedunculated lesions. They appear as a globular hard mass mottled with hemorrhage arising from the fossa ovalis as shown below.

Transesophageal/ Transthoracic echocardiography (TTE) is the diagnostic investigation.

The below image of TTE shows a mass in the left atrium suggestive of atrial myxoma.

Surgical excision is done regardless of the tumor size.

questions.text: A baby presented with the following appearance and a history of seizures. Which of the following is unlikely to be seen in this condition?

choices.text: Tram-track calcification in the cerebral cortex

questions.solution:
The image shows a baby with a port-wine stain occurring in the distribution of the trigeminal nerve, which is seen in Sturge-Weber syndrome. Lisch nodules are unlikely to be seen in this condition. They are iris hamartomas, seen in neurofibromatosis.

Features of port wine stain:

  • Does not fade with time
  • Special form of nevus flammeus
  • Tend to grow during childhood
  • Thicken the skin surface

Sturge–Weber syndrome shows the following features:

  • Facial port-wine nevi
  • Ipsilateral venous angiomas in the cortical leptomeninges
  • Mental retardation
  • Seizures, hemiplegia
  • Skull radio-opacities

Ocular manifestations -

  • Glaucoma — The predominant ocular abnormality of SWS is glaucoma (increased intraocular pressure), which occurs in 30 to 70 percent of affected patients.
  • Visual field defects — Many patients have visual field defects, typically homonymous hemianopia. This is due to the presence of a leptomeningeal capillary-venous malformation affecting one or both occipital lobes or optic tracts.
  • Capillary -venous malformation of the choroid.
  • Heterochromia of the iris
  • Episcleral and conjunctival lesions.

Image shows tram-track calcification associated with Sturge–Weber syndrome.

Related Pearl: Tram Track Appearance in Various Conditions

Tram tracks or tram track signs are medical signs that bear some resemblance to tramway tracks (Railway Track).

1. Pulmonology

  • When found in the lungs, tram tracks are radiologic signs that are usually accompanied by pulmonary edema in cases of congestive heart failure and bronchiectasis.
  • Tram tracks are caused by bronchial wall thickening, and can be detected on a lateral chest X-ray.

2. Nephrology

  • The term "tram tracks" is also used to describe the basement membrane duplication found on light microscopy that is characteristic of membranoproliferative glomerulonephritis (MPGN) type I.
  • It is less commonly associated with types II and III.

3. Neurology

  • The term has also been used to describe findings associated with optic nerve sheath meningioma.
  • Tram track-shaped calcifications in the cerebral cortex indicate Sturge-Weber syndrome.

4. Mammary glands:

  • Tram track appearance in mammography/USG indicates Duct Ectasia.

questions.text: A 14-year-old boy presents with a history of vomiting within 3 hours of consumption of food at a party. Gram-positive cocci in clusters were isolated from the food samples collected at the party. The isolated organism formed beta-hemolytic colonies on sheep blood agar. Which of the following statements is incorrect about the organism most likely to cause these symptoms?

choices.text: Negative mannitol fermentation test is seen.
It is catalase-positive and coagulase positive.
Forms small, pink  colonies on MacConkey agar due to lactose fermentation.

questions.solution:
The most likely causative organism in the given scenario is Staphylococcus aureus. It causes food poisoning within 1 to 6 hours after consumption of the contaminated food. Gram-positive cocci in clusters that form beta-hemolytic colonies on sheep blood agar indicate that the organism is staphylococcus aureus. It shows a positive mannitol fermentation test.

The common sources of infection are foods that are not cooked after handling. These include ham, poultry, potato or egg salad, mayonnaise, cream pastries. Patients present with nausea, vomiting, stomach cramps, and diarrhea.

They are coagulase-positive, catalase-positive, hydrolyse urea, reduce nitrates to nitrites, etc

Enterotoxin produced by staphylococcus:

  • It is a preformed toxin that is heat stable (Most of the other exotoxins are heat-labile).
  • Around eight antigenic types of enterotoxin are currently known. Most of the cases are caused by type A toxin. The toxin is believed to act directly on the autonomic nervous system than on the gastrointestinal mucosa. The toxin is antigenic in nature.
  • They are superantigens and are potent activators of T-lymphocytes.

 Another organism causing food poisoning within the same time period of 2-6 hrs is Bacillus cereus.

questions.text:
An 8-year-old girl child is scheduled for a tonsillectomy. Prior to endotracheal intubation, she is given IV propofol, followed by an agent, labeled "A" as shown below. The procedure is completed as planned and the anesthetist now administered a new drug (a gamma-cyclodextrin), labeled "B" in the image to reverse its effect. Read the statements given below and choose the correct statements.
  1. "A" is a non-depolarizing skeletal muscle relaxant
  2. "B" is excreted unchanged in the urine complexed with the blocking agent used
  3. "A" is a depolarizing skeletal muscle relaxant
  4. The order of affinity of "B" for "A" is  - rocuronium, vecuronium, and pancuronium
  5. The order of affinity of "B" for "A" is  - succinylcholine, pancuronium, and vecuronium
  6. "B" has no effect on atracurium
questions.solution:
In the given clinical scenario, a non-depolarizing agent, rocuronium (labeled "A" in the image) is used for induction prior to endotracheal intubation. Following the surgical procedure, a newer drug, gamma-cyclodextrin ("B" in the image), sugammadex is used to reverse its action.

Sugammadex has the most affinity for rocuronium and has no effect on succinylcholine and benzylisoquinoline NMBAs such as atracurium. 

The graph shows the train-of-four monitoring to assess the neuromuscular block in an anesthetized patient. The fade in the graph indicates non-depolarizing neuromuscular blocking agent which is reversed by sugammadex. 

Sugammadex is a novel reversal agent for rocuronium and vecuronium.

Sugammadex is a modified gamma-cyclodextrin that binds rocuronium and vecuronium tightly and decreases the concentration of free plasma levels.

A specific reversal agent for rocuronium, i.e., sugammadex can terminate the action of rocuronium.

Sugammadex is a cyclodextrin. It is the first selective relaxant binding agent. It exerts its reversal effect by forming tight complexes in a 1:1 ratio with steroidal non-depolarizing agents (rocuronium > vecuronium >> pancuronium).Since rocuronium is a steroidal agent, it is specifically bound by sugammadex.

Sugammadex is essentially eliminated unchanged via the kidneys.

Rocuronium at a dose of 0.6 mg/ kg intravenously is commonly used to provide muscle relaxation during routine intubation in pediatric patients because of its faster onset and it can be administered intramuscularly. For rapid sequence induction, a higher dose (0.9-1.2 mg/kg) can be used.

A disadvantage with rocuronium is its long duration of action and the possibility of hypersensitivity reaction.

questions.text:
A 38-year-old nulliparous woman comes to the clinic for evaluation of abnormal menstrual bleeding. Her menses occur regularly, once every 33 days, but the bleeding is prolonged and heavy, lasting about 10 days with clots. She also complains of crampy abdominal pain and pelvic pressure. She is a current smoker. She has previously had similar symptoms for which she was worked up and treated medically. She does not desire future fertility and wants to undergo surgical management for her recurrent symptoms. Physical examination shows an obese woman with a palpable abdominopelvic mass. Bimanual examination reveals an enlarged, irregular uterus. Surgery is performed and the gross specimen is shown. Which of the following statements is true about her condition?
  1. Smoking increases the risk of developing this condition
  2. It contains a higher density of estrogen receptors necessary for growth
  3. It is surrounded by a true capsule
  4. Nulliparity decreases the risk of developing this condition
  5. Obesity increases the risk
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario describes a case of leiomyoma uteri or fibroid uterus. The specimen is of a leiomyoma. Fibroids contain increased numbers of estrogen receptors to create a hyperestrogenic state to aid in growth. Obesity is an important risk factor.

MED12 and HMGA2 gene mutations are the most common genes associated with leiomyomas.

Gross specimen appearance:

  • The uterine body/corpus is enlarged and deformed.
  • The cut surface shows multiple nodules, well-circumscribed, firm, white-greyish with a whorled appearance formed by the intersecting bundles of brown muscle fibers and white fibrous tissue.
  • Leiomyomas can also present bleeding areas, cystic degeneration, and calcifications. The uterine cavity is compressed.
  • A typical myoma is a well-circumscribed tumor with a pseudo capsule and firm inconsistency. The cut surface has a whorled appearance.
  • The vessels that supply blood to the tumor lie in the capsule and send radial branches into the tumor.
  • Therefore, the central portion of the tumour­ receives the least blood supply and degeneration is noticeable early in this part of the tumour­.
  • On the other hand, calcification begins at the periphery and spreads inwards along the vessels. 

Risk factors:

  • Increased risk is seen in nulliparous women, obesity, hyper estrogenic state (endometriosis, endometrial hyperplasia, endometrial carcinoma), and black women.
  • Decreased risk in multiparous women.
  • Recent studies have shown no correlation between smoking and leiomyomas

Pathophysiology:

Leiomyomas create a hyperestrogenic environment, which appears requisite for their growth and maintenance.

Main mechanisms:

  • Compared to normal myometrium, leiomyoma cells contain a greater density of estrogen receptors, which results in greater estradiol binding.
  • These tumors convert less estradiol to the weaker estrone.
  • There are higher levels of cytochrome P450 aromatase in leiomyomas compared with normal myocytes. This specific enzyme catalyzes the conversion of androgens to estrogen.

Symptoms of fibroid uterus:

  • Most women with leiomyomas are asymptomatic. However, affected women may complain of bleeding, pain, pressure, or infertility.
  • In general, symptom risk increases with myoma size and number.
  • Bleeding is common, especially heavy menstrual bleeding (HMB), and dilated endometrial venules are implicated.
  • Dysregulation of local vasoactive growth factors is thought to promote this vasodilatation.
  • When engorged venules are disrupted at the time of menstrual sloughing, bleeding from these markedly dilated vessels overwhelms the usual hemostatic mechanisms. Hence, subserosal, intramural, and submucous tumors all have a propensity to cause heavy menstrual bleeding.

Treatment:

Medical therapy for fibroids includes mifepristone, GnRh analogs, Aromatase inhibitors

Drugs to reduce the size of the fibroid

  • Antiprogesterone – Mifepristone/RU-486
  • Danazol (Usually not used due to androgenic side effects)
  • GnRH analogs
    • Agonists – goserelin, leuprorelin, nafarelin, buserelin

questions.text: A researcher is studying the phases of the ventricular muscle action potential as shown below. Which phase represents the closing of fast sodium channels?
questions.solution:
Phase 1 represents the closure of fast sodium channels.

Phases of the cardiac muscle action potential:

Phase 0 (Depolarization): Opening of fast sodium channels. When the cardiac cell is stimulated, the fast sodium channels(voltage-gated sodium channels) open and cause sodium influx. This depolarizes the cell and the membrane potential becomes positive. It reached about +20 mV and the sodium channels close. 

Phase 1 (Initial repolarization): Closing of fast sodium channels. The fast sodium channel close and the potassium channels open. the potassium ions leave the cell leading to repolarisation. 

Phase 2 (Plateau): Fast potassium channels close and calcium channels open. The slowly opening voltage-gated Ca2+ channels start opening in phases 0 and 1. The influx of calcium through these channels is balanced by the decrease in the efflux of potassium via the potassium channels. This produces the plateau. 

Phase 3 (Rapid repolarization): Slow potassium channels open and calcium channels close. The potassium ions leave the cell through slow potassium channels and the calcium channels close stopping the influx of calcium ions. This ends the plateau and brings the membrane potential to resting level. 

Phase 4 (Resting membrane potential):  around −80 to −90 millivolts.

questions.text: As a researcher employed in a pharmaceutical company, you are involved in a clinical trial. A monoclonal antibody for the treatment of renal cell carcinoma (RCC) is entering phase III of the clinical trial. Which of these statements correctly describes this phase?

choices.text: 250 healthy volunteers from the general population, randomized and blinded
2946 patients with RCC, randomized and double-blinded
96 healthy volunteers in an open-label study, to study adverse effects
5548 patients with RCC in an open-label observational study

questions.solution:
Phase III trials are usually done on 500–3000 patients with the disease, and these are randomized double-blinded studies.

Phase III trials are usually considered pivotal trials that are necessary for the approval of the majority of drugs. They are also called a multisite trial, which is done for 3–5 years. This phase confirms the efficacy of the drug. It is also done to study the long-term or rare side effects of this drug. 

When the initial phase III trials are complete, the sponsor (usually a pharmaceutical company) applies to the FDA for approval to market the drug. This application is called either a new drug application (NDA) or a biologics license application (BLA).

Note: In some drugs related to rare diseases or oncology, phase II studies are considered pivotal, and the drug may be approved on the basis of phase II studies.

Other phases of clinical trials:

Preclinical trials are performed on animals and they are regulated by guidelines prescribed by the committee for the purpose of the control and supervision of experiments on animals (CPCSEA) in India. Standards for the conduct of clinical trials involving Indian subjects are laid down in good clinical practice (GCP).

Phase I clinical trials are performed on healthy volunteers in an open-label study to determine the safety, tolerability, and pharmacokinetic properties of the drug.

Phase II clinical trials are conducted to evaluate the appropriate dose range of the drug. It is evaluated on a small group of patients (50-500) with the target disease. Most of the new drugs will be administered for the first time in patients with the target disease.

The study is designed to obtain proof of concept (potential of the drug to treat the disease) and dose-ranging study (provides input for choosing the most appropriate dose for phase III studies).

Phase IV clinical trials are conducted after the drug is marketed and approved by regulatory authorities. It includes post-marketing surveillance and other studies that complement the earlier findings on the drug.

questions.text: A 56-year-old woman presents with persistent soreness of the nipple of the right breast. A crusted red, eczematous rash is present on the areola of the right breast. Histopathology shows malignant cells scattered individually throughout the squamous epithelium. These cells are periodic acid Schiff (PAS) positive and diastase resistant. What is the likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
In the given clinical scenario, the presence of a crusted red, eczematous rash on the areola with histopathology revealing malignant cells that are PAS positive and diastase resistant is suggestive of Paget's disease of the nipple.

Paget’s disease is a unique type of DCIS arising in the nipple. It presents as a unilateral erythematous eruption with crusting. Patient complaints of pruritus. It may become invasive with metastasis to the axillary lymph nodes.

Histology shows Paget cells, with abundant pale cytoplasm and pleomorphic nuclei, scattered individually throughout the squamous epithelium. Paget cells do not breach the basement membrane, they rather extend via the lactiferous sinuses into the nipple skin.

The underlying carcinomas are usually poorly differentiated, ER-negative, and overexpress HER2. A triple assessment is needed to exclude underlying malignancy. Paget’s disease without associated underlying malignancy is treated by central core excision followed by radiotherapy. Paget’s disease with underlying malignancy is treated by mastectomy and evaluation of the axillary nodal status.

Other options:

Option B: Mondor’s disease is thrombophlebitis of the superficial veins of the breast and anterior chest wall. The pathognomonic feature is a thrombosed subcutaneous cord which is usually attached to the skin.

Option C: Zuska’s disease, also called recurrent periductal mastitis, is a condition of recurrent retroareolar infections and abscesses. Smoking has been implicated as a risk factor for this condition.

Option D: Tietze syndrome is inflammation of the costochondral junction. Clinical features include pain in the lateral chest wall in the anterior axillary line and over the serratus anterior.

questions.text:
A 36-year-old multigravida at 36-weeks gestation comes to the emergency room of a tertiary care hospital with a history of painless vaginal bleeding. She recalls waking up to see blood on her bedsheets. On examination, her vitals are within normal limits. There is no active bleeding at present. Abdominal examination shows the uterus to be relaxed and soft. The symphysiofundal height (SFH) is approximately 35cm. Leopold maneuver show the head to be floating and cannot be pushed into the pelvis. There is a characteristic slowing of the heart rate when the head is pressed into the pelvis. She does not feel any contractions. Laboratory studies reveal a Hb of 10.3 g/dL and hematocrit of 33%. Non-stress test done is shown below and ultrasound does not reveal any abnormalities. Read the following about this patient's condition and pick out the correct statements.
  1. This patient needs immediate termination of pregnancy
  2. This patient should be given betamethasone 30 mg IM
  3. This patient can be managed expectantly
  4. Stallworthy's sign is positive in this patient
  5. Hematocrit value of at least 35% is a pre-requisite for expectant management in this patient
questions.solution:
The clinical scenario describes a classical case of placenta previa. This patient at 36 weeks gestation, with a reactive NST (the image shows an NST with baseline heart rate around 120 bpm, multiple accelerations and good variability), Hb > 10g% and hematocrit >30% can be managed expectantly. 

Risk factors for placenta previa

  • Multigravida
  • Age > 35 years
  • Smoking
  • Previous cesarean section or myomectomy
  • Abnormal placental size and lobes
  • Prior curettage

Clinical features of placenta previa:

  • Sudden-onset recurrent painless vaginal bleeding: First bleeding usually appears after the end of the second trimester or later and is usually mild and not fatal. This is called ‘Sentinel bleed’. 
  • The size of the uterus corresponds to gestational age. 
  • The uterus is relaxed, soft, no tenderness 
  • Floating head 
  • Fetal heart sound is present unless there is major separation and the patient is exsanguinated.
  • Slowing of fetal heart rate on pressing the head down into the pelvis which recovers promptly as pressure is relieved is suggestive of a low-lying placenta especially of posterior type: Stallworthy sign.

Degree of placenta previa:

There are four types of placenta previa depending upon the degree of extension of the placenta to the lower segment

  • Type—I (Low-lying): The major part of the placenta is attached to the upper segment and only the lower margin encroaches onto the lower segment but not up to the internal os.
  • Type—II (Marginal): The placenta reaches the margin of the internal os but does not cover it.
  • Type—III (Incomplete or partial central): The placenta covers the internal os partially (covers the
    internal os when closed but does not entirely do so when fully dilated).
  • Type—IV (Central or total): The placenta completely covers the internal os even after it is fully dilated.

Per-Vaginal Examination should not be done in suspected Placenta Previa, whereas it can be only done in the operation theatre with all the arrangements for C-section.

The image below shows the types of placenta previa.

Expectant management for placenta previa was advocated by Macafee and Johnson. The aim is to continue the pregnancy for fetal maturity without compromising maternal health. 

Prerequisites 

  • Availability of blood for transfusion whenever required 
  • Facilities for cesarean section should be available 24 h. 

Suitable cases for expectant management for placenta previa: 

  • Mother in good health (Hb ≥10 g%; hematocrit ≥30%) 
  • Duration of pregnancy <37 wk
  • No active vaginal bleeding 
  • Fetal well-being is assured (USG) 

Conduct of expectant treatment

  • Corticosteroids for fetal lung maturity if <34 wk
    • Betamethasone 12mg IM 24 hours apart for 2 doses or
    • Dexamethasone 6mg IM 12 hours apart for 4 doses
  • Bedrest 
  • Hb, Blood grouping and urine for protein 
  • Inspection of vulval pads, fetal surveillance with USG
  • Supplementary hematinics 
  • Rh Immunoglobin should be given to all Rh-negative (unsensitized) women
  • Use of tocolytics if there are uterine contractions.

The pregnancy is carried till 37 weeks as part of expectant management. During this time, if there is fetal distress or a bleeding episode, then terminate immediately.

Note - Cervical cerclage is not a part of expectant management

questions.text: You are performing CPR on a woman who is 38-weeks pregnant. She was admitted to the emergency after a massive pulmonary embolism led to cardio-pulmonary arrest. Despite the initial management of airway, oxygenation and vasopressor support, there is no improvement. What is the cut off time  for perimortem cesarean delivery in this patient?
questions.solution:
Perimortem cesarean delivery should be considered if there is no return of spontaneous circulation in 5 minutes, according to the AHA 2020 Guidelines. 

The goal of perimortem cesarean section (PMCS) should be primarily aimed at saving the life of the mother. PMCS improves maternal survival by decreasing compression of the IVC by the gravid uterus. This improves venous return and diaphragmatic displacement, which in turn improves respiratory dynamics.

questions.text: A 23-year-old male patient presents with a rash. He describes an initial lesion on his right thigh 2 weeks back. It rapidly increased in size and reached a size of around 2 cm.  One week back there was an eruption of the rash on the trunk which later spread to the rest of the trunk as shown in the image below. Which of the following organisms is not commonly associated with the eruption of this disease?
questions.solution:
The most probable diagnosis is pityriasis rosea. The patient is giving a history of herald patch on his right thigh and the image shows oval and pink lesions. Near the ribs, the long axis of the lesion is along the lines of cleavage and parallel to the ribs. Varicella-zoster virus is not commonly associated with this condition.

Pityriasis rosea is an acute self-limiting disease, probably infective in origin, affecting mainly children and young adults. It is characterized by a distinctive skin eruption and minimal constitutional symptoms. Organisms commonly associated with pityriasis rosea are - HHV 6, HHV 7, HHV 8, HSV 2, Hepatitis C, and H1N1 influenza.

The first manifestation of the disease is usually the appearance of the herald patch which is a sharply defined, erythematous, round, or oval plaque. Around 5-15 days after this it erupts into discrete oval lesions, dull pink in color and covered by fine dry silvery‐grey scales. The center clears with a marginal collarette of scale attached peripherally, with the free edge of the scale internally. It distributes in a Christmas tree pattern along the lines of cleavage.

Pityriasis circinata et maculata of Vidal is a variant of pityriasis rosea. It mainly occurs in the axilla and groin. 

Mild cases are self-limiting and do not require treatment. If the itching is worse it can be treated with topical steroids or UVB. If the lesion is associated with HHV‐6 or HHV‐7 infection, acyclovir is useful.

Related Pearl: Types of scales associated with dermatological conditions

Types of Scales and Associated Diseases

Type of Scale

Associated Disease

Collarette scale

It is a fine, peripherally attached, and centrally detached scale at the edge of an inflammatory lesion. It is seen in pityriasis rosea.

Fish-like scales

They are seen in ichthyosis vulgaris (ichthyos - fish). Ichthyotic scales are large and polygonal.

Silvery scales

They are characteristic of processes involving parakeratosis, especially psoriasis. The silvery color is due to the reflection of light at several air–keratin interfaces.

Mica-like scales

They are seen in Pityriasis lichenoides. The lesions are polymorphic with some showing hemorrhagic crusting and adherent scales.

Yellow / greasy scales

Leaf-like scales

questions.text: A 50-year-old man presents with complaints of fever, malaise, sore throat, and chills. He does not drink alcohol, denies smoking, and is sexually active with 2 men, and inconsistently uses condoms. In the past, he has been treated for urethritis. Physical examination reveals scattered lymphadenopathy. Diagnosis is confirmed by the detection of p24 antigen on ELISA testing. The patient is then started on anti-retroviral therapy. He presents several months later with findings as seen in the image. Which of the following is the cause of this finding?
questions.solution:
The clinical vignette represents a case of HIV. The above image depicts fat redistribution resulting in the classic buffalo hump appearance. Nelfinavir is the most likely cause. It is a protease inhibitor (PI) and chronic administration of PIs can result in fat redistribution & metabolic syndrome. 

Atazanavir has the least propensity to cause lipodystrophy and metabolic syndrome.

Abacavir can cause  hypersensitivity reaction In HLA-B5701+ individuals .

Tenofovir can cause renal toxicity, osteomalacia or Hep B flare in co-infected individuals.

questions.text: A 57-year-old male patient who has been diagnosed with aggressive pancreatic cancer presents with deep abdominal pain in the epigastric region. Intraoperatively, there was retroperitoneal haemorrhage due to erosion of the artery running along the superior border of the pancreas. Which of the following arteries is injured?
questions.solution:
The superior border of the pancreas is formed by the splenic artery which is marked as '4'.

Borders of the pancreas:  

Superior border: Related to the celiac artery and its branches, the common hepatic artery, and the splenic artery.

Inferior border:

  • Behind the gland, the superior mesenteric vessels emerge.
  • The inferior mesenteric vein runs behind the inferior border to join the splenic vein or where the confluence of splenic and superior mesenteric veins meet.

Posterior surface:

  • Devoid of the peritoneum.
  • Anterior to the aorta and the origin of the superior mesenteric artery, left suprarenal gland, the left crus of the diaphragm, left renal vein, and the upper pole of the left kidney surrounded by perirenal fascia 
  • The splenic vein runs on the surface from left to right

Relations of the pancreas 

1) Uncinate process: Anterior - superior mesenteric artery and superior mesenteric vein

2) Neck of the pancreas: Posterior - superior mesenteric vein and portal vein

3) Body of pancreas: Posterior - Splenic vein

4) Tail of pancreas: Present in lienorenal ligament

5) Head of the pancreas: Posterior - inferior vena cava, right and left renal vein

Blood supply of the stomach

The arterial supply of the stomach is contributed exclusively by the celiac trunk through its branches:

  • Left gastric artery - Supplies the lesser curvature of the stomach
  • Splenic artery
    • Short gastric arteries: Supplies the fundus of the stomach
    • Left gastroepiploic artery: Supplies the greater curvature of the stomach
  • Common hepatic artery
    • Right gastric artery: Supplies the lesser curvature of the stomach
    • Gastroduodenal artery: The right gastroepiploic artery arises from this and supplies the greater curvature of the stomach.

questions.text: A 12-year-old boy was diagnosed with Kearns-Sayre syndrome. Which of his relatives could be affected by the same disease?
questions.solution:
The inheritance pattern of Kearns-Sayre syndrome is mitochondrial inheritance, therefore his sister could be affected with the disease.

As the disease is only transmitted from mother to all offsprings, he neither could transmit the disease to his offsprings, be it male or female child nor could he have got it from his father.

  • Pigmentory retinopathy
  • Cardiomyopathy

  • Caused by mutations of the mitochondrial genome.
  • Inherited exclusively from the affected mother (ovum) as an individual’s mitochondrial genome is entirely derived from the mother because sperm contain few mitochondria, which are typically shed upon fertilization.
  • Both male and female children born to an affected mother will inherit the disease.

questions.text: During your visit to the ER, you notice a patient's leg appearing as shown in the image below. This procedure would have been performed because his differential pressure measurement would have revealed ____________

choices.text: Diastolic pressure - measured intracompartmental pressure < 30 mm Hg
Diastolic pressure - measured intracompartmental pressure > 30 mm Hg
Diastolic pressure - measured intracompartmental pressure < 40 mm Hg
Diastolic pressure - measured intracompartmental pressure > 40 mm Hg

questions.solution:
Diastolic pressure - measured intracompartmental pressure < 30 mm Hg would be the indication to perform fasciotomy.

The image shows fasciotomy which is done to relieve the pressure in the muscle compartments in patients with compartment syndrome. There is a longitudinal incision present over the swollen leg, lateral to the subcutaneous border of the tibia. 

The diagnosis of compartment syndrome can be confirmed by measuring the intra-compartmental pressure using a split catheter introduced into the compartment. The difference between diastolic pressure and compartment pressure is known as the differential pressure (ΔP). A differential pressure (ΔP) of less than 30 mm Hg (4.00 kilopascals) is an indication for immediate compartment decompression.

Closed lower limb injuries can increase the pressure within the muscle compartments, leading to compartment syndrome. It is characterized by severe pain, pain on passive movement of the affected compartment muscles, distal sensory disturbance, and the absence of pulses distal to the compartment.

The classic features of ischemia in acute compartment syndrome include the 5 P's:

  • Pain: Pain is the first symptom of acute compartment syndrome. Ischemic muscle is highly sensitive to touch. On passive stretching of the muscles, severe pain can be elicited. 
  • Paresthesia: Paresthesia and hypoesthesia may be noted due to the compression of nerves traversing the affected compartment. They are the first signs of nerve ischemia.
  • Pallor: Pallor of the skin may not always be seen. The skin outside the compartment may be normally perfused, as only the intra-compartmental perfusion may be affected.
  • Paralysis: Paralysis of muscle groups affected in that compartment is a late sign.
  • Pulselessness: Usually, the peripheral pulses and capillary return are intact in the early stages, unless there is a major arterial injury. If pulses are absent, arteriography is indicated.

questions.text:
In the neonatal unit, the pediatric resident was examining a newborn and heard a continuous"machinery murmur" on auscultation. Further workup revealed a patent ductus arteriosus. Examination shows the presence of hearing defects and bilateral congenital cataracts in the baby. The mother gives a history of viral exanthem during 10 to 12 weeks of the pregnancy. Which of the following statements are correct regarding this disease and the etiological agent?

1. Causative organism belongs to family Togaviridae

2. Diagnosed by presence of IgG antibodies in the infant shortly after birth. 

3. Forchheimer spots are seen in this disease.

4. Maximum damage to the fetus occurs in the second trimester.

5. A live attenuated vaccine RA 27/3 strain is used in prevention.
questions.solution:
The clinical picture is characteristic of a newborn with congenital rubella syndrome. Statements 1, 3, and 5 are correct. 

Rubella (German measles)

Causative organism belongs to the family Togaviridae. The period of infectivity is usually a week before and a week after the onset of the rash appears and the incubation period is around 2-3 weeks.

Rash appears on day 1 and Forchheimer spots are seen, which are tiny, rose-colored lesions in the oropharynx.

Rubella can be prevented by vaccination. 27/3 live attenuated vaccine is available.

Congenital rubella syndrome:

When a woman in the 1st trimester gets infected with rubella, the resulting complications may include miscarriage, fetal death, premature delivery, or live birth with congenital defects. The baby is spared if the infection occurs beyond 16 weeks.

The commonest malformations caused by rubella are cardiac defects, cataracts, and deafness, which constitute the classical congenital rubella syndrome.

Patent ductus arteriosus (PDA) is the most common congenital heart disease associated with rubella, followed by pulmonary artery stenosis (PS). PDA presents with a continuous machinery murmur. 

Diagnosis is by demonstration of positive rubella IgM antibodies in cord or neonatal blood.

Thrombocytopenic purpura present in the babies gave rise to the term “blueberry muffin syndrome.”

Related Pearl: Rubella and congenital rubella syndrome

Congenital rubella syndrome:

  • The triad of Gregg in congenital rubella syndrome includes:
    • Sensorineural hearing loss - Nerve deafness is the single most common finding among infants with congenital rubella syndrome
    • Congenital cataract
    • Congenital heart disease - The most common cardiac defect is patent ductus arteriosus
  • Maximum damage to the fetus occurs in the first trimester
  • Infection in the second trimester causes only deafness
  • If infection occurs after 16 weeks there are no major abnormalities
  • Diagnosis - Presence of IgM rubella antibodies in the infant shortly after birth or persistence of IgG antibodies for >6 months.

The given image shows bilateral cataract in an infant with congenital rubella syndrome

The given image shows blueberry muffin rash in an infant with congenital rubella syndrome

The image given below shows the salt and pepper fundus.

  • Also called the German measles
  • Causative organism belongs to the family Matonaviridae
  • Period of infectivity is -5 to +6 days after the onset of the rash
  • Droplet trasmission

  • The rash appears on day 1

questions.text: Caroli's disease is __________
questions.solution:
Caroli's disease is a type V choledochal cyst.

Choledochal cysts are congenital cystic dilations of the intrahepatic and/or extrahepatic biliary tree. They present with a triad of jaundice, a palpable upper quadrant mass, and abdominal pain.

Choledochal cyst is classified into five types:

  • Type I: is a simple cyst that can involve any portion of the CBD.
  • Type II: It is described as an isolated diverticulum arising from the wall of the CBD
  • Type III: They arise from the intraduodenal portion of the common bile duct and are also known as choledochocele.
  • Type IVA: The cysts consist of multiple dilatations of the intrahepatic and extrahepatic bile ducts.
  • Type IVB: These choledochal cysts are multiple dilatations involving only the extrahepatic bile ducts.
  • Type V (Caroli’s disease): It consists of multiple dilatations limited to the intrahepatic bile ducts.

Related Pearl: Classification of Choledochal Cysts

Type

Feature

Type I

The most common choledochal cyst type; it involves only the extrahepatic biliary tree and is generally a fusiform dilation.

Type II

Saccular diverticulum off the common bile duct and may be mistaken for an accessory gallbladder.

Type III

A cystic dilation of the intramural common bile duct, within the wall of the duodenum, known as choledochoceles.

Type IV

Type IVa: Cysts involving the intrahepatic and extrahepatic biliary tree

Type IVb: Multiple cysts limited to the extrahepatic biliary tree.

Type V

Also known as Caroli disease, involve the intrahepatic ducts only.

questions.text: A 23-year-old man presents with throat pain, fever, and pain with swallowing. When he attempts to speak his voice is muffled. The patient tilts his head to his right side. Physical examination shows findings as seen in the image.  Contrast-enhanced CT and needle aspiration reveal the diagnosis. Which of the following is not a complication of this disease?
questions.solution:
Periodontal abscess is not an expected complication in this disease. The above clinical features and the above image are suggestive of Quinsy or peritonsillar abscess.

Quinsy is the collection of pus between the fibrous capsule of the tonsil and the superior constrictor muscles of the pharynx.

The clinical features are sore throat, odynophagia, muffled voice (hot potato voice), foul breath, dysphagia, drooling of saliva, trismus, ipsilateral otalgia, and fever. 

Physical examination reveals congestion of tonsils, pillars, and soft palate, swollen and edematous uvula pushed to the other side, mucopus over tonsils, cervical lymphadenopathy, and torticollis. This tonsillar swelling can be differentiated from other tonsillar swellings by yellowish spots of purulent material at the opening of crypts (acute follicular tonsillitis), presence of membrane over the tonsils (acute membranous tonsillitis, diphtheria, infectious mononucleosis, vincent angina), or extensive swelling and congestion of the tonsils that they may meet in the midline (acute parenchymatous tonsillitis)

Diagnosis is through CECT/MRI or aspiration of fluid in the abscess.

Management: Antibiotics and incision & drainage to drain the abscess followed by interval tonsillectomy 4-6 weeks later. Some surgeons prefer surgery during active disease known as a hot tonsillectomy, but this has the risk of rupture and bleeding.

Complications:

  • Parapharyngeal abscess
  • Retropharyngeal abscess
  • Airway obstruction
  • Septicemia
  • Pneumonitis
  • Jugular vein thrombosis
  • Spontaneous hemorrhage from carotid artery or jugular vein

questions.text: A 40-year-old man presents to the emergency department for pain, erythema, and swelling in the left leg. His symptoms started 4 weeks back, were incompletely managed, and have progressed since then. On physical exam, there is tenderness to palpation of the left leg with a discharging sinus. Laboratory testing is significant for leucocytosis, and elevated erythrocyte sedimentation rate, and C-reactive protein. X-ray findings are shown below. Which of the marked structures acts as a nidus for the chronic infection?

choices.text: There is no nidus as infection is always carried hematogenously

questions.solution:
The patient described in this clinical stem with complaints of pain, swelling, erythema, and a chronic discharging sinus most likely suffers from chronic osteomyelitis. The sequestrum marked as '3' acts as the nidus for infection in such cases. This is because the bacteria within the devascularised sequestrum are protected from antibiotics and the endogenous immune response, thus forming a nidus for chronic infection which may persist for many years even.

Clinical presentation of osteomyelitis - erythema, chronic pain, swelling, tenderness, discharging sinus tract.

When osteomyelitis is suspected on clinical grounds, early radiographs show only the soft tissue swelling, with no bony abnormality. The first bony lesion of osteomyelitis is the periosteal new bone formation. It is seen on an X-ray radiograph by the 2nd week of infection. It appears as a faint extracortical outline. Hence, the following imaging modalities are used to aid early diagnosis:

  • MRI: Marrow edema is seen within 24-48hr. A normal MRI can rule out osteomyelitis.
  • Technetium 99 bone scan: Osteomyelitis will show increased osseous uptake of the tracer whereas other soft tissue infections will not show osseous uptake. A normal bone scan rules out osteomyelitis.

X-ray findings are as shown below - 

 

1 - Involucrum is the thick sheath of periosteal new bone that surrounds the sequestrum.

2- Cloacae is an opening in an involucrum that allows the drainage of purulent and necrotic material out of the dead bone.

3 - Sequestrum is a piece of devitalized bone that has been separated from its surrounding bone during the process of necrosis. Acts as a nidus for chronic infection.

 

Lab investigations show a raised ESR and CRP and leucocytosis as seen in this patient.

questions.text:
Which of the following drugs act via the mechanism depicted in the illustration shown below?
  1. Dobutamine
  2. Interferon
  3. Imatinib
  4. Atropine
  5. Verapamil
  6. Misoprostol
questions.solution:
The given illustration shows the G-protein-coupled receptor pathway for signalling. The drugs that function via this mechanism are dobutamine, propranolol, atropine, misoprostol, montelukast. 

Functional families of GPCRs include beta-adrenergic receptors, muscarinic cholinergic receptors, eicosanoid receptors, and thrombin receptors.

G proteins act as inhibitory and excitatory because of differences in the alpha subunit.

In general, Gs and Gq subtypes are excitatory whereas Gi is inhibitory.

Resting-state:

  • G protein heterotrimer consisting of alpha, beta and gamma subunits forms a complex with G-protein-coupled receptors at the intracellular domain. The extracellular domain of GPCR has the binding domain for hormones and G protein subunits do not directly bind them. 
  • The alpha subunit is bound to GDP 

Binding of ligand results in an activated state: 

  • Alpha subunit undergoes a conformational change
  • Release of GDP and binding of GTP
  • GTP bound alpha subunit dissociates from beta-gamma subunit
  • Both alpha subunit and beta-gamma subunit bind to and regulate effectors only when they are separated 

The illustration below shows the pathway.

Other options:

  • Interferon acts through cytokine receptors, which belong to the structural family of transmembrane, non-enzymes.
  • Imatinib acts via the receptor tyrosine kinases, which belongs to the structural family of transmembrane enzymes.
  • Verapamil acts via the voltage-gated ion channel.

questions.text:
A 3-day-old newborn is being evaluated in the nursery for excessive somnolence. The baby was born at term and was immediately started on breast milk. The baby has been feeding poorly and has been increasingly lethargic. There have been four episodes of vomiting since yesterday.

Physical examination reveals a somnolent infant, the temperature is 97F, pulse rate is 130/min, and respiratory rate is 80/min. Laboratory investigations are as follows -

ABG Component Value
pH 7.47
pCO2 30
HCO3 24

Laboratory analysis shows elevated ammonia and glutamine, reduced levels of arginine, normal levels of arginosuccinate and absent citrulline. Orotic acid levels are grossly elevated. The deficient enzyme in this baby is?
questions.solution:
The given clinical complex describes a case of ornithine transcarbamoylase deficiency. The neonate presents with features of hyperammonemia such as lethargy, somnolence, inability to maintain body temperature, decreased feeding, and vomiting. Physical examination may reveal hyperventilation leading to respiratory alkalosis (Arterial blood gas analysis shows a pH of 7.47 and pCO2 of 30) as seen in this patient. Hyperventilation is thought to be due to the accumulation of ammonia, glutamine, and other metabolites which leads to cerebral edema. These features are commonly confused with sepsis.

Untreated patients will develop progressive cerebral edema, encephalopathy, and death.

Laboratory examination in patients with OTC deficiency will show -

  • Elevated ammonia
  • Elevated glutamine
  • Decreased arginine
  • Decreased or absent citrulline
  • Grossly elevated orotic acid to more than 1000 micromol/mol creatinine (normal, 1 to 11 micromol/mol creatinine)
  • The diagnosis can be confirmed by enzyme analysis on a liver biopsy

Treatment involves correction of hyperammonemia and initiating IV arginine hydrochloride, IV sodium phenylacetate-sodium benzoate, and oral citrulline.

Other options:

Option A: Arginosuccinase deficiency leads to argininosuccinic aciduria which presents with elevated levels of arginosuccinate in the blood (this patient's levels are normal), CSF, and urine. Trichorrhexis nodosa which is friable, tufted hair is an associated condition. 

Option B: Alpha-galactosidase-A deficiency causes Fabry's disease, which is an X-linked lysosomal storage disorder that presents with angiokeratomas and acroparasthesias.

Option D: Arginase deficiency leads to hyperarginemia which presents with features of hyperammonemia but only at 2-4 years of age. Furthermore, arginine levels will be elevated 2-4 fold in patients with arginase deficiency. They are not reduced in this patient. 

Related Pearl: Urea Cycle and its disorders

questions.text:
A 60-year-old male patient is admitted to the surgical ward with severe burns which occupy >30% of his body surface area. He is started on aggressive fluid resuscitation. A few hours later, he complains of abdominal pain and swelling.
Vital Signs  
Temperature 99°F
Pulse Rate 90/minute
Respiratory Rate 17/minute
Blood Pressure 140/90 mm Hg
SpO2 98% on room air

Physical examination reveals marked distension of the abdomen. The abdomen is tense on palpation. Bilateral lower extremity edema is present and urine output is markedly decreased. Bladder pressure is measured to be 22 cm of H2O. Which of the following is expected in this patient?
questions.solution:
The given clinical vignette describes a case of abdominal compartment syndrome. The increased intraabdominal pressure (Option D) and intrathoracic pressure causes extrinsic venous compression, leading to elevated CVP. The compression also results in decreased IVC flow and decreased cardiac preload thereby. This finally leads to decreased cardiac output (Option B), hypotension, and compensatory tachycardia. Abdominal wall compliance cannot increase in an acute setting (Option C).

Etiology:

  • Trauma
  • Liver transplantation
  • Abdominal conditions such as massive ascites, intraperitoneal bleeding, abdominal surgery
  • Retroperitoneal pathology 
  • Sepsis which requires fluid resuscitation
  • Post-surgical patients

Pathophysiological features:

  • Impaired cardiac function
  • Reduced venous return
  • Elevated CVP and PCWP
  • Increased peak and inspiratory airway pressures
  • Renal vein compression and renal artery vasoconstriction
  • Decreased intestinal perfusion
  • Lactic acidosis
  • Elevated ICP

Clinical features:

  • Malaise, weakness, abdominal pain, abdominal bloating, lightheadedness, dyspnea
  • Tensely distended abdomen
  • Decreased urinary output
  • Peripheral edema
  • Hypotension
  • Tachycardia

Diagnosis:

Measurement of bladder (ie, intravesical) pressure is the standard method to screen for intra-abdominal hypertension (IAH) and Abdominal compartment syndrome (ACS)

Treatment:

Treatment includes rapid decompression of the elevated intra-abdominal pressure by opening the abdominal wound and performing a temporary closure of the abdominal wall with mesh or a plastic bag (Bogota bag).

Abdominal compartment syndrome grading system based on bladder pressure:

Grade   cm H2O
I   13-20
II   21 – 35
III   36 – 47
IV   > 48

 

Increased stroke volume (Option 2) will not be seen in a patient with abdominal compartment syndrome because there will be a decreased preload and cardiac output thereby. Abdominal wall compliance (Option 3) cannot increase in an acute setting. There is a marked increase in intra-abdominal pressure (Option 4) in compartment syndrome, not a decrease.

  • Venous return
  • Visceral blood ﬂow

  • Glomerular filtration

Increased :

  • Cardiac rate
  • Pulmonary capillary wedge pressure
  • Peak inspiratory pressure
  • Central venous pressure
  • Intrapleural pressure
  • Systemic vascular resistance

questions.text: The Chest X-ray of a presumptive TB patient who presented with a dry cough and weight loss is suggestive of TB, but the sputum examination is negative. As per the National Tuberculosis Elimination Programme guidelines, what should be the next step in management?

choices.text: Give antibiotics and repeat chest X-ray

questions.solution:
A patient with a suggestive CXR but sputum smear-negative should undergo a CB-NAAT as the next step in management.

CB NAAT (Cartridge Based Nucleic Acid Amplification Test) provides a rapid and accurate diagnosis of TB by detecting Mycobacterium tuberculosis and mutations responsible for rifampicin resistance. It can be used for sputum samples as well as samples from extrapulmonary sites. It is done when the smear is negative for TB but the chest X-ray is suggestive of tuberculosis and also in some cases smear is negative and the chest X-ray is not suggestive of TB but there is a high index of clinical suspicion.

It is mainly used for diagnosis of DR-TB in presumptive DR-TB patients and TB preferentially in the key population such as children, PLHIV, extra-pulmonary TB, and in smear-negative TB as per the diagnostic algorithm. 

Diagnostic algorithm for pulmonary TB:

Related Pearl: Diagnostic algorithm for Pulmonary TB – National Tuberculosis Elimination Programme (NTEP) 2020 Guidelines

Any case of presumptive pulmonary TB should undergo sputum examination + chest X-ray + CB-NAAT

  • If sputum and chest X-ray normal: rule out TB and refer
  • If sputum is positive and CB NAAT is positive: microbiologically confirmed case of TB

The following protocol is used for CB-NAAT testing:

As per the latest recommendations from National Tuberculosis Elimination Programme (NTEP), treatment of TB is now based primarily on drug susceptibility testing. This is irrespective of new cases, previously treated cases or recurrent TB cases. 
All cases of TB are treated with Drug Sensitive TB Regimen, as long as the patient is sensitive to isoniazid and rifampicin. (No classification into category I or II)

  • Poly-Drug Resistant (PDR): A TB patient, who is resistant to more than one 1st line anti-TB drug, other than Rifampicin and isoniazid. 
  • Rifampicin Resistant (RR): A TB patient, who is resistant to rifampicin with or without resistance to other drugs. Patients, who have rifampicin resistance, should be managed as if they are an MDR TB case.
  • Multi-Drug Resistant (MDR): A TB patient, who is resistant to both isoniazid and rifampicin.
  • Extensively Drug-Resistant (XDR): A MDR TB patient who is additionally resistant to a fluoroquinolone (ofloxacin, levofloxacin, or moxifloxacin) and at least one additional group A drug (as of 2021, these are bedaquiline and linezolid)

questions.text: A 25-year-old football player is brought to the emergency room after falling on the field during a match. His X-ray shows the findings below. Which of the following peripheral blocks is indicated to restore the normal anatomy?
questions.solution:
The given clinical vignette describes a case of shoulder dislocation as seen on the X-ray. Interscalene block provides surgical anaesthesia for procedures of the shoulder and upper arm.

Interscalene nerve block is performed between the anterior and middle scalene muscles in the inter-scalene groove at the level of C6, where the brachial plexus emerges. It provides an adequate block of the superior and middle trunks of the brachial plexus. The ulnar nerve (C8, T1) from the inferior trunk may be missed. Hence, this block is not used for procedures of the forearm and hand.

The most common complication of inter-scalene block seen in 100% of patients is diaphragmatic hemiparesis due to ipsilateral phrenic nerve blockade. This can result in dyspnea, hypoxia, and hypercapnia, especially if the patient has compromised lung function or preexisting contralateral phrenic nerve paralysis.

Other complications of inter-scalene block are:

  • Horners syndrome – ptosis, myosis, anhydrosis. Due to the involvement of the sympathetic nerves in the cervicothoracic ganglion. (loss of ciliospinal reflex)
  • Recurrent laryngeal nerve palsy
  • Vagus nerve involvement
  • Pneumothorax (stratosphere sign on ultrasound of the chest)
  • Bezold Jarisch reflex (hypotension, bradycardia and coronary vasodilation)
  • Accidental vertebral artery injection (immediate seizure is seen)
  • Accidental spinal or epidural injection
