questions.text: A hormone, with the structure as shown below, is being administered to a patient. It is known that it is released during the well-fed state and that it induces the rate-limiting enzyme of a reaction. Choose the correct pair of the rate-limiting enzyme induced and the reaction it is involved in.
questions.solution:
The hormone whose structure is shown in the image is insulin which is released in the well-fed state. Insulin induces the enzyme phosphofructokinase, which is the rate-limiting enzyme in glycolysis.

Glycolysis is a pathway in which glucose is converted to pyruvate in aerobic conditions or lactate in anaerobic conditions, along with the production of a small amount of energy. The rate-limiting reaction in glycolysis is the phosphorylation of fructose-6-phosphate to fructose 1,6-bisphosphate. This is catalyzed by the enzyme phosphofructokinase.

There are two phosphofructokinases, PFK-1 and PFK-2 which participate in this reaction. PFK-1 plays a key role in regulating glycolysis and is subject to feedback control. It converts fructose-6-phosphate to fructose-1-6-bis-phosphate.

Inhibitors of PFK-1:

  • ATP
  • Citrate

Allosteric activators of PFK-1:

  • AMP
  • Fructose 2,6 bisphosphate (most potent activator)

Hormonal regulation:

  • Inducer—Insulin
  • Repressor—Glucagon

Due to the inhibition of phosphofructokinase-1 by ATP, there is an accumulation of glucose-6-phosphate, which in turn inhibits the uptake of glucose in extrahepatic tissues.

PFK-2 phosphorylates fructose-6-phosphate to form fructose-2-6-bis-phosphate in the fed state. PFK-2 also acts as fructose bisphosphatase-2 (FBPase-2) and breaks down fructose 2,6-bisphosphate to fructose-6-phosphate in the fasting state. Hence, PFK-2 is a bifunctional enzyme whose function is reversed by the presence of insulin or glucagon in the fed and fasting states respectively. 

The primary structure of insulin consists of 2 polypeptide chains: A-chain (21 amino acids) and B-chain (30 amino acids).
 
It has two interchain disulfide bonds, 
  • Between the 7th amino acid of the A chain and the 7th amino acid of the B chain 
  • Between the 20th amino acid of the A chain and the 19th amino acid of the B chain

One intrachain disulfide bond is present between the 6th amino acid of the A-chain and the 11th amino acid in the A-chain.

questions.text: A 50-year-old morbidly obese man presents to the ER with breathlessness. He has had similar severe episodes in the past and was diagnosed with COPD. Vitals are significant for tachypnea and tachycardia. Physical examination is notable for accessory muscle use and marked respiratory distress. Auscultation of the chest reveals diffuse coarse rhonchi. The physician decides to start noninvasive positive pressure ventilation. Which of the following is a contraindication to initiate this?
questions.solution:
Noninvasive positive-pressure ventilation (NIPPV) is contraindicated in extreme obesity.

Contraindications of NIPPV:

  • Cardiovascular instability
  • Impaired mental status or inability to cooperate
  • Copious secretions or the inability to clear secretions
  • Craniofacial abnormalities
  • Trauma precluding effective fitting of the mask
  • Extreme obesity

Indications of NIPPV:

  • Apnea: Central and Obstructive
  • Hypoventilation syndrome: Central and Obesity hypoventilation syndromes
  • Neuromuscular and chest wall disorders
  • Respiratory failure: PaCO2 >45 mmHg

Non-invasive positive pressure ventilation (NIPPV) is provided to a patient with acute exacerbation of COPD.

Initial management of acute exacerbation of COPD includes:

  • Bronchodilators: Inhaled beta-agonists and muscarinic antagonists.
  • Antibiotics
  • Supplemental oxygen
  • Non-invasive positive pressure ventilation (NIPPV)

If the initial NIPPV fails, then, invasive PPV may be provided. However, during the invasive PPV, the tidal volume is reduced to prevent damage to the alveolar structures.

Anticoagulation is necessary for patients with mitral stenosis, hypertrophic cardiomyopathy, prior history of stroke. Patients without these indications require the CHA2 DS2 -VASc score to be calculated for estimating stroke risk. The CHA2 DS2 -VASc is expanded below in the pearl. 

Drugs to prevent stroke include anticoagulants such as oral warfarin and the factor Xa inhibitors rivaroxaban, apixaban, and edoxaban, and the direct thrombin inhibitor dabigatran. These direct-acting agents have proved to be non-inferior in trials and are easier to monitor.

questions.text:
A 30-year-old woman presents writhing and jerking movements of her extremities for 1 week. She also complains of pain in multiple joints. Vital signs are within normal limits. Physical examination is remarkable for hepatosplenomegaly, ocular KF ring, and examination findings as shown below.

Lab results are as follows:

Liver function tests Values Normal Range
Total bilirubin (µmol/L) 20 2-20 
Direct bilirubin (µmol/L)   6 0-6
Aspartate aminotransferase (AST) (U/L) 300 5-30 
Alanine aminotransferase (ALT) (U/L) 150 5-30 
Alkaline phosphatase (U/L) 100 50-100 

Which of the following is the treatment of choice in this patient?
questions.solution:
The clinical vignette of a patient with KF ring, along with the clip showing a wing beating tremor, is suggestive of Wilson's disease with decompensation. The treatment of choice in this condition is Zinc + Trientine.

Wilsons disease:

The autosomal-recessive disease is caused by mutations in the ATP7B gene, which encodes a membrane-bound, copper-transporting ATPase.

Clinical symptoms:

  • Hepatitis and cirrhosis
  • Behavioral disturbances
  • Wing beating tremor(shown in the gif in question)
  • Ophthalmic characteristics:
    • Deposition of copper in the posterior capsule of the lens resulting in sunflower cataract
    • KF ring 

Kayser-Fleischer ring (KF) Ring:

  • KF ring is a golden-brown ring formed due to the deposition of copper in Descemet’s membrane of the cornea
  • Characteristically observed in Wilson's disease but is not pathognomonic
  • Does not interfere with vision
  • Present in almost all patients of Wilson's disease with neurological/psychiatric symptoms
  • Present only in 30–50% of patients diagnosed in the hepatic or presymptomatic state. Therefore, the absence of KF rings does not exclude the diagnosis of Wilson's disease

Diagnosis:

    • Presence of KF rings
    • Decreased serum ceruloplasmin (copper-containing enzyme/ferroxidase) levels
    • Measured hepatic copper levels in liver biopsy
    • Increased 24-hour urine copper excretion

The gold standard for diagnosis: Liver biopsy with quantitative copper assays

Treatment: Trientine and Zinc are the first choice of drug regimen to be used for treating mild hepatic decompensation in Wilson’s disease.

questions.text: A pregnant woman at 14 weeks of gestation developed sudden-onset fever, rash, conjunctivitis, muscle and joint pain, malaise, and headache. Symptomatic treatment was initiated and these manifestations subsided within a week. The delivery was uneventful at term, but multiple abnormalities were noted in the baby such as, high muscle tone, limb contractures, visual defects, and microcephaly. Which of the following statements is incorrect about the condition and the implicated organism?

choices.text: Transmission is through the bite of an infected Culex mosquito
The virus can be transmitted through sexual intercourse

questions.solution:
The given scenario of high muscle tone, limb contractures, visual defects, and microcephaly noted in the child is suggestive of congenital Zika syndrome due to the infection of the mother during pregnancy. Zika virus can be transmitted by the bite of infected Aedes aegypti and Aedes albopictus.

Zika virus belongs to the Flaviviridae family (Option B) and was first identified in Uganda. It is an arbovirus that is transmitted by Aedes mosquitoes, primarily Aedes aegypti. The reservoir of infection is unknown and has not yet been reported in India. Zika virus can also be transmitted via sexual contact, blood transfusion, and also from mother to fetus during pregnancy. (Option D)

Infection with Zika virus is usually asymptomatic. The symptoms are usually mild and include fever, skin rashes, conjunctivitis, and muscle and joint pain. These symptoms usually resolve in 2-7 days. Complications include Guillain-Barré syndrome (Option C), neuropathy, and myelitis, and are particularly seen in adults and older children.

Zika virus infection during pregnancy is associated with complications such as fetal loss, preterm birth, and stillbirth. The transmission of the infection to the baby can lead to congenital Zika syndrome which is characterized by microcephaly. Other malformations include limb contractures, high muscle tone, eye abnormalities, and hearing loss. Congenital malformations can follow both symptomatic and asymptomatic infections.

RT-PCR is the standard test for the diagnosis of Zika virus infection. In India, NCDC Delhi and the National Institute of Virology Pune, are the only institutes that can provide the diagnosis in an acute febrile stage.

There is no treatment available for Zika virus infection. Plenty of rest and fluids along with antipyretics and/or analgesics are indicated for symptom relief. Medical attention should be sought if symptoms worsen. There is no vaccine available for the prevention of Zika virus infection. The key measure for prevention is protection against mosquito bites. WHO also recommends contraceptive counseling for sexually active men and women, especially in regions with active Zika virus transmission.

The image below depicts the transplacental transmission of Zika virus infection.

  • The life span of mosquitoes is around 8 to 34 days
  • Their morphology consists of a head with a proboscis, a pair of palpi, and a pair of antennae; a thorax and an abdomen

questions.text: A patient presents with sudden-onset fever, chills, headache, and painful inguinal lymphadenopathy. There is a history of rodent infestation at his farm. He is diagnosed with a disease transmitted by the vector shown in the image below. Identify the type of zoonosis and the type of biological transmission in this disease.
questions.solution:
The given image above is of a rat flea, which transmits plague bacilli. The type of zoonosis is meta-zoonosis, and the type of biological transmission is propagative transmission. In propagative biological transmission, the disease agent only multiplies in the vector but there is no change in form. Metazoonosis refers to zoonoses that require both vertebrates and invertebrates to complete their infectious cycle.

Zoonoses: These are diseases and infections that are naturally transmitted between other vertebrate animals and man.

Classification of zoonoses on the basis of their reservoir hosts:

  • Anthropozoonoses
  • Zoo-anthroponoses
  • Amphixenoses

Classification of zoonoses on the basis of the life cycle of the infecting agent:

Category

Mode

Example

Direct zoonoses

Direct contact/ fomite/mechanical vector

No essential developmental/ propagative changes during transmission

Rabies , Trichinosis, Brucellosis

Cyclozoonoses

Require more than one vertebrate host is needed to complete the developmental cycle and no invertebrate host

 Human taeniasis, Echinococcosis, Pentastomid infections

Metazoonoses

Transmitted by invertebrate vectors, in which the infective agent develops/multiplies and after a period of extrinsic period of incubation is transmitted to another vertebrate host.

Arboviral infections, Plague and Schistosomiasis

Saprozoonoses

Has both a vertebrate host and a non-animal (food, soil/ plants)developmental site/reservoir

Various forms of larva migrants and mycoses

Biological transmission in vector-borne diseases:

  • Propagative - The disease agent only multiplies in the vector and there is no change in form. e.g., Plague bacilli in rat fleas.
  • Cyclo-propagative - The agent changes in form and in number. e.g., Malarial parasites in mosquitoes.
  • Cyclo-developmental - The agent undergoes only developmental changes and not multiplication. e.g., Microfilaria in mosquitoes.
  • Transovarial - The infectious agent is transmitted vertically in the vector, from parent to progeny. e.g., Rickettsia rickettsii in ticks.
  • Transstadial - The infectious agent stays with the vector from one stage of its life cycle to the next. e.g., Borrelia burgdorferi in ticks.

Plague is a zoonotic disease. The plague bacillus is a natural parasite in rodents and the infection is transmitted amongst them by rat fleas. In the flea, the bacilli multiply and block the proventriculus. When such a blocked flea bites another rodent, the blood, mixed with the bacteria is regurgitated into the bite, transmitting the infection.

When a diseased rat dies (rat fall), the fleas may bite human beings, causing the plague, which usually manifests as sudden onset of fever and painful lymphadenopathy. Several species of fleas act as vectors. 

Human plague occurs in 3 clinical forms:

Bubonic plague is the most common variety. It is characterized by swollen lymph nodes, which typically develop within a week after an infected flea bite.

Pneumonic plague occurs when bubonic plague spreads to the lungs. It is the most virulent form of plague, and an infected person may transmit the disease via droplets to other humans.

Septicemic plague occurs when the bacteria enter the bloodstream directly and multiply there.

Related Pearl: Biological Transmission in Vector-Borne Diseases

1. Propagative

  • The disease agent only multiplies in the vector and there is no change in form.
  • E.g., Plague bacilli in rat fleas.

2. Cyclo-propagative

  • The agent changes in form and in number.
  • E.g., Malarial parasites in mosquitoes.

3. Cyclo-developmental

  • The agent undergoes only developmental changes and not multiplication.
  • E.g., Microfilaria in mosquitoes.

4. Transovarial

  • Infectious agent is transmitted vertically in the vector, from parent to progeny.
  • E.g., Rickettsia rickettsii in ticks.

5. Transstadial

  • The infectious agent stays with the vector from one stage of its life cycle to the next.
  • E.g., Borrelia burgdorferi in ticks.

Related Pearl: Rat Fleas

  • Rat fleas (Xenopsylla cheopis) belong to the genus Xenopsylla.
  • Their morphology includes a conical head, absent neck, a thorax with 3 segments, and an abdomen with 10 segments. They have three pairs of legs and no wings.
  • The four stages in their life cycle are egg, larva, pupa, and adult.
  • They cannot fly but can leap up to 6 inches horizontally.
  • They transmit diseases by biting, mechanical transmission, and feces.
  • Flea indices that are used in flea surveys are the general flea index, specific flea index, percentage incidence of flea species, and rodent infestation rate.
  • Rat fleas are vectors for endemic typhus (murine typhus), chiggerosis, bubonic plague, and Hymenolepis diminuta.
  • Insecticidal control is mainly by 10% DDT.
  • Resistance to DDT, gamma-HCH, and dieldrin has been recorded.
  • Repellants like diethyltoluamide and benzyl benzoate are efficient.
  • Rodent control also aims to reduce flea infestation.

questions.text: A 16-year-old girl presents with nasal obstruction. She states that her friends make fun of her because she emits a bad odor. Physical examination reveals wide nasal turbinates filled with greenish-black dry crusts and a pale nasal mucosa. Which of the following is not a component of the Kemicetine solution used in the management of this disease?
questions.solution:
Phenylephrine is not a component of the Kemicetine solution commonly used in the management of this disease.

The clinical scenario with nasal obstruction, bad odor, wide nasal turbinates filled with greenish-black dry crusts is suggestive of atrophic rhinitis. The Kemicetine solution used in the management of atrophic rhinitis contains chloramphenicol, oestradiol, and vitamin D2.

Atrophic rhinitis is a chronic nasal inflammation associated with atrophy of the nasal mucosa and turbinate bones. The etiology of primary atrophic rhinitis includes:

  • Hereditary
  • More commonly in females than males
  • White and yellow races are more susceptible
  • Nutritional deficiency- Deficiency of vitamin A, D, or iron
  • Infective- Causative agents include Klebsiella ozaena, Proteus vulgaris, Escherichia coli, etc.
  • Autoimmune process

The clinical presentation of atrophic rhinitis includes nasal obstruction, foul smell from the nose with merciful anosmia, crusting of the nasal passage, pale nasal mucosa, wide nasal turbinates, and epistaxis.

Treatment

  • Nasal irrigation and crust removal using warm saline or an alkaline solution composed of sodium bicarbonate 1 part, sodium bi-borate 1 part, sodium chloride 2 parts in 280 mL of water
  • Local antibiotics - Kemicetine anti-ozaena solution contains chloramphenicol, estradiol, and vitamin D2. 
  • 25% glucose in glycerine, estradiol spray, systemic use of streptomycin, potassium iodide, placental extract.
  • Surgical management includes the modified Young's operation or narrowing the nasal turbinates.

Related Pearl: Etiology of atrophic rhinitis

Etiology of primary atrophic rhinitis:

  • Hereditary- Involves more than one member of a family
  • Endocrinal- More common in females, starts at puberty and regresses after menopause
  • Racial- More common in mongoloid and caucasian races
  • Nutritional deficiency- Vitamin A, D, iron deficiencies
  • Autoimmune- Antigens of the nasal mucosa
  • Organism- Klebsiella ozaenae

Etiology of secondary atrophic rhinitis:

  • Specific infections like syphilis, lupus, leprosy and, rhinoscleroma
  • Long-standing purulent sinusitis
  • Radiotherapy to nose
  • Excessive surgical removal of turbinates
  • Diphtheroids, Proteus vulgaris, Escherichia coli, staphylococci and streptococci

Related Pearl: Clinical Features of Atrophic Rhinitis

Atrophic rhinitis is more common in females and usually starts at puberty. It is a bilateral condition.

  • Symptoms:
    • Foul smell from the nose
    • Nasal obstruction in spite of roomy chambers due to large crusts filling nasal cavity
    • Epistaxis on removing of the crusts
    • Anosmia due to degeneration of nerve elements (merciful anosmia).
  • Signs:
    • Greenish or greyish black dry crusts covering the turbinates and septum
    • After removal of crusts, nasal cavities appear roomy with atrophy of turbinates
    • Nasal mucosa appears pale.

questions.text:
A 53-year-old female patient presents with complaints of weakness for the last 2 months. Additionally, she is facing difficulty rising from a chair, and combing her hair every morning. A physical exam reveals decreased strength in the shoulders and hip. Skin findings are as shown in the image. Which of the following is seen in this patient's condition?
  1. Perimyseal infiltrates
  2. Perivascular infiltrates with amyloid inclusion bodies and rimmed vacuoles
  3. CD4+ cellular infiltrates
  4. Predominant distal muscle weakness
  5. Underlying malignancy
questions.solution:
In the given clinical vignette, this patient's symptoms along with the image findings showing heliotrope rash are highly suggestive of dermatomyositis. Dermatomyositis involves CD 4+ cells, perimyseal infiltrates, and is associated with underlying malignancy. Hence, the correct findings are 1, 3, and 5.

Dermatomyositis is an idiopathic inflammatory myopathy characterized by proximal skeletal muscle weakness, muscle inflammation, and a variety of characteristic skin manifestations. The pattern of muscle involvement helps distinguish a myopathy from a cerebral, spinal cord, neuronal or neuromuscular junction cause. It is commonly associated with an underlying malignancy.

Classic signs-

  • Heliotrope rash/ eyelid erythema- Violaceous erythema of the upper eyelids
  • V sign- Confluent macular erythema over the lower anterior neck and upper anterior chest
  • Shawl sign- Confluent macular erythema over the upper back and lateral aspect of arms
  • Gottron’s papules- Erythematous papules and plaques over extensor surface of the metacarpophalangeal and interphalangeal joints
  • Gottron's sign- Erythematous rash over the extensor surfaces of joints such as the knuckles, elbows, knees, and ankles. 
  • Mechanic’s hands- Rough, hyperkeratotic lines on the lateral and palmer areas of the fingers
  • Scalp erythema and hair loss
  • Facial rash- Confluent erythema in the malar distribution involving the cheeks, nasal bridge, and nasolabial folds
  • Nail fold changes
  • Flagellate erythema- Linear erythema on the upper back with pruritus
  • Poikiloderma- Mottled pattern of hyperpigmented and hypopigmented macules with telangiectasias
  • Cutaneous calcinosis- Accumulation of calcium deposits in the skin.

Laboratory evaluation of patients with dermatomyositis will reveal elevated serum creatinine kinase and antinuclear antibodies. Electromyography will reveal features of myopathy. Histology will show perifascicular atrophy and immunohistochemical staining will reveal myxovirus resistance protein A, a sensitive and specific marker. 

Treatment of dermatomyositis is immunotherapy with high-dose glucocorticoids being the first line. Methotrexate can be started as the second line if the patient presents with severe weakness, other organ system involvement, or those with risk of steroid complications like patients with diabetes, osteoporosis, or postmenopausal women. Otherwise, second-line agents are only started in patients who do not show improvement after 2-4 months of treatment with prednisone or those who cannot be maintained on a low dose. Triple therapy with intravenous immunoglobulin or rituximab may be required.

questions.text:
A 35-year-old female complains of 3 months of fatigue. She states that she gets breathless on climbing a few flights of stairs which she previously climbed easily. Physical examination is significant for pallor of her conjunctiva. His RBC count is 3.5 million cells/mcL, and Hb is 10g/dL. Peripheral blood smear revealed microcytic hypochromic anemia. Iron studies are shown in the table below.
Iron Studies Values Normal Range
Total serum iron(µg/dL) 25 65-180  (men), 30-170 (women)
Total iron-binding capacity(µmol/L) 100 45-85
Ferritin (ng/mL)   8 12-300(men),12-150 (women)

Which of the following is true regarding absorption and storage of the deficient substance leading to the patient's disease?

1 - Phytanic acid, ascorbic acid, and oxalates decrease iron absorption
2 - Iron absorption majorly occurs in the duodenum
3 - Ferrous form is commonly absorbed
4 - Ferroportin 1 is an apical transporter that transfers iron from lumen to enterocytes
5 - Ferritin deposits in lysosomes aggregate as hemosiderin
questions.solution:
The clinical vignette represents a case of iron deficiency anemia. Statements 2,3 and 5 are correct regarding iron absorption and storage.

Iron deficiency anemia presents with pallor, decreased MCV, decreased RBC count, increased RDW, increased TIBC, decreased serum iron, decreased ferritin and peripheral smear showing microcytic hypochromic anemia.

Absorption and storage of iron:

  • Dietary factors affect iron availability for absorption. Phytic acid, phosphates, and oxalates decrease iron absorption.
  • Most of the dietary iron is in the ferric form (Fe3+), whereas, the iron is absorbed in the ferrous form (Fe2+).
  • Fe3+ reductase in the brush borders of the enterocytes provide the ferrous (Fe2+) form of iron which is then absorbed. Gastric secretions permit iron to form soluble complexes with ascorbic acid and other substances which help in reduction to Fe2+ form(hence gastrectomy can cause IDA).
  • Most of the iron absorption occurs in the duodenum. Divalent metal transporter 1 (DMT1) helps in the transfer of Fe2+ into enterocytes. Ferroportin 1 which is situated basolaterally transports iron out from enterocytes into the blood vessel. Hephaestin (Hp) is associated with ferroportin 1. The remaining ferritin molecules in lysosomal membranes may aggregate and are called hemosiderin.

questions.text: Which of the following describes the Bainbridge reflex?

choices.text: Hypertension, bradycardia and irregular respiration in response to increased intracranial pressure
Tachycardia in response to atrial distension
Brady­cardia, hypotension and apnea due to activation of vagal C fibers
Increase in breathing rate and hypotension due to stimulation of the juxta-pulmonary capillary receptors

questions.solution:
Bainbridge Reflex is the tachycardia in response to atrial distension. 

The stretch receptors of the atria are activated when the stria distends. They transmit the afferent signals through the vagus nerves to the medulla of the brain. The efferent signals are transmitted via the vagal and sympathetic nerves. They increase the strength of heart contraction and heart rate. This reflex prevents the pooling of blood in veins, atria, and pulmonary circulation.

Other options:

Option A: Hypertension, bradycardia, and irregular respiration in response to increased intracranial pressure is called the Cushing reflex. When intracranial pressure is increased, the blood supply to Rostral Ventro-Lateral Medulla (RVLM) neurons is compromised. The local hypoxia and hypercapnia cause an increase in discharge from the neurons, producing hypertension, bradycardia, and irregular respiration.

Option C: Brady­cardia, hypotension, and apnea due to activation of vagal C fibers is called the Bezold–Jarisch reflex. This apnea is followed by rapid shallow breathing.

Option D: The juxta-pulmonary capillary receptors are C fiber endings located close to the pulmonary vessels. These are stimulated when there is hyperinflation of the lung. This produces rapid breathing, bradycardia, and hypotension. This is called the J Reflex.

questions.text: A young boy presented with sudden-onset painless, rice-water diarrhea with flecks of mucus. He was treated with intravenous fluids and antibiotics, after which, he recovered. However, his stool sample still contains the causative agent, 2 weeks after this episode. Such a carrier is known as:
questions.solution:
A carrier who continues to excrete the causative agent for 2-3 weeks after they have recovered from the illness is known as a convalescent carrier. The clinical scenario of sudden-onset, painless, rice-water diarrhea is characteristic of cholera, caused by Vibrio cholerae.

An apparently healthy individual excreting V.cholerae in stools is a cholera carrier. The V. cholerae antibody titer is increased and is positive as long as the indivudal harbors the organism.

There are 4 types of cholera carriers:

  • Incubatory/pre-clinical carriers: They are potential patients. They shed the infectious agent during the incubation period of the disease. The duration of their carrier state is 1-5 days (incubation period).
  • Convalescent carriers: Those who continue to shed the disease agent during the period of convalescence, i.e the patient has recovered from an attack of cholera, continues to excrete vibrios for 2-3 weeks, usually due to ineffective antibiotic treatment.
  • Contact/healthy carrier: Those who had a subclinical infection and developed a carrier state without suffering from an overt disease. Duration is usually less than 10 days.
  • Chronic carrier state is not a frequent phenomenon in cholera but has been documented.

Note: Paradoxical carrier is a carrier who acquired a pathogen from another carrier.

questions.text:
In a reverse transcriptase-polymerase chain reaction test (RT-PCR), the target RNA strand that will undergo the process is 5' - AUGCUGCAGUCAAAAAA - 3'. Outputs obtained from the process are shown below. Choose the correct statement.
  1. "A" is the DNA strand obtained after replication of cDNA
  2. "B" is the cDNA strand obtained from RNA
  3. "C" is the cDNA strand obtained from RNA
  4. "D" is the DNA strand obtained after replication of cDNA
questions.solution:
For the given RNA strand, 5' - AUGCUGCAGUCAAAAAA - 3', the obtained complementary DNA strand will be as shown in image "C" following the rules of complementary base pairing (adenine binds with thymine/uracil and cytosine binds with guanine). The DNA strand obtained by replication of the cDNA strand will contain only thymine and not uracil and is therefore represented by "A" in the image above.

RT-PCR is a method that is used for the analysis of mRNA expression and its amplification.

Reverse transcriptase-polymerase chain reaction (RT-PCR) is a variant of PCR and includes 2 steps:

  • Generation of complementary DNA (cDNA copies) from mRNA using reverse transcriptase - used to qualitatively detect gene expression
  • Amplification of newly synthesized cDNA by traditional PCR - This can be quantitatively measured by using fluorescent dyes (qRT-PCR).

Uses: 

  • Determination of viral load
  • Screening of genetic diseases and cancers

questions.text: A 16-year-old girl complains of blurry vision and asthenopia. Ophthalmoscopy reveals a tilted optic disc and retinopathy reveals different power in two different axes. Further examination shows that her vertical meridian is more curved than her horizontal meridian. Which of the following subtypes does her disease fall under?
questions.solution:
When the vertical meridian is more curved than the horizonral, it is suggestive of astigmatism that is classified as 'with the rule'.

Astigmatism refers to the condition where there is different refractory power in both the principal meridians of the eye. Astigmatism is classified into two broad varieties - regular and irregular astigmatism.

  • Regular astigmatism: there are two principal meridians. 
    • With the rule -  principal meridians are vertical and horizontal; both meridians at 90°; and the vertical meridian is more curved than horizontal.
  •  
    • Against the rule -  principal meridians are vertical and horizontal; both meridians at 90°; and the horizontal meridian is more curved than vertical.
  •  
    • Oblique - the principal meridians are not vertical and horizontal, but they are at 90° to each other; e.g., at 45° and 135°.
  •  
    • Bi-oblique -  the two principal meridians are not vertical and horizontal, and they are not at 90° each other; e.g., at 40° and 100°.
  • Irregular astigmatism: there are multiple meridians.

Clinical presentation of astigmatism includes:

  • Asthenopia - tiredness of eyes relieved by closing the eyes
  • Blurred vision and defective vision
  • Elongation of objects
  • Keeping reading material closer
  • Half closure of the lid
  • Tilted or oval optic disc is seen on ophthalmoscopy

Retinoscopy shows different power on the two meridians. Other investigations include keratometry, astigmatic fan test, and Jackson’s cross-cylinder test.

questions.text: A 20-year-old female patient came to the emergency room stating that she passed blood instead of urine. Labs revealed Hb 6.5 g/dL, leukocyte count 3500/mm3, platelet count 65000/mm3, reticulocytosis, and elevated LDH levels. Flow cytometry showed CD55- and CD59-negative RBCs. Which of the following drugs is used for the treatment of this condition?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario is suggestive of paroxysmal nocturnal hemoglobinuria (PNH), and the drug used to treat this condition is Eculizumab.

PNH is an acquired chronic hemolytic anaemia characterized by a triad of intravascular hemolysis, pancytopenia, and the tendency for venous thrombosis. 

Clinical features include:

  • Symptoms of anaemia (may also be discovered incidentally)
  • Increased susceptibility to infections (due to severe neutropenia)
  • Hemorrhage (due to severe thrombocytopenia)
  • Recurrent attacks of severe abdominal pain (due to abdominal vein thrombosis or intravascular hemolysis)
  • Budd-Chiari syndrome, presenting as acute hepatomegaly and ascites (due to hepatic vein thrombosis)

Lab investigations reveal:

  • Anaemia: Normo-macrocytic; can become microcytic due to chronic iron loss
  • Hemoglobinuria: Resulting in chronic iron loss
  • High MCV: May occur due to marked reticulocytosis 
  • Elevated unconjugated bilirubin
  • Markedly elevated LDH
  • Cellular bone marrow with marked erythroid hyperplasia, progressing to a hypocellular or aplastic bone marrow
  • Increased susceptibility of RBCs to complement (C): Occurs due to deficiency of surface proteins CD59 and CD55. This definitive diagnosis is performed via flow cytometry (high sensitivity). A bimodal distribution of cells is seen, with a substantial population of CD59- and CD55-negative cells.

Treatment involves anti-complement therapy with drugs such as eculizumab (administered IV every 2 weeks) and ravulizumab (administered every 8 weeks). 

However, since these drugs are expensive, supportive treatment is exceedingly important:

  • Folic acid supplements (at least 3 mg/d)
  • Periodic monitoring of serum iron, iron supplements, and blood transfusions whenever necessary
  • Regular anticoagulant prophylaxis for patients with venous thrombosis or thrombophilia
  • Thrombolytic treatment with tissue plasminogen activator for patients with thrombotic complications

Bone marrow transplant or immunosuppressive therapy should be considered in very young patients with severe PNH and possible bone marrow failure.

Other options:

Option B: Ocrelizumab is an anti-CD20 monoclonal antibody used to treat patients with relapsing and primary progressive multiple sclerosis. It depletes circulating B cells through antibody- and complement-dependent cytotoxicity.

Option C: Tocilizumab is an anti-IL-6 monoclonal antibody used in the treatment of giant cell arteritis, rheumatoid arthritis, cytokine release syndrome, COVID-19 infection, and systemic sclerosis.

Option D: Durvalumab is an immune checkpoint inhibitor of the programmed death-ligand 1 pathway used to treat patients with stage III non-small cell lung carcinoma and limited-stage small cell lung carcinoma.

  • Autoimmune hemolytic anemia

questions.text: A patient was evaluated for hearing loss. Rinne’s test shows that air conduction is better than bone conduction in both ears. Weber's test lateralizes to the left ear. What is the diagnosis?

choices.text: Conductive hearing loss in the right ear
Conductive hearing loss in the left ear
Sensorineural hearing loss in the right ear
Sensorineural hearing loss in the left ear

questions.solution:
In the clinical scenario, the inference of the tuning fork tests is Weber's test lateralized to the left ear and Rinne's test normal. So the diagnosis is sensorineural hearing loss in the right ear.

Tuning fork tests are performed commonly with tuning forks of frequencies such as 128, 256, 512, 1024, etc. The tuning fork of 512 Hz is considered ideal as forks of lower frequencies produce a sense of bone vibration while those of higher frequencies have a shorter decay time. Some examples of commonly done tuning fork tests are as follows:

Rinne’s test is done by placing a vibrating tuning fork on the patient’s mastoid and when he stops hearing, it is brought beside the external auditory meatus (EAC). If he still hears the sound, air conduction (AC) is better than bone conduction (BC). The inferences are as follows:

  • Rinne's test is considered positive (normal) when the air conduction AC>BC is seen in normal people and people with sensorineural deafness.
  • It is considered negative when the BC>AC, and is seen in patients with conductive deafness. It suggests a minimum hearing loss of 15-20 dB.

 Weber test is done by placing a vibrating tuning in the middle of the forehead or the vertex and the patient is asked in which ear the sound is heard. The inferences are as follows:

  • Normal result is achieved when the sound heard equally in both ears
  • In conductive deafness, it is lateralized to the worse ear
  • In sensorineural deafness, it is lateralized to the better ear

Other options: 

Option A: Conductive hearing loss in the right ear presents with a negative Rinne's test (BC>AC) and Weber's test lateralized to the right ear. 

Option B: Conductive hearing loss in the left ear presents with a negative Rinne's test (BC>AC)and Weber's test is lateralized towards the left ear.

Option D: Sensorineural hearing loss in the left ear presents with a positive Rinne's test (AC>BC) and Weber's test is lateralized towards the right ear.
